title: Worth it just to play with Badgy
text: We took the guided tour from Isaac, who was great and gave us lots of information about the various animals currently being looked after. The highlight is of course the friendly honey badger, Badgy. From the minute we stepped in to his house he was up and around our legs wanting fuss and playtime. Isaac was great with him and gave him some good rough and tumble. Badgy also gave us a good demo of his intelligence by operating the door to his private den by himself. Aside from badgy there were lots of injured and sick animals being looked after and it was very interesting to learn about them and how they are being helped. Definitely worth a visit if you are in Kasane.

placeInfo.name: CARACAL Biodiversity Center

title: Recommend a visit if you like animals
text: The sanctuary does very nice work, rehabilitating injured or orphaned animals/birds/reptiles. I visited the sanctuary by myself and there are two types of visit: the standard or “enhanced” visit ($5 or $7), I opted for the enhanced tour and I really enjoyed it. My personal guide took the time to show me all the animals, explain about the animals’ habitat and history. You can interact with animals like the honey badger and tree squirrel etc. They also do a lot of educational work with the local community and I highly recommend visiting if you like animals and you’re in the area.

placeInfo.name: CARACAL Biodiversity Center

title: Informative and great hands on experience.
text: Very cheap to get into and worth paying a tiny bit more to have the hands on option. We held snakes, chameleon, bush baby and tortoise, saw lots of poisonous snakes, meerkats and birds but the undoubted highlight was the honey badger who kept closing his sliding door as he didn't want to come out. This centre does fantastic work, rescuing animals, eventually releasing them again when and if appropriate and educating the locals and school children about some of the benefits of these animals . It was a pleasure  to support this cause.

title: Worthwhile
text: An animal rescue centre where the staff are very caring towards the animals and very keen to tell you about them. It was a rainy day and this filled the time nicely. Bush-babies were cute, honey badger amusing and the eponymous caracal quite aggressive (presumably from previous ill treatment before he arrived). Many snakes and other reptiles in quite cramped vivaria, but at least they had been rescued and were still alive.

placeInfo.name: CARACAL Biodiversity Center
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District
placeInfo.address: Plot 3102 Airport Road, Kasane, Chobe National Park Botswana

title: Thoroughly recommended!
text:
I have to admit that we were a bit hesitant about going to this not very well advertised animal sanctuary. It is the only place like it that we came across in three weeks in Botswana but it is SO worth supporting. We were the only group that turned up on the morning that we went and it was great!. Isaac showed us around and we handled several snakes and some other animals. The pookies (bushbabies) were the stars but Isaac's stories kept us interested in all the animals.
The centre has at least one research project with an American university (mongoose-related as I recall), but the big educational issue is with schools, where it works to dispel the local myths, especially about creatures of the night. So many groups are too politically correct to explain what the locals believe so it was refreshing to get an idea of why chameleons were particularly feared as harbingers of death - and even better to handle one!
This place needs to be supported - so I thoroughly recommend it for that reason alone - but nowhere else comes close to providing such a hands on experience!

placeInfo.name: CARACAL Biodiversity Center

title: Hidden Gem

They’re the best.

title: This Centre is doing a fantastic job in education and rehabilitation of injured wildlife.
text:
This is a working centre and educates children and adults about local wildlife, people have the wrong idea on snakes, yes caution and knowledge is needed. Our guide had to leave us couple of times to with a couple of school trips, but left us with snakes, we have a little knowledge and know how to handle them. My wife went into teacher mode when children wouldn't come near and squealed, and she got some children to touch them and lose the fear. There are a lot of local snakes you wouldn't go near so the children need to know what to do.
There are injured animals and birds some can be release when well some can't.They came down to our hotel to remove a puff adder from the grounds and release it in the bush. Some wander around the place such as the one winged Marabou Stork
This is not a pretty place it is a working centre, please help them by putting some money in their donations box, they are doing a good job.

placeInfo.name: CARACAL Biodiversity Center
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District
placeInfo.address: Plot 3102 Airport Road, Kasane, Chobe National Park Botswana

title: Very interesting!
text:
We went there to see the snake farm. But this place turned out to be so much more than that! 
This place is a sanctuary for injured and maltreated wild animals of all kinds. The people working here are driving spirits with a great love for the animals they are caring for. Animals that can be healed will be let out in the wild. Others will find a loving home here. The sanctuary also takes on responsibility to educate visitors and children/school classes about animal behavior, to prevent future maltreatment of animals.

text: We are really glad we made the effort to go out to the centre. Any that can be released back into the wild are rehabilitated. Our guide was charming and informative, and local. We thoroughly enjoyed our time and learnt a lot. The cost is very low and well worth it.

title: Very interesting centre
text: i read reviews about this centre and decided to visit. The centre houses a range of wildlife that have been rescued, maybe from being smuggled over the border, or being hit by a car. There were many snakes, that I was curious to see (as it was winter when I was there there weren't many active snakes. There were also bush babies, that i had seen their eyes at night jumping through the trees, but had not seen them up close. There were also a pair of scops owls. These I had also heard in a tree above our campsite in Kruger, but not actually seen. The guide was very informative.

title: Nothing but a Small Run Down Zoo -  Run by Americans
text: No Aardvark on display, no touching of bush babies, not a any craft activity by a woman of African heritage.  In fact, not a single African woman even spotted.  The photos on their Facebook Page is deceiving too.  Upon arrival we were approached by a very rude,  American lady who was clearly involved in running this business, telling us that it's cheap "only P60".  She then left us in the hands of a guide who was very kind and embarrassed by her rudeness.  In short, you pay P60 to see snakes in small boxes and a handful of animals in small cages.  This American employee stated very clearly that the bushbabies are not to be touched or held, basically the box was opened and closed.  The Aardvark was not even seen or displayed, and the baboon was not even mentioned. You are allowed to hold the python, but you can hold a python in many places in the world.  P60 to hold a snake was outrageous.  Give this place a skip, spend your P60 in Chobe National Park for a whole day in the park, see loads of animals you will never see in another park, but animals in cages can be seen in any zoo. In short this is a tourist trap.  Last but not the least, after paying P60, we found a box at their exit asking of additional donations.  They also promote themselves as a "Womens Centre".   No sign a single woman of African heritage...just another trap.

The CARACAL team

title: New selfie-profile pictures for everyone!
text:
This biodiversity centre is still a small setup in Kasane, nothing huge, but really worth the stop. We also heard from friends to check it out and we al loved it. The biodiversity centre has two major attractions and a baby baboon.. but I'm afraid that baby baboon will be getting very big soon, so it won't be around for ever. 
The other two major attractions we found extremely interesting to see, feel and photography up close are the snakes, where you also get every good and detailed explanation from the guide and ... the stars of the centre.. Bush Babies! 
A bush-baby must be the cutest animal alive in the African outdoors, but they are very difficult to spot in the wild. Mostly they come out at night and then you only see their huge eyes reflect in your spotlight. 
This was for all of us, the very first time we could clearly see and hold a bushbaby and they are very cool... photos are attached :)

title: Chobe Crocodile Farm
text:
Entry charge to "Chobe Crocodile Farm"  was 100 Pulas and a employee guided me inside the farm that had many dogs which included a Dachshund and a Mastiff.
The employee took me to a large hallway having  Circular fish tank wells that contained crocodiles. . Was introduced to Ms  Pedzani,the caretaker and employee of this crocodile farm.She explained me the different crocodiles in different waterless tanks.One tank had only baby crocodiles which were 4 years old." Moremi" who is supposed to be over 100 years old is the prized breeding crocodile of this farm.The next crocodile of importance  " Mr Big Boy"  is the second oldest crocodile on the farm at supposedly 90 years of age. She feeds each large crocodile about 15 chickens once in three months.This particular hall exhibit of  the crocodiles was used for student and tourist tours and hence illustrations on the walls explaining the life facts of the crocodile. I was next taken to  the outdoors breeding pond enclosures which had numerous crocodiles including females guarding their eggs buried in sand.The females guarding the eggs are very protective and aggressive and one female close to the fence almost charged at me when I went too close. Ms Pedzani told me to keep my distance from the female crocodile as they can also leap a few feet and grab their  prey as seen in wildlife documentaries which in this present situation  could be my limb.She showed me the two different enclosures in which " Mr Big Boy" and " Moremi" were kept and finally while  departing met the owner, a white Botswanan  citizen Ms Sue.Slogrove who explained me her farm and the crocodile industry in Africa which is big commercial business. Her prized and most famous crocodile on her farm was " Nelson" who lived over 100 years of age expiring in 2004  and was also pictured on the stamp of Botswana.

title: Amazing wildlife
text:
Having travelled over a very narrow timber bridge we entered the Moremi Wildlife Reserve. 

The roads were quite rough in places and on a couple of occasions we bounced so hard we hit out heads on the rough of the vehicle as the potholes were deeper than expected, but it was so much fun.

Here we saw wild dog, hyenas - including their cubs, elephants and lions as well as giraffe, and plenty of birds.

After spending a couple of hours in the park we made our way back to our accommodation as you had to be out of the park by dark.

You can camp in Moremi, there are places to pitch your tent, cook a meal and have a shower but you need to be mindful of the wildlife around you.

Beautiful scenery and worth a visit.

title: Stunning Wildlife, but changing.
text:
Moremi has been absolutely battered since our last visit. Previously, across much of the area the bush was thick and right to the track edge. This is now very uncommon, the lack of water and especially elephant damage to the trees has resulted in a much more open landscape. Not really an improvement but we still managed to see many animals. Highlights were a honey badger, distant rhino, and an absolute multitude of birds. Sadly, we didn’t see lion here. Last time we spent a fabulous morning watching three lion at very close quarters.

Moremi is also busier than we remembered it. Many vehicles seem to come from Maun on a daily basis, and many are in poor repair. They also thrash around the place trying to maximise viewing opportunities without much thought to the animals welfare. It is high time the park limited numbers.

Driving in the area isn’t difficult but you absolutely must stay on the tracks. Also, slow is good, and increases your chances of animal encounters. If and when you do spot something don’t be surprised to see other vehicles come to see what you are looking at. Also, some of the guides have taken to telling others that there is a “five minute rule”. They expect you to move on so that they can claim a better viewing angle. There isn’t. Tell them to shove it! 

Moremi is an enchanting place, we have been to Ngorongoro and I would rate the two similarly. There are wildlife encounters around every corner and the bird life is exceptional. However, it is changing. Getting busier, reduced bush cover and (September 2019) very dry. Perhaps a good idea to go soon before mankind does his usual trick and ruins it.

Would we go back. Yup, we like the area, especially as we have now broken our Leopard duck with a great two cat sighting close to Fourth Bridge. However, in view of my previous comments about human intrusion, we probably wont.

Furthermore we found that the ablution facilities are not kept as clean and well maintained at the entrance gates,  as what one would expect for an important tourist attraction such as this.  The prices charged for camping sites, due to the Park fees, Vehicle fees and bed levies;  is rather high considering what you receive in return with facilities being neglected.

title: Capture Africa, best luxury tented safari!
text:
This September I was lucky enough to experience 5 days and 4 nights in the oldest protected section of the Okavango Delta, the Moremi Wildlife Reserve, Botswana. We were taken care of by the Capture Africa Luxury Safaris Team, with the added bonus of  having the owners, Brian and Hildrene Gibson right beside us on our safari. The Capture Africa Team have been operating since 1997, and over this time have developed an extraordinary team of heads, hearts and hands that know this part of the African continent like no other, and are proud to share it with all those who love simple luxury in the wilderness.

We were collected from Maun Airport, an immaculate Safari Vehicle awaiting our arrival. It was stocked with Ice cold refreshments and warm Ponchos for the dusty/windy Botswana Roads that lead us from Maun to the Delta. This gave us our first taste of the bush, as Elephants clambered through the woodlands, a herd of Buffalo crossing the road ahead, Giraffe ambling passed Baobab trees and Warthog digging in the dirt. 

We arrived at sunset, to Tswana voices singing a welcome song and our camp drenched in golden light, camouflage tents, nestled along a quiet section of the river in the heart of the Moremi Reserve. Warm, friendly greetings and campsite tours followed by an ice cold G&T by the fire overlooking the idyllic river with Openbill Storks preening themselves in the sunlight. Open-mouthed and pinching oneself.

Capture Africa have created the most extraordinary Luxury Camping Safari experience, the small, thoughtful gestures evident everywhere. From the delicious quality meals prepared with care, campfire rituals, the fully-equipped, comfort tents, African-style shower under the stars, and the friendly staff with limitless capacity to ensure your experience is memorable. Late evenings spent around the campfire sharing stories and listening, to the sounds of the wild; lions roaring, Hippos grunting and the eerie night calls of hidden owls. To drift off to sleep with these sounds in the background is both enlivening and strangely, familiar as the presence of these sentient, primal beings accompanies you into the night. 

The quiet mornings come with a beauty of their own, especially the sunrise safari . I know a fair amount of the wildlife species, having grown up in South Africa, but having them identified by an expert, and seeing them up-close-and-personal is incomparable to “armchair travel”. Led by Brian Gibson, a professional conservation guide & naturalist, we tracked, spotted and learnt another language over the 5 days, the language of the Wild. He shared insights, observations and stories from his decades of experience, and on our final days safari was able to track one of the most endangered mammals in Africa, the rare African Wild Dog. We sat inn awe watching the pack, having just made a kill, frolicking and playing in the veld oblivious to our stares and whispers from across the river. The birdlife was mesmerising, hours spent behind the binos, in silence, watching, and then comparing notes about all we’d seen over a hot cup of coffee and rusks in a Mopane woodland, under an Acacia, or on a fairytale-like section of the Khwai river. Pure, morning magic!

I will make my way back to the Okavango in this lifetime . Thoughts disappear, the heart beats louder and the wilderness creeps under the skin and into the soul like it’s home. This Luxury Tented Safari, is an enlivening way to capture Africa. Ke a leboga!

#Captureafrica #Okavangodelta #Moremigamereserve #Botswana #Khwai

title: Highlight of our travels around Botswana
text:
We travelled to Botswana with Jenman African Safaris, booked via Bench Africa, and visited several national parks/reserves in the Okavango Delta region and nearby. Moremi was easily the most rewarding of these. 

We made two day trips into the Reserve, one around the Khwai River and the other near the North Gate. The wildlife was just amazing -- we were exceptionally fortunate and saw lions (twice, including a kill), a leopard, wildebeest, elephants, hippos, giraffes, zebras, a variety of antelopes, crocodiles, so many different birds ... it really was like being in the middle of a David Attenborough documentary!

There's a bit of driving involved from wherever you camp on the southern side of the reserve, and an early start in winter can be pretty cold, but the rewards are well worth it!

title: 4x4 trip in Savuti
text: Fantastic trip to Savuti Game Reserve wildlife reserve located in Botswana. It is known for its large elephant population, as well as other species such as lions, leopards, and hippos. The reserve is also home to a variety of bird species. The landscape of the reserve is diverse, including savannah grasslands, wetlands, and rocky outcroppings. Visitors can go on safari drives and walks to see the wildlife, and there are also luxury camps and lodges available for accommodation. Overall, Savuti Game Reserve offers visitors the opportunity to experience the beauty of the African wilderness and see a wide variety of wildlife in their natural habitat.

title: Fantastic
text: Staff, location and cabin absolutely brilliant. Safaris and guide,Tua, just exceptional. Laundry done in a day, wine and food delicious. A must visit.

title: A tree climbing Impala?
text: One of the first things we saw here was an Impala up a tree. Of course it didn't climb the tree but was left there by a leopard. So we were checked in, relaxed and had our first game drive back to the same tree. Sure enough we saw our first ever leopard here. Then the second. Then the third. It was a mother and two sub adults. What could be better? So imagine our astonishment when an adult male came out of the bushes and joined them! A complete family group of  four. We spoke to Matto Barfuss who was also there. He spends six months of every year in the bush and hasn't seen that for ten years. What a privilege. Of course we saw much more in our three days. Wild dogs were an obvious highlight. And three young male lions relaxing together, one of which walked past the jeep so close I could have touched him. Food and service here was first class, as were the guides. Ask the guide about the Savute Channel, its an interesting fact.

title: Animals Galore
text: We had special moments every day Lions, Cheetahs, Elephant, herds of wildebeest & antelope, 100's of birds, giraffe, & best of all Painted Wolves (Wild Dogs !!!)

title: excellent national park
text: Beautiful views and wildlife. Saw many, many birds along with giraffe, buffalo, elephant, lions, impala, jackels, zebra and many more.

title: Absolutely Amazing
text: We had a wonderful time camping there, the staff was very friendly and best of all, the ablution blocks are super clean!

title: Amazing Animals
text: Watching the animals was incredible.   A leopard walked right along side our jeep.  Up close and personal with the animal water hole.

title: Above expectations
text: Got a private tour in a large safari vehicle. Eye in eye with all the wildlife, except for the leopard. Even witnessed a pack of wild dogs hunting and killing a small impala. Fabulous park.

title: Beautiful landscape, rich wildlife and lions paradise
text: Savuti was one of the highlights of my trip to Botswana. Not easy to get to the reserve, as the drive can be challenging, but I am so happy I spent 2 full days and 2 nights exploring this amazing area. I saw many animals, including a lion eating his kill first thing in the morning and 2 lionesses with 9 cubs - just amazing views, photography and experience.

title: Boring & being riped off
text:
If you have been to Kenya or other national parks, you will find this boring in terms of the minimal types & numbers of animal to be seen here. 

And the drivers of the park's game drive use dirty trick to ripe off tourists. The drivers said, "we are not supposed to drive off the track but we know that the lions are sleeping under the bushes. If each party pays USD10 and we will keep this secret and drive you off track to see the lions". We said NO but the driver still drove us off track to see the lion. And then force us to pay afterwards.

title: exceptional visit
text: very unique park in a forest, with superb amenities, with a/c, best foods, massage, spa, pool, game trips are A class

title: Bumpy road
text: Savute Reserve is one of the greener area's in the Okavango Delta during dry season due the precense of the Chobe river with a lot of wildlife in the area. The road from the Savuti Campsite to Ngoma gate is bumpy as a washboard with here and there deep sand during dry season, even with lowered tire pressure it is a very uncomfortable drive.

title: wonderful reserve
text: Take a guide through the reserves. Self drive is available but you see so much more wildlife when guided. This is a wonderful part of the chobe national park. Great wildlife viewing though very dry 2019. Dawn drives are a must.

title: so much fun
text: It was amazing.  Going in September they were experienceing an unprecedented drought so things were really dry. A llot of the watering holes were dried up , but I was able     to still see quite a few animals

title: Incredible Savuti
text: Incredible wild wilderness area where the absolute feeling of isolation is just magical. Viewed Lion, Elephant and Buffalo every day and Leopard twice in only 4 days.

title: Great game drives in quiet park
text: Saw leopards, cheetah, lions and cubs as well as elephants, zebra, impala, giraffe etc. Not as busy as the area around Kasane.

title: Great lions
text: In June it was very dry and sandy, so 4x4 are required. Use of a guide is recommended. Lovely stop/tea areas. Good sightings of elephant and birds.

title: Great sightings in Savute
text: We spent two nights in savute. We saw lions, elephants, honey badger and lots of antelopes. Had a peaceful stay with good cooperation from DWNP and SKL

photos.caption: Planning your next safari trip to Botswana? A good self drive tour guide available for all your safari needs!! contact tshepo@kalaharisafaris.co.bw

title: Savuti, the magic name, right? - somehow wrong....
text: The place is huge, and every part is different from the other. Savuti camp area: somehow crowded, a lot of roads, not many animals. Savuti marsh / end of savuti channel (which is bone dry again after 10 years flow), less roads, not many animals. Marsh road versus ridge road: Marsh - if driveable way better. Area around baobab forest / goha hills: away from the crowds - you might see roan. Lynyanti: at least some water, more animals, but difficult road (deep sand) from savuti. If you have not much time I recommend to spend either on the Chobe water front or in the Khwai area.

title: Perfect place for gamedrives
text: Staying at the Savute Safari Lodge we did two gamedrives per day in this reserve. It is amazing how many different animals you can find an how close your guide can bring you to them. Having a sundowner close to a waterhole where you can take pictures of elephants, giraffes, impalas and warthogs at the same time makes you feel like beeing in one of those films from National Geographics.

title: Amazing Experience
text: Watching animals and learning about the savanna ecosystem was exciting, educational and pure fun. Our guide was excellent, the room clean, cozy and safe, and the staff purely professional.

title: The best wild dog sighting ever!
text: Getting there is not for sissies, a 4x4 and some experience is required but once you're there, Savuti (along with Moremi, Chobe and Kruger Park) is in my personal top four. During our last visit we witnessed a wild dog chase-kill, what an experience.

title: Perfect gaming
text: The Savute reserve is very rich in game. We were very lucky and saw 3 leopards. The landscape is beautiful and stunning. The bushman paintings are a bit of a challenge to find.

title: Abundant game
text: The Savuti Reserve is an animal abundant reserve. We saw 12 lions of the southern pride at one spot and the two alpha males the next day. We did however not find the northern pride despite hearing their roars at night. Also spotted 5 leopards, but no rhinos.

title: Some great sightings
text: A relatively quiet park but with some great game sightings - as well as dozens of elephants, buffalo and hippos we were lucky to see a small pride of lions, a few giraffes and a leopard slinking through the Bush. Take a morning and an afternoon drive to see a variety of animals.

title: Animals galore.
text: So much to see,  so many elephants so if you are an elephant lover this is the place for you.   We had great guides who knew their stuff and answered our many questions.  This is truly an awesome experience.

title: One of my favourites for wildlife. But wilderness campsites are unkept.
text:
Game viewing at this national park is probably one of the best in Botswana/South Africa, been twice both times seem spectacular big cat sightings and wildlife. SO many animals to see and guaranteed sightings of all the animals and birds. 

Shame the tolerate tour companies driving off road despite it being banned-  leads to harassment of the big cats. 

Wilderness camping sites - yes they should be wild- but are dirty from campfire ashes/thorns.

title: Gigantic gray mammals abound
text:
Of course I'm talking about elephants, of which there are many in Chobe/Savuti (and Botswana in general), and Savuti in particular seemed to be home to some of the largest we saw in all of Botswana. 

The sand can get thick and the mud puddles deep (when it rains), so take note of that; also, in certain parts of the park you can drive for a couple hours without coming across another vehicle (so, I guess, also take note of that if you're not in caravan or whatnot). 

Savuti is splendid, though if comparing to Chobe Riverfront, I'd say you'll have a much easier time seeing animals--lots of, and a wide variety of--than in Savuti, but Savutis is still a special place, regardless of what the reviewere a few down from me thinks.

title: Beautiful Reserve lots of game
text: Because of the draught many animals were at the waterholes, like elephants, Gnoes, Warthogs and of course the huge pride of Lions

title: One of the best safari in Botswana
text: Savute is one of the best places in Botswana in safari. It has large variety of spices and very skilled and knowledgeable rangers who are able to track and find animals as well as to explain many interesting things about them. This site is special for large prides of lions hunting elephants. I certainly plan to come back and I can recommend this location for excellent safari experience.

title: Decent animal viewing nothing special
text: It was ok for a one day trip but to me doesn't compare to any of the major national parks in any of the 3 countries which adjoin.   Saw a herd of elephants at a spring, that was the highlight after 2.5 hours of driving and one giraffe, no cats at all either on the land drive or on the boat.  Didn't love it. Lots of tourists doing the same thing and route as us, felt way commercialized also.

title: Great animal viewing in October
text: October is a great time to go when everything is still dried up because you can easily spot the animals. We saw so many animals here. It is a huge area and we did have a safari guide. We even saw wild dogs and a hippo out of the water! Two things we missed in South Africa near Kruger. We flew out and the landing strip at Savuti International airport is just that - a strip of land in the middle of nowhere. This area is not easy to reach - we spent two hours driving on a very sandy "road" to get here. We loved how remote this place is. And it was very hot in October - 100+ degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Animals abound
text: This park is very spread out and you need to go with an experience guide. Other wise you will spent a lot of driving and looking without much good results.

title: Beautiful landscape, great game
text: The savute game reserve was our best experience in Botswana. Not too many cars, loads of animals, vaerious landscapes, we loved it

title: Elephant heaven!!!
text:
I simply have NEVER seen such a large number of Elephants, Water Buffalo, Hippos  and many more!!  Elephant heaven!!  We saw two young males fighting in the water, many babies crossing the river with their Moms, and actually found ourselves in the middle of a matriach Elephant and another elephant squabble!!  It was a little scary but we just remained still in our vehicles!  The best ever scene for Elephants.   Botswana's people were so friendly and kind!

Gotta come back!

title: Good location to see most of the African wild animals
text: .We saw lots of wild animals, lions, cheetahs, jackals, wild dogs, leopard, elephants, giraffes, varieties of antelopes and varieties of birds. The ranger was very good. But the weather was hot. Suggested best time to visit is in August, September

title: Semi desert Savute
text:
We stayed at Savute safari lodge(Delta and desert safari)
We had Bab as guilde for  the 2 days we were there
He was just amazing
Was very knowledgeable and also funny
Made the drives very interesting 
Took all efforts to show as many animals as possible 
We learnt so much about the animals and the Savute game park and also about the culture and life style of some of the tribes
Was very interesting and worthwhile

title: amazing game viewing
text: This is one of the most beautiful places to see a variety of animals and birds.  It was an amazing experience.

title: Great game viewing
text: We saw a leopard, lions guarding a sable antelope kill, lions mating and a pair of cheetahs in addition to the usual herbivores. All in a span of 24 hours and in close quarters.

title: a place we return to over and over again...
text: it is a wonder on earth. we have seen this place in the wet season and the dry season. every time it is a new and wonderful experience. to miss it anytime you would be in Botswana would be a shame,

title: Ed & Chris Africa-18
text: Great reserve to see many of the key species with the exception of rhino - we had brilliant sightings of leopards, cheetah, elephants, hyenena cubs in their den and birds.  This included some very unusual species and lions having sex every 15 mins!  Fairly dry habitat with watering holes and vast grassland plains.

title: one of the most boring park we have visited so far
text: Very few animals and even if Bushman paintings sound interesting, they are more a joke: first you only find them if you drive from one direction as the sign is visible only from one side and then you climb some rocks just to find a scribble of a cow and an impala? It’s utter mockery! At least they don’t charge you an entrance fee for that.

title: Best place to see wildlife
text: The Chobe national park is well protected from poachers and the animals roam freely. We saw many animals from up close and the game drives are well organized.

title: Everything is here!
text: We really saw everything we could have wanted to see, cheetahs, elefants, leopards, lions! very well preserved, rough roads.

title: Just wonderful
text:
Stayed in a lodge and did 2 safaris each day into this reserve. The drivers are all connected no matter which lodge they are from, so when something special is found it is quickly passed around. Saying that it was never crowded. The most vehicles we saw was, I think 7. 
The park has a few rules, the most important one is after 6:30pm all lodge guests are out of the parks and the local people know that after that time armed rangers go in to protect the wildlife. 
Botswana is away ahead of most of the world in recognising that their wildlife is all important and they will protect them any way they can. I for one salute them. The national parks are situated where they are needed ie on migration routes. 
Go and support Botswana and see amazing sights. Nothing is promised because this is a natural habitat but you could see some amazing sights. We did

title: This is real Africa
text: We enjoyed our stay at Savute Camp. It is so lovely to be so close to the animals. Listening to the lions roars at night were a highlight. We were only disappointed not to have a campsite near the ablution block. The office told us that they were fully booked and that was not the case at all. Lots of empty campsites (as well as next to the ablution block). Think they must get their paperwork in order!!!

title: Great reserve
text: We saw a lot of game here. We saw the most lions here than anywhere else in Botswana. The drive is dusty so bring a bandana to cover your nose and mouth if you are sensitive. The driver/trackers are great and pull the trucks up very close for great photos.

title: Looking for Big 5
text: Didn't see the Lion, Leopard or Rhino but did see other animals in their natural habitat. Elephants, wilder beast, zebras, jackel, ostrich. Once you have customised your self with rough roads, safari is a breeze. Actually, we got closer to animals here that in Chobe river safari.

title: The best safari experience
text: This is one of three safari camps we visited in May 2018 and it was the best!  Our guide OB was superb.  Our lodgings, meals, and overall experience was absolutely incredible.  I highly recommend Savute!!! We saw so many animals, up close and personal, could not have asked for a better trip.

title: Wildlife in abundance
text:
I had a 2 hour safari drive in the Savute reserve and what can I say? I saw dozens of elephants, crocodile, antelope, hyena, buffalo, and....a leopard!

We drove along the banks of the river and got up very close and personal with some moody motherly elephants. 

The park is picture perfect.

title: Take a walk for a quick stop view
text:
Worth the short walk to view - follow the main road out of town towards the Park and you’ll find it in the left.
Situated right outside of the Police Station.
Information Boards are helpful to give context.

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: Boab Prison Tree
text:
The Historic Baobab tree is situated in front of Kasane  Police Station.  which was hollowed out and used to hold up to 14 people.This particular Baobab tree played a major role in the administration of justice, distribution of mail and labour recruitments in northern Botswana. It was used as a gaol before the advent of modern prisons in the area.
The prison baobab has some cavities which served as prison cells in historic times. There are some windows like openings which appear to have provided both light and ventilation into these prison cell.

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: A historical spot
text: The baobab tree at the Kasane Police station was hollowed out and used to hold up to 14 people.  It's an easy spot to go check out, read a bit about on the placards, and marvel at the size of the tree.  It's also located at the police station so you're a close walk from there to several shops and restaurants (as well as the ATM/money exchange).

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: Great history
text: Easy stop to see a bit of history in Kasane.  This Boabob tree was used as local jail and now you can walk right in an get some great photos.

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree

title: The only tree with both a penal and postal history
text: Ancient tree with excellent reader boards about the role this tree played in Kasane's history, as well as the baobabs more traditional uses.

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: History Lesson
text: The tree is impressive and the history connected to it is also very interesting. So easy to miss but worth a stop outside the Police Station for a look

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: Interesting history in town
text: The boabab prison tree is at the police station in the town of Kasane, Botswana. There is interesting info at the tree and one has to use one's imagination to envisage what it was like to house prisoners in such a tree. Interesting and well worth the stop.

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: One of the biggest baobabs
text: Right next to the Chobe safari lodge at the police station you can see this big baobab tree, which was used as a prison. Amazing that a tree can grow this big

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: Unique!
text: Stopped there with our guide and really didnt expect this to be a real thing. Well, joke was on me, this actually used to be a prison inside the tree! Really cool little spot with some local history.

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: Boabab prison tree
text: This is a must visit. There is a tree right in front of the police station. With a info board. But that we do not know is behind the police station there is a tree that was used to hold 14 prisoners in side.will post pictures. That one is still in tact. Also the boabab tree closses it self when there is a hole in the side. Witch is visible on the big tree. It is still hollow on the in side.

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: On the list to see in Chobe
text: We had been toild of this spot - a part of the area's history and still standing strong. Interesting and the photograph of the tree will form part of our trip portfolio

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: Big Baobab zim
text: Also a very nice tourist attraction in Zimbabwe on your way to Victoria falls. With the locals selling their handmade stuff there

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: Beautiful tree.
text: In the center of the small village of Asane you’ll find this beautiful and old Baobab. It’s really wort a visit and a walk around and inside.

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: Don't miss the baobab trees !.
text: Amazing huge baobabs at the police station - worth a quick stop and photo.   Interesting history posted outside too..

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: Interesting.
text: This huge tree was once used as a holding cell for prisoners in Kasane. Although a quick look is all that is required it makes for a nice talking piece afterward.

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: Tourist spot
text: One of many boab trees that I visited whist in the area. It is fascinating how they grow  with such large trunk and small branches

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: Don’t miss this
text: It is in the grounds of the police station and is fascinating. There are information boards in English to tell you about the tree and it’ history.

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree

title: Memorable
text: Only in Africa would you have a Tree-Prison! It was like something from a fairly tale! But it worked and it worth seeing. How simple and rudimentary the "cell" was but still helped to keep up the law

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: Huge Baobab trees with a fascinating history
text: If you are in Kasane, it is worth visiting the two ancient and massive Baobab trees located at the Police Station / prison building. They are hundreds of years old. One of them has a hollow trunk and was formrly used as a "prison". The other was used as a "post office". It has a hole in the trunk where letters were placed for people who were expected to pass through Kasani.

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree

title: Leuk geschiedenis weetje
text: Aardig weetje op het terrein van de politiekazerne, ziet er  interessant uit, maar het verhaal erachter is het spannends ( voormalig postoffice en "gevangenis" )

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree

text: 20日間のケープタウンからビクトリアフォールズへのオーバーランドツアーで訪問しました。バオバブの木は葉っぱなどもいろんな目的に使えるとの事でガイドさんが説明してくれました。とにかく大きいです！

text: hier macht fast jeder mal Rast, schön im Schatten, beobachtet von den Vögeln, die ihren Nistplatz im Baum haben. Die "Buschtoilette" ist unübersehbar hinter dem Baum.

placeInfo.name: Boab Prison Tree
placeInfo.locationString: Kasane, Chobe National Park, North-West District

title: chobe park
text: Did a river safari on the way to Nogatssa pans lodge.  Enjoyed seeing the animals from the river - able to see more hippos and crockadiles.  Loads of elephants, water buffalo and antelopes.  Then to Nogatssa where the animals came to us - we sat on out porch and watched them drink.  We could hear them at night as they walked by our tents.  Instead of looking for cars as we walked back to the main lodge we needed to keep out eyes open for elephants and buffalo.  What an experience

title: AWESOME!
text:
What an incredible place to visit!  Elephants, giraffes, hippos, impalas, baboons and more and more and more!  We visited via boat and safari truck...both gave us incredible views of the wildlife!

What a life changing experience!

title: Elephants everywhere
text: This is the place to watch the elephants swimming in the river, hippos, birds, zebras, you name it.  a great place

title: Wonderful place off the beaten path...
text: must come here if you like being with the animals and not 10 other drive 4x4 cars. it is a great place.

title: Great River Ride
text: We saw hippos, crocs, elephants, water buffalo.  The wetlands are very pretty.  We saw some amazing birds.  Take your long lens to get the best shots.  This was one of our favorite runs!   The guide was very knowledgeable, and the boat was comfy.

title: Absolutely wonderful
text:
We have so much enjoyed this part. There is a lot of wildlife: hippos, crocks, birds, buffalos, giraffes and of course elephants.
It was amazing to see the big herds of elephants; playing/bathing in the mud or just enjoying each others company.
Truely magical to see! Would definetely recommend!

title: Beautiful boat ride
text: Here, we did one of many boat cruises and it was by far the best location for wildlife. We saw so many animals in their natural habitat getting on with their daily lives. It was especially amazing to observe the elephants playing in the water. Don't forget to look around at the wonderful scenery and watch the sun set here too. Simply a wonderful experience!

title: Even during rainy season great wildlife experience
text: We knew that there would be less wildlife in the river due to the season. However we still saw some 50 elephants making their way to the river. They passed our car very close which offered us great close up pictures.  Also lots of hypo, Buffalo, giraf and antilopes.. We did both self drive and organised game drives. In rainy season you definitely need a 4x4 car

title: Both from the river and the land...
text: Unfortunately we had only one day there but had the chance to visit both from the river and the land. It was amazing, we were thrilled. I am sure other parts of the Chobe National Park are beautiful but having the chance to visit also by a boat is a privilege. I want to visit again sometime.

title: A whole new experience
text: This is so unbelievable. If you have a chance to do this don't pass it up . So much to see, elephants  and hippos swimming rightbin front of us. Lots of water buffalo too and so many African birds. We booked this from our resort in Zambia as a day trip . Fabulous.

title: Chobe Riverfront
text: There were some amazing sightings here, lions, elephants, leopards etc, but be warned the driver can't follow the animals off road, so you won't always get close to them. Its definitely a game reserve to take your zoom lens to.

title: Wonderful in terms of wildlife, but it's proximity to the shooting farmers in Namibia should come with a warning
text: We ended our safari in Chobe.  After Savute, it was great to see the Chobe River and a ton of wildlife.  It was like a 1000 Noah's Arks had emptied out by the river (Namibia is on the other side).  Seeing the happy animals play in/near the water was great.  Seeing the lionesses and their cubs crossing from the open areas into the bushes was spectacular.  However, being present while a truckload of Namibian farmers with their guns chased two lions (and then hearing a series of 7-10 shots)...that was traumatic and it still gets my blood pressure up even though I waited three weeks to write this.  I looked away when I realized what was happening.  But there were at least a half dozen other safari cars next to us on the Botswana side of the river witnessing what was happening.  It was horrible.  Our guide later mentioned it to three "anti-poaching police"...one female officer said, "they can do whatever they want."  Hmmm...I'm very anti-Trump, but perhaps the idea of building a wall isn't so crazy after all.  Espcially since the lions will go where there is food and not be aware that it's unsafe on the Namibian side of the river.  I hope that the Namibian government aides their farmers in building better fences/protection around the livestock instead of making it ok to shoot lions.  I will never return to Chobe again because it's simply too damn close to Namibia.  I pray every day that no more lions die at the hands of man.

title: 3 day visit to Chobe
text: Interesting mix of animals and birds.  Crocs and hippos everywhere.  Water Buffallo peacefully mix with elephants, hippos and antelope.

title: River Wildlife
text: We went on a morning game drive and an afternoon game drive, both along the river out. I would have liked to have taken multiple routes, but at seams at this part of the park, the entry people determine what route you will take, rather than letting the guide follow the tracks and do their thing. We saw plenty of wildlife though; elephants, hippos, giraffes, zebra, impala, judu, jackal, honey badger (in the morning), brown hyena (not often seen), plenty of birds. The only thing we didn't get to see were cats, though we did see cat tracks.

title: Spectacular wildlife in an unspoilt evironmet
text: The experience of a safari in Botswana is unquestionably an amazing experience and real Africa. Take your time try and book 4 Wheel drive Landrover and guide and camp out under the stars. The country is full of wonderful wildlife without crowds. We travelled as a family of 4 for 3 weeks and came across a couple of dozen people so you have complete space and nature. Head up to Maun and do a fly over the animal below wading through the water it is everything you have seen on the National Geographic channel.

photos.caption: Victoria Falls formal dinner no more camping!
A bit close for comfort Botswana

title: Wilderness pure!
text:
It was my dream once to visit that remote area of Chobe NP. We were staying in Ghoha Hills lodge and took off early in the morning to Ghoha Gates where we turned to the right and drove along the park boundary (excellent road). Then we drove into the park (there are no fences) where Nxunxutsla Pan is. It took us 45 minutes up to there. The road disappeared a bit but one needs to turn left and it is seen again. We joined the main road along the Ngwezumba river.
The riverbed scenery is beautiful: red sand gorges, blue water and big trees along the river. Excellent habitat for leopards. 
Sometimes the road was washed away and the slope of the river bank in combination with holes demanded a big courage of the driver. The landscape was changed and there were water holes with a few shy animals who didn’t manage to escape from a car: there were no Toyota tracks on the road but only animal tracks. The animals are not used to vehicles there. 
We entered a wonderful Mopane woodland where we got a flat tire and stopped in the shadow of a big trees. I step out of the car and turned to be a ward during the wheel was changed: I was watching in all directions and listening. There were so many tracks of cats … some of them were petrified in the sand after the last rains. All those messages said: it is our place! And I felt like many eyes were watching me. I would not go through that woodland by feet even during the day light.
After woodland we got to Nogatsaa. There are a few waterholes there and some of them have wooden platforms. The platforms are obviously from 1960th or 70th and are broken down. We stopped by one and sat into the shadow with a cup of Italian espresso (from Hand Presso Machine) as two the rangers arrived. 
They introduced themselves and looked into our papers. It was obviously that they don’t have too much opportunities to chat because the visitors are sparse in Nogatsaa. They told us about a pack of wild dogs who killed Kudu a day before on that same waterhole and that the lions roaring every day. “You need to come in September! There are a plenty of animals here! And look we are repairing the waterholes and started to repair platforms for you, guys!”, they said. It was a very nice meeting, indeed. Friendly people from Poha Gate.
The most beautiful pan was Kwikamba Pan. The place was wide and open with some single trees. The breeding herd of elephants were grazing in the distance. Some birds were sitting close to the water. The colour of the grass changed from fresh green to dark brown making the pan very colourful. We drove around but elephants saw the vehicle and run away. 
We visited a few other waterholes. By one there was a military camp. The waterholes had beautiful scenery but the animals are not used to cars and are shy. According to the tracks there are a lot of animals in the area. 
The management of Ghoha Hills lodge can provide you an information about building a new lodge in Nogatsaa. At the moment it is not possible to stay there overnight because there no camping places or some other accommodation. Ghoha Hills owners/managers are going to build a lodge in vicinity of Kwikamba Pan which is supposed to start the operation next year (about May 2016) You can get more information from Abram, the manager of Ghoha Hills. The work must be done to get used animals to vehicles but after one-two years the area will be a hit because there are a lot of predators and zebra migration from Nxai Pan NP to Chobe river is going also through that area. If all platforms will be fixed they will provide an attractive hides for nature lovers. Wilderness pure! 
It took us about 4 hours to Nogatsaa from Ghoha Gate. 
There was high grass in some parts of the road - attention must be payed on radiator! We drove further to Chobe river front. The last 20km is a very deep sand and needs a good momentum! Before we got to the tar road we came to a waterhole where a breeding herd of elephants drunk in the orange colour of sunset. It was a very nice trip to Nogatsaa.

title: You can see lots of wildlife here
text: Our trip here was great and we spotted many many wild animals. The guide driving the 4x4 was very informative and great at spotting animals from a distance away!

title: Zona de Chobe apartada y natural
text: Se trata de una zona recientemente abierta y los animales no están tan acostumbrados a las personas, con lo cual la experiencia es genial

title: Elefanten
text: Im Chobe National Park konnten wir sehr viele Elefanten beobachten. Ein Highlight war die Elefanten im Chobe Fluss baden zu sehen!

title: チョべ川でのボートサファリ
text: 川沿いに建てられたホテルからボートに乗り込みチョべ国立公園内の川へとボードサファリです。水はとても綺麗で風も心地いいです。ボートサファリではカバの集団とワニそして、沢山の鳥達に会えました。日本とは違い、色が綺麗な鳥が多く沢山撮影しました。カバの親子が川から顔を出しては沈む風景は和やかで楽しかったですが、ワニは寝ていて、あまり迫力がないとうか、はく製みたいでした。

title: Excelente
text: La cantidad de elefantes es brutal. Fue probablemente el mejor safari que hicimos. Se ven muchos más animales, favorecido por la cantidad de agua que hay, y ya sabes, donde hay agua...hay animales. Es un buen consejo para un safari.

title: ボートサファリ
text: 水辺の動物が多いので単調になるのかなぁと思いましたが、クルーズをしながら、珍しい植物を見ることもできました。雨季は乾季に比べて水辺に動物が集まらないといわれていましたが、かなりたくさんいました。

title: Flott natur
text: Var på Game Drive tidleg om morgonen.  Blei plukka opp på hotellet i Kasane.  Såg masse dyr, fuglar, insekter, tre og blomar.  Inne på området var det rasteplass og toalett.

title: Espetáculo da natureza!!
text: O Parque Chobe é por si só um paraíso. Se participar dos safáris, poderá ver animais magníficos dentro de um contexto de vida natural incrível!

title: Sensacional!
text: Chobe National Park é muito bom! Sem dúvidas um dos melhores safaris da África. Parque bem estruturado e um show de bola da natureza! Muita vida e muita diversidade! Recomendo!

title: You can't really reach the dam itself
text: The same experience as many here below: we saw the dam for the very bad road (you almost need 4wd!) that goes to an entrance gate where the (friendly) guy asks for a permit and can't explain how to get it. Mind you: here in Gabs they use the word "dam" as well for the dam proper as for the lake made by it, and that you can reach from the yacht club (if you get in!) also by road only good for 4wd!

title: Gans dam !
text: The people at the gate wanted P100, unofficially ! so I didnt go in !  ! How much are they managing to rip off from  tourists ? The gate-keepers have found a gold-mine.

title: No go
text: We just wanted to go and take a look at the dam, but the official at the boom gate said we had to go into town to fill out forms. Then said we could go in if we paid that person cash . Oh dear. Please help tourists not dissuade them

title: The most amazing SUNSET!
text: The size of the dam is a surprise, it's huge, it stretches and stretches. The Yacht Club is a lovely place to come and chill whilst enjoying fresh air and smell of fresh water. Best time to be there is sunset especially on Saturdays when club members mainly hang out. The sunset could be the most beautiful thing in Gaborone!

photos.caption: Enjoying the beautiful sunset at Gaborone Dam

title: Lovely views, good food and the sound of waves
text:
We've been living in Gaborone for several months. And one thing I miss the most is the sight of the water. Finally, I found it! The last part of road to the club is very picturesque and once we arrived we could not believe our eyes: water all around surrounded by hills, no city in the sight. We wished to have lunch. First, we were a bit set off by the menu including mostly burgers. We were even more set off by cappuccino that was made of powder. But the burgers - nice! In fact, the best I've had in Gaborone. 

I highly recommend the place to spend a sunny lazy afternoon enjoying nice views, a burger and a glass of beer or wine.

title: Beautiful an sets
text: Wonderful to see the dam full g up.  Sunsets,drinks and simple food make this venue fun, light hearted and not to be missed.  Open Wednesday Friday Saturday and Sunday

title: Clean air, silence, nature and close to the city
text:
A group of us decided to go to the area next to the Yacht Club to see the dam. The hotel arranged for local drivers who stayed with us for the whole trip.
Arriving at the entrance there is security who requested a permit. I noticed a sign saying it was 5BP for each person. The driver suggested a permit could be obtained for a small donation - so 20BP later all of us were allowed in.
The road to the club had recently been flooded, but was now passable. We stopped at a number of places on the road.
The air was fresh and there was a good range of birds to watch. The scenery was really pleasant.
We stayed until sunset. The additional security at the Yacht Club meant we didn't enter.
Well worth a visit

title: Sundowner is a must at Gaborone Dam
text: If you visit Gaborone, you must see the Gaborone Dam from the Yacht club. Check the opening times as they are not always open. The dam was only 4% full on our arrival in February 2016, but after the heavy rains in December 2016 the dam was over 100% full, the water was falling over the concrete walls and even parts of Tlokweng were under water. Now you can visit the Yacht club, but you have to get on a boat to get to the club. The place is great for sundowners, but don't eat here. It will take ages for the food to be prepared and it is awful. The kitchen is just not equipped or staffed to manage large groups and food. Just go for drinks to watch the sunset over the dam and the mountains and have a nice meal in town.

title: relaxing
text: prefect spot to go and meditate, relax, for meetings. the river view is awesome if you love birds this is the place to be

title: Horrible
text:
The security was rude the roads were bad and unsafe - when we eventually arrived the security said you can't go in 
Do t waste your time

title: Interesting spot.
text: Interesting spot for a visit especially when it is 95% full. Something that has not happened in a long time. The February rains hae swelled the upstream rivers resulting in the ustream dams being full and the overflow now making its way into the Gaborone dam. The fiil of the century.

title: Amazing View
text: The dam is huge and has amazing view if you're standing on the Yatch Club Balcony, I love the fact that you can self drive around it & enjoy the view at your own peace

title: What a view
text: The view from the Gaborone Yacht Club is superb when the dam has water, and although the dam is only 32% full one can imagine what it is like when it is completely covered. The cafe is visually perfect for this type of establishment and is a photographers delight. We were only there for drinks bu the food looked ok and the beefburgers ;looked very good as didi the chips. This is a must if you are visiting Gaborone

title: Yacht Club at the Gaborone Dam
text:
We tried to visit the Yacht Club at the Gaborone Dam and were harassed at the WUC Security Gate. Not sure what the rules are but they eventually let us in. While the water levels were very depressing it was interesting to see the old ruins just a couple 100m from the Club house. 
These have not been seen since the dam was constructed as the dam has never reached such low levels.

title: Beautiful at sunset
text: We went sightseeing at the western entrance and it is beautiful at sunset, with clouds and lightning in the southern sky. The gate staff were very friendly and helpful; they advised that the dam is safe to stay over at and there are impala, warthog and other wildlife at the dam. I will definitely visit the dam again and come try my hand at fishing for the tilapia/bream, carp and barbel that are present in the dam. Hopefully the rains will come soon and fill up the dam. Even though it is very empty, it is still a large expanse of water and a sight to behold, especially with a high quality camera.

title: A place to go if you are cautious
text: There is two areas to go to, yacht club or the dame itself. Yacht club is good and popular, the dam itself is dangerous and should be visited with big caution

title: Our dam is sad, very sad!
text: Beautifully positioned area south of the city centre but so, so wasted.  Not for visitors as trying to organise the necessary permits to get into this area is extremely difficult and time consuming. Gate staff are hostile unfriendly and unwelcoming not encouraging visitors.   Road to the gate is sand and badly worn.   Once inside you can pinic close to the water which is extremely low.  Fishing is not allowed.   Peaceful.  This area could be a jewel for locals and visitors and one of the highlights of a city lacking welcoming safe outdoor space.

title: water fountain
text: visit and enjoy the water  that nature has offered.unfortunately , the water is at its lowest level as rains have not been pouring as expected.

title: Great view and bets steak in Gabarone!
text: Great food, great atmosphere. Service a bit slow and th ladies in die kitchen can do with an upgrade on facilities.

title: Empty!
text: With the drought, the Gaborone Dam is nearly empty - a big worry for the Botswanan people and government.  But it was beautiful for hiking and rock climbing.  We had to go to a government office to buy a license and photograph option.

title: relax
text: Great place to meet the locals Friday night they come from work to relax And are a sociable lot generally

title: Market at the dam
text: There was a market held at the dam late 2015 , it can work , however the dam was very dry and in a sad state . The vibe was great and the food offered was quite decent and well priced

title: Usually a lovely spot but...
text: I have been a couple of times before, but due to the current drought (Nov 2015) it is emply.  Very depressing

title: Flamingos!
text: Yes we were the recent lucky few to see the Flamingos in the damn.  What a treat. Great place to go for sundowners as the view is lovely.  The fish and chips seem to be a hit with guest.  Sometimes the wine is buy one get one free.  Wednesday & Friday night's seem to be favorite night's. Great way to unwind from the day without the hassle of a loud restaurant or to many people.  There is a fee to enter.  Closed on Thursdays.

title: Regular Weekend Visitors
text: We used to here back in the 70 s quite often it was a treat to see large expanse of water in landlocked dry country. We used to BBQ, visit yacht club and watch the huge 4 foot lizards slither into the water.

title: The main dam near Gaborone
text: The Gaborone dam was built few decades ago to collect water for supplying the capital of Botswana. It has excellent tourist potential, but was not utilized. There is only one semi-open restaurant, Yacht Club (very attractive name for the landlocked country). There are ruins of the former amusement park City-Scape, but not nice to see today. Very good spot for fishing, if you do not have any other need or wish. All in all - good to know that is there, but not enough good to be recommended.

title: Now officially closed
text:
We viisted the Gaborone Dam while on our Travels and sas to say that this once beautiful Dam has now been officially closed .Due to the drought over the last three years ,Gaborone Dam now no longer exsists .There is no water and completely dry .

Regards 

Ben and Family

title: FISH OUT OF WATER
text: The yacht club is our favourite unwind destination on a Friday after work. Even though the dam is bone dry the restaurant serves the most delicious fish and chips in town. In good years the dam has plenty of water and is very popular with local yachtsmen, but climate change seems to have sealed its fate and the inflow this year was zero.

title: Unwind yourself
text: Nice place with a wonderful view to the dam and if water level is ok you have the feeling that you are somewhere in the Mediterranean. Excellent for pravite parties and big gatherings. Or even for a drink and relax after work.

title: Bone dry!
text:
Not it's fault but this dam is bone dry!  
Despite this, it is somewhere to go in Gaborone and there are still plenty of birds about and you can have a picnic out there for a small cost.

title: Not much happening here
text: We arrived thinking we were going to see something special but in reality it was a nice restaurant overlooking the water with hardly anybody there until the sun was going down, then a handful of people arrived just to see that.

title: Basic - relaxing and great
text:
It is a good meeting place at the end of a long day at work.   Enjoy a glass of red wine/cold beer, relax and watch the sunset and a beautiful view of Gaborone
On Wednesday and Friday nights are the night to visit, it is an open night, great relaxed vibe and and lots of people, light meals are served. 
The Yacht Club also hosts a lot of sporting function; cycling, regattas, cross country marathons etc. and they have a live band (Richard Coughlan and his gang)occasionally.
It is a great place to relax out in the open under the African Skies, what a way to end the day.
Electra is your host.

title: Not much fun in dry season
text:
It's not the most accessible place in the world and you do need a permission to enter. It doesn't cost much to get but we didn't know about it and didn't have it. Fortunately I was with some locals and we managed to persuade the guards at the gate to let us in for a small fee (pretty much what the permits would cost).
There was hardly any water in the dam because it was almost the end of dry season but it was still interesting to see and a nice walk around the area which is usually covered with water.

title: Another Sundowner Spot
text: Aka Gaborone Yacht Club - signposted off the Old Labatse Road  just past  the railway crossing and reached down a rutted dirt track , this is ostensibly the headquarters of Gabs  Yacht and Canoe  clubs on the reservoir that serves the city . Usually members only , but on Wednesday and Friday evenings  guests may sign in for the sake of a small parking fee. Thereafter  reasonably priced drinks and bar food but the main attraction is the glorious view across the reservoir ( you may be lucky to actually see water !) especially at sunset when the cooling breeze after a scorching day makes it one of the best places in town  for a sundowner .

title: Extremely difficult to get to
text: Gabs is not a spur of the moment city. In order to do anything tourist-y you must have planned it at least a week in advance. Having decided to visit the dam on our last day, my friend and I found ourselves faced with very tired and frustrated guards to the dam. You need a permit to visit the dam. And no, permit offices are not open over the weekend. There is a massive fence around the entire dam and as such, permit entry is the only way. Unless you have wire cutters or stumble across a make-shift entrance used by locals.

title: Inaccessible and closed
text: We were driving around for a long time looking for the entrance which is impossible to find, even with a GPS! When we finally did find it we were told to go get a permit at some government building in the city centre. Very disappointing. We literally had to wake up the lady at the gate and she wasn't best pleased about it. She was yawning and stretching while saying "where is your permit?" My advice is: Don't bother

title: Nice view
text: Nice spot for a drink and casual dinner.  The sunset was beautiful, even if the dam is not very full.  The yacht club has a fire pit for when it gets chilly at night.  Worth the drive to see the landscape surrounding the city.

title: Great sundowners
text: I tell everyone who asks that they should pay a visit to the yacht club at the dam. One of the most scenic places in Gaborone,it is a great place to enjoy sundowners, and there is decent food available.

title: Great for kids
text: Went there as a kid with my school and learnt how hydroelectricity was made. It is outside the city and if you really want to enjoy shoot for a weekend.

title: Unwind
text: Good place to relax and unwind after a long busy week at the office. Sundowners with friends and/or family

title: The Yacht Club
text: A stunningly depressing view of the almost completely empty damn. Cheap drinks on wednesdays and fridays surrounded by expats and tourists. Apparently there are burgers you can order which are good. Sunsets are always spectacular.

title: Drinks at the Gaborone Yacht Club
text:
Call ahead to make sure they're open.  Perfect place to watch the sunset, catch up with friends, and enjoy an African tradition... the sundowner!

Small fee to park your car.

title: Water level at 15%, and falling
text: When the reservoir is full and the sun is going down, the Yacht Club is the most wonderful place for a drink. In fact, many a wedding has taken place with this backdrop. Regattas and raft races held here are great fun and often well attended, there are several public sites for a barbeque on the opposite side of the water from the Yacht Club too. Currently though, the water is very low and the lake bed needs dredging, so this is not the most attractive of places.

title: Gaborone Yacht Club
text: This is one of the best kept secrets of Gaborone.   A stunning view across the water and often spectacular sunsets.  Non members pay a small entrance fee but it is well worth it.  Good quality pub food is on offer and the beers are always ice cold.

title: The dam is empty!
text: Down to 16% water level in the dam...  However the Yacht Club is a nice place to go for a drink...  I assume that this review is really meant to be for there?  They also do pretty good food so well worth visiting!

title: Gabs Dam
text: As I have said in my reviews just because I live here I often don't go regularly to the places and therefore cannot mark the red parts and therefore cannot submit my review, but as I am a local I feel I know about the places and want to share my thoughts! I have not been there but just wanted to say it all depends of what time of the year you go! I know for a fact the dam has very little water at the moment and therefore all the water shortages in Gabs. So ask before you go about waterlevel! But have heard it is a very nice place to go when there is water!!!!

title: Gaborone dam
text: Really quite pretty, although very low at the moment due to our continuing drought. Bar open most evenings, and ok food. Best sunsets in Gaborone from here

title: magnificent views
text: This place was like out of a fairy tale. The views are outstanding and the most romantic place I have ever seen. Everywhere you look there is beauty. I went during the day but I can imagine at sundown it would be truly magnificent

title: just the movement of water
text: nice cool place and good for mind relaxation...u jst think of nature and smell natural scents....i lav the place.

title: A beautiful sunset venue.
text: Well worth a visit if you are in to sailing.  The club sits on top of a small hill overlooking Gaborone dam.  It has a reasonably priced bar and a restaurant which operates sporadically.

title: Impressive
text: The tour guy gives the place more life and character. Was such a pleasant experience.  Would highly recommend it to anyone interested in the history of the country

title: Connect with the history of Botswana
text:
This place is worth visiting. It literally takes you back to history class. I loved the energy of the site keeper who had the whole story off head, and the energy he used to say the word Pula. When you visit Gabs, do pass by this place and connect with the history of Botswana.

May be the seats can be improved.

title: 3 statues and nothing else
text: So Botswana has a great history around these 3  chiefs, but they have not put much effort into this attraction. A few dilapidated seating areas and nothing else.

title: Worth the Visit
text: Impressive monument. Got to learn how the three Chiefs petitioned to have their country outside the influence of Cecil Rhodes and his companies.  Our guide was very knowledgeable and made the experience fun. Worth the visit.

title: History on display
text: To be fair, there isn't much to do in Gabs. This monument is worth a visit and admission is currently free. Try to visit during a time when guides are likely to be around. I went for the first time and just took a quick walk around. There isn't much written information to tell you what you are looking at. The second time, I was with my family and a guide offered his services. He was well informed and we got a lot more out of the experience. It was a good way to learn more about the country's history.

title: A Must for All Visitors to Botswana
text: Compulsory stop for anyone who wants to know the colonial and modern day history of Botswana. The guides are knowledgeable and friendly and offer insights into Botswana history that provide context for a visit to the country and understanding its people.

title: DIKHOSI MOLUMENTS
text: These historical giants placed at CBD Gaborone next to Magistrate Court give the place a status. Evey morning travelling to work was a reminder that the place is respectable and prestigeous, excellent planning of the City. Gives value to the whole area, including the SADC house.

title: one-dimensional
text: Look at these pictures and that is as good as going there. I suppose many tours include it since there is almost nothing to see in this city and it remembers an important historic fact. That's all.

title: Wonderful sight see
text: It depends when you go there. It's located in a busy area, but the place itself is fantastic and not conjested with people.

title: Historical Gaints
text:
Place located at the CBD Gaborone, Place called 3 cheifs .  history  makers of of Botswana. Calm and quite place 
very closer to many hotels ,banks, Shopping malls. Near to the high court and many Government offices and SADC  building. Good place to visit

title: Worthy !
text: A site where the history of the nation is depicted in a simple yet magnificent way . Impeccable guide will take you through the significance of the site . Not to be missed on your visit to Botswana .

title: Safe jogging
text: It's a busy area in the CBD, but has enough space and opportunity to jog with friends between the hours 5pm to 7pm or in the mornings on weekends

title: Sunday Drive
text: Me and my wife visit the site in Descember when she visit me in Bobs from SA. The site is very clean and the staff very friendly and informative. Learned a bit about the history of Botswana

title: Botswana History Lesson
text: What a great idea to go visit the 3 Chiefs statues. The place was clean and the guide was excellent. He was very knowledgeable and friendly. The place it self was very clean. I would recommend that all take 30 minutes of your stay in Gaborone and go vist the monument.

title: Botswana's History in one place
text: Here tou can see the big statues of the 3 Chiefs of Botswana. On the left + right side of the statues, there are some portraits with some explanation regarding the periods Botswana went through since 1880

title: Interesting place
text: The place is very clean and in a big yard. The statues are very big and cleary visible. The yard is painted with the colours of Botswana flag.

title: History of Botswana  in the name of 3 dikgosi's
text:
Located at the recently developed/developing area named (Posh) CBD is a definitely worth watching with no entrance fee and guides available to explain the history behind the Three Dikgosi's and how they travelled to UK and claimed to The Queen to save Bechuana Land and also to give Independence.
If visiting in summer Please do carry a small coloured umbrella individually as there are no much shady places.

title: Impressive & Nice Monument
text: Gaborone doesn't have many attractions, but if you're already there, don't miss the opportunity to visit this monument (free entrance & parking)! The place is being cleaned & watched over, so it feels nice to be there, learn about the founding fathers of Botswana, & take a photo with their figures.

title: The Three Dikgosi, Tribal Chiefs
text: We were amazed at the attention provided by the staff. He was a mine of information and open to any questions. He enabled us to understand the value of refugees, heroism, protection, endurance, global responsibility, and independence with Botswana fighting  alongside allied forces for freedom and against racism.

title: Rich Historical Site
text: Found an officer who is well knowledgeable about the History of the place. We were left in awe. He went on explaining what ever pillar there represents and why

title: Wonderful tribute to Bostwana history
text: This is a good introduction to Botswana's path to Independence. The three chiefs were critical in this path. Their statues and the pillars around them provide lots of information as well as confer respect on the groups. The site also provides a great view of the new CBD.

title: In Awe
text: The history of Botswana is written through these men. I visited the statues and was in awe of Afrikan excellence.

title: Beautiful art
text:
We visited the monuments and we were fascinated.
A good spot for souvenir photos.
We will carry the beautiful statues in our memory

title: FUN AND INFORMATIVE TO VISIT
text: It is quite a special, interesting and unique place to learn about Botswana's history and her road to independence. I love that it can host events of high standards like it has before eg WORLDS' STRONGEST MAN, BEAUTY PAGEANTS etc. It's also a great spot for taking cool pictures. It's definitely a must visit if you in and around Botswana CBD.

title: Nice if you have nothing better to do.
text: Guess the fact this has such a high rank on TripAdvisor tells more about Gaborone then about the statutes. It’s a nice place if you have nothing else to do but that’s it.

title: History packed monument
text: A history and heritage attraction you have to see in Gaborone. the guide is very knowledgeable and well articulate

title: Botswana pride with Its Three Chiefs Monument
text: The Three chiefs monument pride Botswana since tourists come in large numbers to view chiefs who went to England to ask for Botswana s independence.The monument also attracts Locals more special school children around the country.It has interesting history to educate people at large.It is located in the Central Business District (CBD) where most people can access it easily.

title: Fascinating insight into the perils of colonialism...
