text: Firstly, who could not be impressed by these (North Korean-built!) statues showing three incredible men who went to visit Queen Victoria to ask for a 'Protectorate' rather than fall into the hands of Cecil Rhodes' BSAC (which had just been humiliated in the Jameson Raid farce) or the Boers. A good place to spend an hour - the guides are informative and there are information boards explaining key events in the development of Botswana.

title: A Monument
text:
A beautiful setting in the CBD of Gaborone. The Three Dikgosi Monument is a bronze sculpture located in the Central Business District of Gaborone, Botswana. The statues depict three dikgosi: Khama III of the Bangwato, Sebele I of the Bakwena, and Bathoen I of the Bangwaketse. 
Worth a visit.

title: The Three Chiefs Monument in the CBD Gaborone, Botswana
text: One of the greatest landmarks in the Capital City of Gaborone. Situated In the hub of the city and accessible easily by road or a walk from the bus terminal. Get to know all the history associated with the Three chiefs who took a long journey across the sea to meet the Queen Elizabeth and seek protection.

title: History in Statues
text: If you want to know the history o Botswana, visist these statues. There is a misconception that the three chiefs went to England to seek indepedence but that is not true. They went to England to seek protection against be annexed by British South Africa-John Cecil Rhodes.

title: Worth the visit
text:
A piece of Botswana history in the middle of the CBD. I like that the area is bang slap in the middle of a populated area and remains open late. The assistant we saw on the day was very courteous and articulately answered all our questions. 

Visitors to the monument must be warned that that's literally all there is to do and see there and that's not to say, people shouldn't go. It's still worth a visit.

title: history in colours
text: place worth visiting to gain instite of how Botswana was built after the independence.  The guide is very knowlegeble and informative. No fee is charged but can make a donation. BotswanA ROCKS

title: Birthday
text: What a historical site that this place is the caretaker was so articulate in taking us through the history of botswana

title: Founding Fathers of Botswana
text:
Across the road from Main Mall, on Khama Crescent, you’ll find the Three Dikgosi Monument - a trio of 5.5 m (18 ft) tall bronze sculptures depicting three chiefs: Khama III of the Bangwato, Sebele I of the Bakwena, and Bathoen I of the Bangwaketse.

These 3 Dikgosi reigned in colonial Botswana (then known as  Bechuanaland) and played a significant role in the country’s history. Had they not travelled to England in 1895 to plead with Queen Victoria and Joseph Chamberlain (the then Secretary of State for the Colonies) to separate the Bechuanaland Protectorate from Cecil Rhodes's British South Africa Company, Botswana may not have gained its independence.

The monument is quite inspiring and is definitely one of the places to go to visit in Gabarones' CBD.

title: Monument in center of the city
text:
This place is in center of the city. Place is honouring the key people of botswana. Worth visiting one of monument. Place is quiet beautiful. Good to know about the great leaders and their contribution.

Surrounding offer lot of restaurant near by. CBD n MaSa square are the key building.All other place are just near by at walking distance.

title: Learn about Botswana history
text: This was a stop that was part of a tour of downtown Gaborone. The monument is impressive, beautiful setting, but what is most impressive is learning about the recent (200 yrs) history of the country, from one of the monument's local, very knowledgeable, guides. This is a good place to get a feeling for why Botswana is such a unique country. The guide's comments were complemented by our tour guide Andy, from heritage adventures tours, both rendering our visit memorable. I would have liked to stay longer and learn more (we stayed for about 40 min). This was a hot day, and umbrellas are recommended.

title: Three Chiefs Monument
text: A must visit, rich history of the Republic of Botswana, how she escaped oppressive apartheid regime.

title: The Dikgosi monuments
text: A great way to begin your journey and understand better the then Bechuanaland protectorate and the now Botswana. This is an interesting and very special pierce of history which highlights the country's success story.

title: Very nice to see
text: I stopped by the monument on my way to the airport. It is very clean and no-one harrases you on your visit. There is security on duty. The monument is beautifully maintained and informative.

title: our guide made this stop special
text: We learned so much about Botswana's history by moving to the each of the six areas and learning of the three chiefs. Our guide was exceptional in bringing together pre-colonial history, years of being a British protectorate the three chiefs and the first president when Botswana gained independence.  This site made for a great start and provided understanding of this very special country.

title: Epic Stop
text: One of the place to pass by when you are around Gaborone to see but I do suggest having a guide to explain to you

title: Pleasant stop
text: We were impressed with the site, and the area was ckean and well kept, making it more of a statement.  We didnt have a guide (he was busy with a group) so some of the symbolism was lost on us. It does need a very clear and obvious explanation as to why these 3 are in pride of place (a leaflet perhaps?) So we googled it back at the hotel. Worth a visit

title: Choose your guide wisely
text: Just a large, paved area with a statue and six pillars? No,much more that this. Given the right guide, this becomes the definitive history of Botswana. Perhaps we were very lucky to get a guide called Timothy, who proved knowledgeable and passionate. We spent a fascinating two hours with Timothy. There is no entrance fee, however you are very welcome to provide a gratuity for your guide as you leave. Well worth the tip for this guide.

title: Nice if you could get there.
text:
Google things to do in Gaborone on the weekend and the Three Chiefs statues jumps up.  Well, I went with the one of the clan to find it fenced around, locked up and no-one at home - other than the policeman eying us suspiciously.  Perhaps that we were the only people around to eyeball didn't help, but we didn't get the memo.

Please open the place up and let us learn more of your post colonial history!  It looks well kept and would make an interesting stop in Gaborone on the weekend.

title: Informative
text: Took the option of having a guide to talk us through the monument which i would recommend as they were able to explain the symbolism of the monument as well as tell the history of Botswana. Timothy the guide was very enthusiastic and informative. Well worth a visit for anyone in gabs.

title: Amazing tour guides will captivate you at The Three Chiefs Monument
text: The Three Chiefs Monument is in the heart of Gaborone's new CBD. It is picturesque and has the High Court building in the background. The statues are well detailed pieces of art. What I love the most are the tour guides as they narrate the history of Botswana. They are so captivating!

photos.caption: Listening to the tour guide at The Three Chief's Monument
Looking at something at The Three Chief's Monument
Listening to the tour guide The Three Chief's Monument
Paying attention at The Three Chief's Monument
Enjoying the tour guide's story at The Three Chief's Monument
Taking refuge in the shade at The Three Chief's Monument
Listening to the tour guide at The Three Chief's Monument
Group photo at The Three Chief's Monument
Group photo at The Three Chief's Monument
Botswana 50 commemoration at The Three Chief's Monument
Botswana 50 commemoration at The Three Chief's Monument

title: Worth a visit
text: Recommended a visit with the tour guides. Free entrance. Timothy was excellent and had lots of information on the history of Botswana

title: nothing interesting
text: It’s all fallacies and nothing that catches an eye. I could add a picture to prove my assertions but it wasn’t even worth to fill my phone memory but if you have time to waste on your hands why not give a try.

title: leisure
text: i usually go out after the training to exercise my mind and view the beauty of the town, and it is of good course to remind myself of historical statues. this is the place where one can go out sit and stair at statues and our own Parliament

title: Khama camp facilities
text:
The camp sites have no electrical points or dish washing facilities. Ablution very far from the camp site number 2. Ablution was clean, however vary small and crammed.
Location is good, reserve is good, but it needs better facilities.

title: A beautiful Sanctuary that does a great job with our endangered Rhinos.
text: Friendly and efficient staff at the reception. They have a restaurant at the reception. We camped in D1 and D2 . Campsite 9 is close to ablution block. The ablation was clean and had hot water. No electric points at campsite.

title: In need of maintenance and a decent cook!
text:
3rd time staying at Rhino, as it’s ideally located between the border and the Delta.
The chalets are falling apart and in need of a refurbishment.
The ‘restaurant’ never has the full availability of the menu and cooking is slow and not that good.

Still a good opportunity to see game and the park is well tendered.

title: Pretty Refreshing Spot
text:
After so many years of being a regular Khama Rhino visitor, thought I'd finally share my over the years experience.

Normally I do self drives with friends usually on the way to my hometown (Palapye). The staff is always sweet (bring your I.D). Locating the animals is always so easy though at times the Rhinos and Giraffes are difficult to find 🤦. But overall the drive around the sanctuary seeing all the animals is super refreshing.

I've spent a night in one of their A-line chalets before. The rooms were clean, I wasn't really impressed with the cleanliness of the floor of the outdoor shower, the toilet was sorta okay.

As for the toilets in the sanctuary itself for public use during drives, they are not really well monitored but they are okay-ish.

title: Good animal viewing
text: Enjoyed the self game drive, although the morning was hot we easily spotted animals seeking shelter from the sun in some shady tree areas. We were fortunate to spot an abundance of Rhino as well as Zebra, Giraffe, Impala, Waterbuck and various BirdLife. You need an AWD or 4X4 to self drive the sandy roads or book a drive with a guide at reception area.  Ring your ID as they will need it to make copies when registering you. Only thing we spotted that needed attention was the Toilets! Urinals we’re flooded and so was the wash basin. Hopefully that gets sorted out quick.

title: Rhino eyes
text:
the Sanctuary is not one of the top attractions in Botswana,  All is about the Okavango....yet it is worth going to. There is a little gift shops where good stuff costs 1/2 than in Gaborone. And the guides are knowledgeable and clearly familiar with the habits of the animals.
The rhinos are superb and...a bit scary...what if they don't like us? They are big!!!!But they look at you through those small eyes...judge you are not a threat and go back to lie down under the shade of a tree. One can take loads of photos of these big, white creatures. Then there are smaller ones, antelopes, with their swirling horns, and the tall necked giraffes, who look a bit scared...even though they should be accustomed to the inquisitive eyes of people. There is plenty of time to look at the wildlife. What one does not see here is elephant and hippos...but elephants may cross the road at any time in Botswana and hippos are in the Okavango delta. Rhinos are a bit different, with that big heavy head...I wondered about what they think.
WE spent much time simply staring at a rhino family. And as much as I love penguins, I realized that there is something unique in this part of Africa. There are mysterious animals and there is the connection to the ancestral world whence humans came out from

title: Great experience
text:
Big reserve with loads of animals, mainly rhinos, impalas, zebras, birds, gnus. 
Driver was informative and made sure we so as much as we can.

title: Brilliant sightings for rhino
text: Spacious campsites with big trees. Good ablution facilities with hot water. Lovely bird hide and rhino's on the pans. Restaurant is a bit of a let down.

title: Great rhino sightings
text:
After a mix-up in our 3-night reservation for a 2-bedroomed cottage (caused by our Botswana travel agent not by the Park officials) we were accommodated in a chalet normally used by teachers at a facility for wildlife education. This accommodation was very basic but we were most grateful as the park was overflowing with visitors.

Absolutely wonderful sightings of various animals and birds, including 26 white and 1 black rhino on our last afternoon! We were surprised at the size of the park, and it was reassuring to note the presence of many armed army personnel within and on the borders of the reserve protecting its assets.

Definitely a place to be revisited!

title: Wonderful park but accommodation is badly managed
text:
The wildlife in the park was great.

Our family stayed for one night in a chalet. The chalet was old and badly maintained and we had small insects falling onto our bed from the grass roof during the night.

The staff allowed a group of campers to have a loud party and play music in the camp site until late in the evening. We were unable to  listen to any of the night sounds in the bush.

Based on our experience we definitely won’t visit the park again, which is a real pity because it is the only sanctuary for rhinos in Botswana.

title: Great stay.
text: Camped one night - July 2021. Friendly reception, clean campsite with awesome trees. Birdlife was amazing with nice sightings of variety of animals. Ablutions clean with hot showers. (Shower heads are low and tall people need to bend their knees to get under the shower - a minor hick-up though). Will definitely stay again.

title: Great game experience, average accommodation.
text:
We stayed at the Rhino Sanctuary for two nights en route to Kubu Island.  There is a lot of game in this reserve - well worth driving around, especially to the various pans.  We really enjoyed this aspect of the reserve.  

The accommodation in the chalets is extremely basic, it consists of beds, a small bathroom and a table.  The upper part of the walls on the A frame is made of netting, so one is unable to "close" this area up.  This resulted in all of us being absolutely freezing during the night.

We ate at the restaurant and found the food to be satisfactory, although somewhat excessively priced.  The service was also very slow due to what seemed like minimal staff.  We assumed this was as a result of Covid.

title: A-Frame Review
text:
We stayed at the A-Frame chalet, on our arrival the state of the chalet was shockingly dirty, as we had booked in advance, we were surprised to find the chalet was filthy, downstairs bedding was covered in a layer of dirt, a canvas strip that was put to close a gap above the door had come out and was hanging which i'm guessing added to the dirt on the bed.  Upstairs loft sheets were covered in bird s%$t and again very dirty, credit to the lady at the reception who was very apologetic and since it was already late in the afternoon she arranged alternate accommodation for the night with the promise that the next day it would be cleaned.  You do hear the cars passing on the main road so if this is not your thing i would suggest booking the other chalets or campsites.

Chalet C & D were clean and comfortable but could do with some TLC, nice shaded braai areas surrounding the chalets.  The following morning the staff did come through and did a thorough clean and changed all linen.  Again A-Frame chalet could do with maintenance, the canvas entrance to the loft needs to be replaced, torn in places and zipper doesn't close.  Mosquito repellent is strongly suggested for the loft.

Apart from the chalet issue we had a fantastic time, plenty of animals to see and very relaxing. We would definitely take the camping route next time round as there were some really nice looking campsites with big shady trees.  Carried our own food so can't comment on the restaurant apart from that it opened at 8am and closed at 5pm which is probably due to the current curfew.  

Staff were friendly and welcoming.

title: Day Visit Self Drive
text: It’s an awesome place to see lot of game activity around the waterholes. We did a self drive and it’s easy to get around the park. Had awesome game views with over 15 rhino sightings.

title: Very Nice and spacious campground
text: Spacious and quiet sites with a good restaurant. Beautiful birds around and af course very close to the Drives in the park.

title: There you can see rhinos very close!
text: It’s an amazing place with 57 white and 7 black rhinos at the moment (as we were told by the local guide). The sanctuary is covering more than 8.5 thousands  hectares, so we were very lucky to see a few rhinos of both species. It’s defiantly worth one good morning game drive!

title: Wild camping experience with a bit of convenience
text:
Definitely need a 4x4 to enjoy this place and make the most of it. We really enjoyed seeing the rhino, and the bird hide over the waterhole was amazing. Lots of wildlife and birds here so worth being able to spend a good few hours - we spent an afternoon and then an early morning here but could easily have spent another night. 
Campsites were allocated and very big and well spaced from each other with some shade. Came with own tap and brai. 
Ablutions were ok, reasonably clean, warm showers and the lights come on early evening until the morning. Open ablutions so quite a few bugs about.
Unfenced but nothing scary coming into camp so we enjoyed seeing bushbaby in tree next to the brai and dikdik coming to drink at the tap.
Staff aren’t very friendly.

title: Nice camp/park poor service
text: I have hardly ever felt less welcome than I was when entering Khama. The lady in the reception is incredibly rude. The staff in the restaurant were not particularly happy to see us either, so we ended up leaving for our camp. The camp sites are good and private, and so is the reserve itself.

title: Disappointing flagship institution
text:
We enjoyed the rhino tracking on foot. It was an exciting experience and a privilege to see white rhino on foot at close quarters.

But the reception lady was rude, unhelpful and uninterested and the guide not well informed. The ablutions were not clean and full of mosquitos.  The hot water geyser was turned off, which is ok, but a sign to warn users to turn it on would help. The shower heads were blocked with deposit. A sign to ask users to turn off lights is needed to prevent insects from invading the ablution rooms overnight. 

The campsites are spacious and well-spaces with abundant welcome shade and water points.

title: Rhinos Galore
text: Khama Rhino Sanctuary does not disappoint on the animal front, especially around the pans that you can visit driving around their reserve. We stayed for two nights and saw multitudes of springbok, steenbok,= and impala as well as some ostriches, zebra, gemsbok/oryx, a lone giraffe, and -of course- rhinos. The bird spotting here is also worthwhile. We had a great time especially as the sanctuary was very quiet over the weekdays that we camped. The campsites are clean and spacious. The restaurant has a pool and free wifi but limited meal options. The staff weren't particularly enthusiastic either but if you're just wanting to visit to spot some cool animals then you have come to the right place.

title: Worth a visjt
text: Relatively low density of game but still worth it. Camp sites were nice with clean bathroom. Wasn’t busy at all, we saw almost no other cars while driving around which made it worth not seeing a huge amount. Should probably note we were there on a weekday during a drought

title: Wonderful project
text:
We had a great tour with one of the wardens from the sanctuary. He drove us round and told us about the animals and birds that we were seeing, he was very knowledgeable. We saw 8 white rhino, sadly the black rhino were hiding that day.  We also saw giraffe, zebra, warthogs and antelope and lots of birds.
The only problem is the Sanctuary is difficult to get to if you are not driving.  Eventually a member fo staff from our hotel drove us out and collected us after the game drive (for a fee).

title: Serowe Khama rhino sanctuary a must
text: Having seen one lonely white rhino in Moremi where they are struggling to reintroduce them, it was especially wonderful to see so many here as part of a successful programme of conservation of white and black rhino. The two hour evening guided tour was thrilling.

title: Visit with colleagues to the Sanctuary
text:
This was a most interesting and enjoyable experience. We saw a wide range of animals , including rhino, in their natural environment. The staff were courteous and pleasant and the ranger who drove us round was excellent. 
Very strongly recommended

title: Disappointing
text:
As a couple we were put in the A frame at the start of our holiday.  We were a family of four the last time we were put in the A frame 18 moths ago.  Couldn’t believe we were booked in there as a couple - the A frame has 2 double beds downstairs and a loft upstairs.  The toilet facilities are outside where white ants have done justice to the thin poles creating a barrier of privacy.  
The concerns from 18 months ago remain unattended to still.
White ants are eating away at the mirror frame - this place is derelict.
If you are running a fridge there is no electricity. 
You have to go out side for toilet needs
The water is a mere trickle from the shower - same concern 18 moths ago.
We were convinced our original accommodation had been swapped out with someone else with the same concerns - no need for a couple to be put here either. The office were not able to help us saying it was pre booked by our agent.
On our return and complaints to our booking agent we were in accommodation better suited to our needs - and yes electricity to run the fridge.

title: A Gem
text:
What a great stop over at KRS. We stayed over in the chalets which were well equipped and comfortable. Lynx took us on a two hour game drive the next morning which was great and finished on a happy note seeing a Rhino family. Birdlife was fantastic right outside front door.
Restaurant was pleasant could possibly do with a little more enthusiasm, however on the whole a fabulous stop over
Well done for good work in a great reserve

title: Rhinos in safe surroundings
text:
Khama Rhino Sanctuary
This sanctuary is next to the A14 between Serowe and Lethlakane. The road are sandy and 4x4 is recommended. Chalets with electricity and camping without electricity is provided.
They have a very good Restaurant on the premises.
Driving on the reserve is allowed.

title: Fantastic place - not to be missed
text: I decided to visit here, mainly to see the birds.  It is a small park,  4,300 hectares, but has an abundance of animals and birds.  You can join a tour, hire a guide or drive yourself.  I opted to drive myself, as I wanted to spend lots of time just watching birds and this seemed the best way to do it.  You must have a 4x4 vehicle and be prepared to scratch the doors!  The roads were great, sandy and sometimes quite deeply rutted but very well signposted and easy to follow.  There is a map available for purchase which is definitely worth getting.  The map is clear and well laid out and there is lots of information on the reverse including checklists for birds, animals and trees.  The best part for me, was the Bird Hide.  A fantastic way to see birds and animals visiting the water hole, without disturbing them.  Everyone I talked to was extremely friendly and knowledgeable.  There is a campground and chalets available, as well as a restaurant but I did‘t use those facilities.  A real gem of a place that I would love to spend another day at.

title: Botswana Safari 2019
text: Khama Rhino Sanctuary was our last stop of our amazing 2 week Botswana Safari. We stayed at Camp C. It was huge and there was lots of space for our 3 caravans. The ablution was about 50m away - this needs some attention as most of the lights need replacement. The pan is about 8km away and we saw 7 rhinos. We drove to 3 different view points and expected to see a few more rhinos since this is a sanctuary. We did however see many small bucks. We decided to go for dinner at the club house restaurant. The food was good however prepare yourself for long wait.

title: Great to see the rhinos safe
text:
Great Sanctuary for breeding of the rhinos in a large open game park.

Didn’t see a large volume of animals on our game drive but we did get to see about 20 rhinos in total a great joy to see.

Also a few giraffe and other game but nothing else, we camped in sanctuary and the camping facilities were very good.

A real highlight on our 10 day trip in Botswana.

title: Khama Rhino Sanctuary, Where Rhinos are (Almost) Guaranteed
text: This was my second time visiting the Khama Rhino Sanctuary and I enjoyed it even more than the last time. We saw 6 rhinos and had lots of time to observe as they were feeding and drinking and there was a young one. As well as Rhinos, there are many birds and animals including giraffes, zebras, warthogs, etc. You never know what will be around the next bend. We were not able to stay in the main lodge but they put us in the overflow cabins that were very comfortable and secluded. The morning was magical with all sorts of birds and impalas. This is a nice stopping point between Gaborone and Kasane.

title: Very disappointed
text:
After spending three idyllic weeks of camping in Botswana, we were looking forward to our stay at Khama Rhino Sanctuary. Needless to say, we have a  4x4 fully rigged for comfortable camping, so this chalet had to be a step up from that, especially at the price!
What we got, was a chalet with no electricity, no hot water, no fridge and one dim oil lamp for two bedrooms of which the one was on the top floor. 
The shower consisted of a wooden screen with gaping missing poles. If we wanted hot water, we would have to light a fire under a donkey "large metal drum" with the fear of setting the environment on fire. Brave the shower with a freezing wind blowing through the gaps, just to find a treacle of water from the shower head. 
The kitchen was filthy (photograph attached) with minimum utencils. So much dust under the beds, we could have planted maize. The one good thing is that the beds were comfortable with clean bedding. 
The staff offered us the dormitories where at least we could have hot showers, but needless to say, we had to pack up and move again! 
The game viewing was extraordinary! We drove ourselves and saw all but the Black Rhino's. 
We had booked and paid for a guided game drive, but with this unpleasant vibe, we wanted to cancel. This we were not allowed to do for a refund. We went, saw less animals but Duncan, the guide was informative and friendly. All in all, the Rhinos made the day.
Bottomline....... Not worth it! 
We could have camped in more comfort and still see all the animals! 
Totally overpriced at R5000 for two nights.

title: Not my first safari...
text: This was part of my intrepid tour, having been on safari in Tanzania and only seen rhinos at a distance this was potentially the most exciting part of my itinerary. I can’t really judge the experience based on seeing the rhinos as in the couple of hours we had we only had two brief sightings. The vegetation is extremely thick meaning you rely on the rhinos being in visible areas at the right time! Would fully recommend doing a couple of drives here if you do really want to increase your chance of encounters! The purpose of the sanctuary is amazing though and the work they do there is fantastic.

title: 3 HOURS GAME DRIVE ON THE 27TH MAY 2019
text: Very friendly guides who try by all means to share information regarding the behaviour of animals, their reproduction cycle and how animals relate to one another. You will see different kinds of animals and also learn which ones are rare to see like the leopard..it is really a nice place where you can go as partners, family or for business excursion. Even though it was my second visit, I have never seen a leopard! they also have nice meals!

title: Well worth staying over a few days
text: We decided to stay over for a few days, normally people would use Khama as a stopover. It was well worth is, we saw many animals, the roads between water holes are quite sandy, but as you would probably be there in a 4X4 it should not be a issue. The restaurant, although limited in offerings in off peak times, makes good pizza, and there is free wifi. Its a good idea to buy enough wood while at Khama, the quality is very high...slightly expensive at 25p per bag, but quality makes up for it!

title: Nice conservation effort
text: Listening to the story of how this sanctuary started and what has been achieved and what is involved is interesting. But what is even nicer is seeing Rhino, including mother and calf is awesome.

title: Rhinos up close
text:
This was our only opportunity to see Rhinos in Botswana. We did, but that only tells part of the story. Spending a bit of time watching family groups is a real reward. The highlight however wasn't the Rhinos but a family of giraffes. Two young ones sat in the road being watched by their mother who was fending off the advance of her very handsome partner. Getting to witness all the interactions was a real treat.
We booked an evening game drive (£50 for 2) , although we could have driven ourselves and probably would have if it was a little later in the holiday and we'd had more experience driving on sand tracks.
The accommodation is fairly basic but clean. The mosquito net didn't fit which meant we got a couple of bites - but hey ho. The food was good and very affordable.

title: Lots of rhinos (obviously), and giraffe.  Sunset = best photo opps
text: This was my first stop in Botswana as part of a group overland tour.  Saw rhinos almost immediately after setting out on the game drive, as well as a few giraffe and zebra.  In my 2 months in Africa, I got the best sunset photos in Khama, due to its dramatic plains landscape (at sunset), which makes everything look super yellow and "African-y".  A beautiful park indeed.

title: Bostoe Bus en Self Ry 4X4 Toere Pieter Marais
text: We only did a Game Drive this time. From previous visits experience the accommodation at Khama Rhino Sanctuary not to my standard for my guests. We now have opted for Serowe Hotel a much better choice. Friendly and helpful staff looking after the interest of their guests. Good quality accommodation and safe parking with security guards on duty 24/7/365. The way to go!

title: Rhinos... Overland tours tick off 1 of Big 5
text:
Camped here. and sites are ok, ablution facilities are inadequate for large groups, with only 3 showers, and 3 toilets. 

Yes, you do see rhinos but arrived late and got rushed in game viewing vehicles to see them. Great to see rhinos. Sponsored by a bank so funding for security.

title: The place to spot (white) rhinos
text:
Great place to see the white rhino. We saw about 15 in different locations during our drive through the park. There are also a few black rhinos but they are more shy and not that easy to spot. Since the place is well guarded and protected against poachers, the rhinos are also used to people and one can get quite close to them (in the vehicle).
The chalets are very basic, with mosquito nets that do not fit the beds and have holes in them. This made the sleeping experience rather challenging, taking into consideration that there are MANY crawling and flying insects around when the evening falls...

title: Awesome animal and bird sightings, incredible nature
text:
This is a beautiful, and accessible animal sanctuary with sightings of rhino, giraffe, zebra, eland, black backed jackal, flamingo (unusual for the sanctuary, but amazing for us), kori bustard, bateleur. The internal roads are well sign-posted and its easy to spend up to 5 hours cruising around appreciating the animals and the environment. 

If you're on your way to the Okavango Delta, stay overnight at Serowe Hotel, only 30kms drive from the sanctuary. Enjoy either a morning or evening game drive at the sanctuary, you can use your own vehicle, or book a game drive at the sanctuary reception. 

If you live in the area, this is something you should be doing every weekend!

title: Self camping and Rhino tracking December 2018
text:
We had a wonderful 2 night experience at Khama Rhino sanctuary with 8 of us self camping under big shady tree. It was the start to our 3 week holiday. Loved the privacy of campsites far away from one another. We saw plenty Rhino and some other animals on our self drive. The Rhino tracking was something very special. Got up close with an experienced guide. Definitely recommend this place as a good stop over.
Ablutions clean. No electricity. Pool, bar and wifi were welcomed by us all.

title: Camping: November 2018
text: We camped for two nights under big shady trees. Good size campsites. Very sandy. Basic but clean ablution facilities. Friendly and helpful staff. Lovely bird hide. Saw lots of birds and Rhino's. Animals such as Wildebeest roaming through campsites.

title: Fantastic Animal Encounter
text: I was on a tour with Intrepid and we set camp right in the sanctuary. The camp ground was really nice and had good facilities. After we were all set up we were picked up by a few game drive vehicles and set off to spot some Rhinos. We saw many animals along the way and after seeing a few lots of rhinos from the distance we stumbled upon a group of rhinos, with a baby!!! It was so cute and came up really close to the vehicle. Amazing opportunity to see these incredible creatures up close.

title: A good place to see white rhinos
text:
Best time to visit on a game drive is early or late in the day.  However we did find the safari vehicle used to be very noisy which may have frightened some of the animals away. Also it was not open which made it impossible for communication between the driver and participants and vice versa.

There is a nice little souvenir shop at the entrance.  The Sanctuary is definitely worth a visit to support the efforts to conserve this endangered species.

title: Rhinos up close
text: While a self-drive (4x4) game drive is possible, I HIGHLY recommend one of the Ranger led drives - their knowledge, which they readily share, is invaluable.

title: Knock off the most elusive of the 'big five'
text:
This is quite a small place to do a Safari which is good because there are 50+ rhinos here so you're more likely to stumble along one. We were there for 10 mins and bumped into about 15 at the first watering hole!

We also ran into a few giraffe and zebra. All that we've seen before at the big parka but never this close. 

It doesn't have any of the other 'big five' but that's not what you come here for. It cost 900p to do an afternoon game drive (including entry for two).

The staff are all very nice, and it's great that all the profits go to community projects and the sanctuary but it would be great if they had an information centre to learn about all of the great work they do and stuff about the rhinos. Especially for those who choose to do a self drive safari.

title: A Great Safari!
text:
We spent four great days in Chalets C and D here - in the depths of the game reserve! You can camp - but we prefer the chalets. We cooked on the braai every day - self-catering and we did not leave the sanctuary until our stay was over. It was brilliant! 
The accommodation is adequate - this is not meant to be a hotel! You are in the middle of the bush. You open your door in the morning and you never know what you will see! One day, a large antelope was staring back at me - then it just moved slightly and it disappeared - camouflaged behind the trees!

You need a 4WD - and the rule is that you stay in it, come what may. The animals then know that, when they see a car with people, they are safe, so you can get quite close to them - or rather, they can get very close to you!

The rhino are justly famous - but we saw zebra, warthog, giraffe, kudu, impala, oryx, steenbok, waterbuck, wildebeest, ostrich, hartebeest, eland, springbok, black-back jackal, mongoose, kori bustard, francolin, guinea fowl, grey lourie, emerald spotted dove and loads of other birds, including vultures and storks. We went in winter (end of August) and the bush was quite devoid of leaves so visibility was very good.

The Khama Rhino Sanctuary (KRS) is a community based wildlife project and it deserves to succeed! 

We took nothing but photos and left nothing but footprints! Fantastic!

photos.caption: Pride of place goes to the rhino!
Waterbuck at the water hole by the bird hide
Yellow-billed hornbill - always near the braai!

title: Stay over
text: We enjoyed our stayover at Khama. Campsites are neat, ablution facilities were clean. Sandy roads to sites might require 4 wheel drive at times. Fireplace at campsite was in working condition.

title: Marvellous camping Safari in Botswana.
text: The 9-day 8-night Okavango Expeditions camping Safari, Kasane to Maun, with 2 nights in 4 different  campsites, starting in Chobe, was a marvellous experience.  Tour guides/drivers Paul & Ossi had superb fauna/flora, knowledge, binocular-grade eyesight &, seemingly a 6th sense on where to find elusive animals.  The food was amazing, especially considering the prep. conditions and the team setting up and taking down the en-suite (bush style!)  tents, with beds, were streamlined and speedy - an all-round excellent experience.  Sitting under the star-studded sky, with lions grunting not far off, plus other animal communications during the night, just added to the experience.

title: Seeing African wildlife in style!
text: We followed a pack of wild dogs on a kill and saw many other animals. We stayed at Duke's Camp which was amazing!

title: What Botswana is known for and it doesn't disappoint!
text: We explored the Okavango delta with Sanctuary Stanley's camp during the dry season (late May) and I have to say that the Okavango delta is one of the most beautiful areas I've ever seen in Africa.  The amount of animals and the variety of animals that we saw...well, we've never seen that many before.  And when the rains come and the entire area floods, the same animals are still there, but their habits/behaviors change accordingly.  So we're longing to go back during the rainy season to see the entire area again...but completely new to us again.  Definitely go here!!

title: Three nights at Kwara Camp
text: Three superb days and nights at Kwara Camp in the Okavango Delta. Excellent amenities, wonderful staff, astonishing wildlife. Highly recommended. One of the best places in Africa.

title: Wow
text:
Stayed here for 2 nights as part of an Intrepid trip. Have to say this surpassed my expectations. We were taken to the campsite in Mokoros by local villagers. Once there the campsite was set up for us.
We done bush walking where we were taught about the local wildlife. Right outside the camp site we had elephants and hippos. On the first night I was awoken by elephants passing through the camp!
We bathed in a natural pool right by our camp.
This was definitely the highlight of my 2-week trip.

title: We explored Okavango Delta with Sekanka Safari
text: We spend a good week on a safari starting from Maun, ending in Kasane / Victoria Falls and loved the Xakanax area in Okavango Delta most. We opted for a tailor-made tented safari through a company called "Sekanka Safari", which we can recommend to anybody looking for a small safari company to take their family on the safari of a life time. When looking at safaris we wanted to do it all: Okavango Delta, Chobe, Moreni, Savuti, Victoria Falls, under the assumption that the areas would be very different from each other. In reality they are not that different allthough we found the Xakanaxa area to be the most stunning of all. We were very lucky with the game sights we had there and perhaps that helps with our preference for that area. After those, the game ride in Chobe felt very average. I know that sounds very snobbish but after such an amazing start of our safari tour I guess we were spoiled ;-).

title: Spectacular
text:
Amazing experience to spend 2 nights in the delta. No facilities in this untouched area.
The campsite was enough for a group, able to swim in the river (with no chemical used), had bush walks, studied tracks etc.

title: Amazing wildlife
text:
The Delta has been on my wife’s bucket list for many years, so it was great that we finally managed to visit and, due to covid, with relatively few tourists. Apart from our game drives, we decided to take a scenic flight (with Major Blue Air out of Maun) which is great if you don’t mind a small plane and a few bumps here and there. 

We saw all of wildlife we’d hoped for as well as getting a much better appreciation of the delta.

title: Captivating
text: What a treasure the Okavango is! Serenely beautiful and peaceful,  and truly something to protect and enjoy.  Lots of animals and birds to see, gorgeous landscapes, and unforgettable experiences. Protect it!

title: Awesome safari
text: Game drives and boat rides with experienced guides made the entire experience an unforgettable trip.

title: WATERY WORLD WITH ANIMALS
text: An amazing place. Lots of animals to see. There were several people in our ad hoc group. We had a tour guide with us who was knowledgeable and spoke three languages,  including English.

title: Hope to come again…
text:
So diverse… from speed boat to mokoro to game drive to horse riding. And a few more….
And it changes, too. So different in Summer or May-July…

title: Nowhere better to go on Safari than Botswana's Okavango
text: The best safari experiences in Africa can be had in the Okavango Delta. Doesn't matter if you are at a lodge, mobile luxury camping or basic camping, canoeing or horseriding, you'll have the best time of  your life.

title: Anyone seen an elephant?  Here they are!
text: More animals in one day than you can imagine!  Botswana is the best!  We were with Arifcan Bush Camps.  Superb!

title: Serene, enchanting place.
text: It was amazing to be in such a special place that changes so much based on the annual rainfall and water seasons. Quiet, peaceful, solitary. The stars were amazing!!! It was so fun to camp out in the bush, listening to our neighboring hippos! The makoro rides are fun and the walking safaris were humbling and insightful, though the animals kept their distance. We barely entered the edge of the Delta and would love to go deeper into the Delta next time. Our experience was heightened by the possibility that the Okavango might not get water forever because of increased water consumption in Angola. This amazing place will be greatly changed, so go there now before its gone. Botswana is an amazing country with friendly and welcoming people!

title: One of the natural wonders.
text: This natural wonderland must be on every nature and wildlife travellers bucket list. The rainwaters flow from Angola through Namibia into this pan shaped delta into a myriad of lakes and bull-rush waterways.

title: Letaka Safaris - mobile tented safaris
text:
We had an absolutely amazing six-night journey from beginning to end. Mmegi met us at the airport and took us to our pre-Safari destination, then collected us again and made sure we were airport ready… we arrived in Moremi for a 3-night stay, and was met by our guide Lucas, it was nonstop excitement from the word go, we saw a small pride of male lions before we even arrived at camp. and then drove to Khwai for 3 nights. Each location had a different feel and experience. Our Guide, Lucas was extremely knowledgeable and did not pass an opportunity to turn every occasion into an adventure, from spotting and chasing a leopard, not just once but twice! To leading us to a herd of 500+ strong buffalo, not once but twice, different locations. We saw elephants, lions, loads of hippos, giraffes, zebra, warthogs, wildebeest, African wild cat, wild dogs, Lechwe and a rare buck called the Roan antelope. Not to mention all the birds, flora and crocodiles. The best part was 2 mating African rock pythons. The river Mokoro excursion in Khwai was just awesome. I also enjoyed the walking safari.

The camping facilities are fantastic, way more than I expected. Elliot delivered a warm shower to our en suite every afternoon and warm water to wash with every morning. Elliot and KT had our tents and camp cleaned and we had a surprise towel origami on our beds every day. This all in the African mobile bush safari!

Now the best part !!!! the food - was astounding what they created on a camp fire. KK cooked up three course dinners every night plus lunches and warm breakfasts. A freshly baked cake every day, felt like I was in a 5-star hotel! Lucas had wonderful stories to share at dinner time, and around the campfire.

Coming back from a drive, we would be welcomed with a welcome song, smiles, a cold drink and warm washcloths for our faces and hands. And a blazing campfire.

Mmegi made sure we were covid tested before we said our goodbyes…

Thank you Letaka Safaris and team for sharing your playground with us for a short while…

title: A massive water expanse - a must to see
text: We spent 3 nights on the delta camping and doing a mokoro ride. This is a must experience.  The size of the delta is not easy to comprehend. It is worth doing a helicopter flight over the delta as well as boating.

title: Great sightings of lions, leopards, wild dogs, elephants
text: Our guide Monti from Xakanaxa Camp was able to find 4 of the big 5 on our game drives in the Moremi Reserve,  Camp is very comfortable and the food excellent.

title: Beautiful area - so many animals
text: I loved my visit to the Delta.  I got to see so many different types of animals.  I have never seen such a variey of wildlife and the setting along the river was truly beautiful.  I loved the opportunity to spend time on water and land and would recommend it on any travel to Botswana.

title: Tourism capital of Botswana
text: The boat rides through the Delta, the elephants crossing and magnificent sun downs made my 4870kms from Uganda by road worthwhile. see you soon

title: Wildlife at its best
text: I never seen so many animals in their natural habitat. This is place is a must! It is nothing compare to a zoo. You will be suprise to see so much and up close. The landscape is amazing, you are relaxing and drinking while enjoy all the views of different beautiful aninmals around you.

title: THE DELTA IS UNIQUE AND UNBEATABLE
text: We stayed at a camp in the north western part of the delta. The facilities were first class as was our guide. The wildlife was as brilliant as ever

title: Worth a trip
text: The delta is fantastic. We  were there in February and were told that it is better in May, when most of the water from Angola has arrived. We made a scenic flight, a boat trip and a walk and all were great even in February.

title: It’s an amazing place, but make sure that you are with the right guide
text:
We had a 3 days/2 nights camping in Okavango Delta. The area itself is just breath-taking. Beautiful landscapes, many birds and animals, I couldn’t put my camera down. We didn’t see any cats close, but we could hear them. That is probably a case when we were glad not to meet them, because we were walking and not driving! We also had to keep a good distance from hippos and buffalos. It’s a place that makes you feel that you are so little without machines and equipment. And there were no mosquitos at all!

It was our first camping experience, so many things were very new for us. However, with the help of our local guide Philip we quickly adapted to the conditions. Philip was fantastic, he was explaining us everything, making the biggest accent on our safety, but also doing everything possible for our comfort and entertainment. His knowledge about local wild life is phenomenal. We have learnt the official and local names of different species, many interesting facts about their lives and habits. Philip was shaping our walks and boat trips according to our wishes and interests and nothing was too much trouble for him.  

Unfortunately, our guide and tour organiser Pastor Maswanganyi from Swangs safaris, who was providing the 10 day tour from Johannesburg to Victoria Falls, was totally different. Before the trip he was telling us how well he knows the area, but in the Delta we weren’t provided with any information from him at all. Quite the opposite, he treated the trip like a personal holiday and was communicating only with local guides in the local language, spending time with a female guide, disappearing with her for a long time.    That was the only beginning of our sad experience with Pastor Maswanganyi, later he has just escaped with our money, but that is a different story in a different review… 

Now we understand how lucky we were with Philip! If not for him, we would feel totally abandoned and helpless, and wouldn’t be able to enjoy the Okavango Delta. So we have learnt a lesson – check the guide you are going to trust your money and life, and, when you think you have checked, do it again!

title: Low season
text:
A beautiful place but our arrival coincided with the low water season, as such I feel we didn’t get the full delta experience.

However the guided nature walk across one of the lowlands was very ethereal. Being on foot so close to such amazing animals was an experience to treasure.

title: Spectacular experience!
text: Did an overnight excursion to Okavango Delta. This was a wonderful experience and highly recommend for other solo, couple or family travellers. Camping out in the wild, chatting to the locals, going on bush walks are all a major not to be missed highlight!

title: very good experience
text: we saw many elephants,hippos,hyenas,chettah,impalas,the experience of botswana and the crew of bushbaby calls was very good

title: safari at Okavango and lodge
text: Okavango Delta is beautiful with many wild animals.   Alosopeople are so friendly and lodge is very good with excellent service and amenities.

title: The pinnacle of safari experiences!
text:
I am lucky enough to have been on several great safaris, all over Africa & India & the Okavango Delta is the best place I have visited.Amazing landscape even in the Dry Season, incredible Animal & Bird sightings & all with the emphasis of Eco tourism.
Totally stunning.

title: Wow even in this drought
text: We did a flight in a tiny Cessna, to view the Delta. Although it’s quite dry, it was an unforgettable experience. Can only imagine how more impressive it is in the wet season

title: Still the best game viewing in Southern Africa
text:
We have visited many reserves and national parks in Southern Africa and the Okavango Delta is still the top destination for us. 
There are no telephone and electricity poles, there are no tarred roads, no fences in sight and no need to do anything else but take in the magnificent scenery. 
The Delta caters to all pockets, from incredible luxury to self drive campers. 
There is no 'best time' to visit, however every season offers something different yet worthwhile experiencing. If you have never been before, then the winter months from May to July is where you should start as the 'flood waters' are in and the Delta becomes this amazing water wonderland. A flight over the Delta is worth every cent if you are not flying into a lodge. 
When planning a trip make sure you use an agent who has been there themselves so that they know what will suit you and your pocket best as there are hundreds of options to choose from. Lodges, overland safaris, and self drive each offer many levels of luxury and experiences, so choose an agent who knows the Delta.
The birdlife is exquisite and we usually find ourselves concentrating on the birds and the animal sightings end up finding us while we are birding. Your guide will quickly find out what is on your 'must see' wishlist and will endeavour to make it a reality. There are no guarantees though, as the Delta is not a zoo or animal park. Try not to be too rigid with your list or you can end up stressed and miss out on many other things. We always find that just watching the sun rise and set is enough.

title: Land of sea & sea of water
text: Really is a fantastic place to see. The Okavango Delta which starts off as a Kavango in Angola is a UNESCO world heritage site in Maun Botswana. The Delta is a vast inland river in Northern Botswana. It’s one of the most spectacular places to visit in search of wildlife. It’s home to hippos, elephants and crocodiles. On dry land the wildlife includes lions, leopards, giraffes and rhinos.

title: Super combination
text: Done a 9 night safari also in the Okavango Delta. Perfect for game viewing and without WIFI experience.

title: Unspoiled Paradise
text: We have been going to the Okavango Delta for over 20 years now and find it among the most beautiful and pristine places in Africa. The Botswana govt has done a good job of limiting access so that it does not seem overcrowded. I know several people who have visited there after going to Kenya and told me they wished they would have gone to the Okavango first and never have gone to Kenya. Kenya was too much like Hollywood!!

title: Brilliant
text: Out of this experience going by mokoro along the waterways. Although suffering badly from the drought some channels still navigable. Fantastic birds, hippos and crocs.

title: World Heritage Site
text: A river delta which doesn't empty into the sea but rather peters out into the desert. There are many camps to choose from which will give you an up close view of the animals. A truly unique experience.

title: okovango
text: We travelled in a mokoro to get a birds eye view of the vast expanse of swampland and my only disappointment was that the only game visible around the edges of the riverways were elephants or hippos !! Setting that aside it was still a good  experience to get a feel of how vast the delta is

title: Amazing Experience
text: We flew over the Okavango in a helicopter. It has got to be one of the most beautiful experiences that I have had. It was very dry because of the drought and the poor animals had gathered there so the air safari viewing was exceptional as the animals had conglomerated around the water.

title: Serenity in the Delta
text: The Okavango experience was such an opportunity, from viewing the picturesque landscapes to the animals it inhabits, the skilled polars and their mokoros provides an unique adventure of travelling amongst the wilderness. Balancing friendly interactions and steering a safe journey through hippos and crocodiles and later in the evening, the pleasure of listening to them sing and dance around the campfire 👌🏼 Superb!

title: Camping
text: I been with friends in Zimbabwe, Botswana and Namibia. We camped four nights in Okavango delta. Awesome

title: A Must!
text: We camped in the Delta as part of a tour across Botswana. It is a must!! The scenery, tranquility, wildlife, etc is wonderful. Nothing beats being right in the middle of what is going on. Bathing in the Delta on a hot afternoon was also a highlight.

title: Abundant wildlife
text: There are quite a lot of private lodges in the Okavango Delta.  It was not a cheap holiday but we certainly have fantastic memories that we will treasure for many years to come.  The game viewing is just fantastic.  For most of the private lodges you can fly in on a small chartered plane to the nearest air strip and you can expect fully inclusive service with fantastic hospitality and game viewing.  We stayed in Mma Dinare and Splash camps.  I recommend staying at more than one lodge in different parts of the delta as they had very different vegetation and game viewing experiences.  Mma Dinare and Splash are both excellent.

title: Everyone should go once in his life
text: Okavango delta is a unique experience that make you strictly in touch with the nature and it’s rules. We spent two night in tend. We had walking safaris and mokoro trip. You will love it!

title: "Very dry"
text: Due the lack of rainfall during last rainy season a great part of the delta is dryer then usual so the wildlife was much more concentrated during our roundtrip. Due the draught the roads have deep sand in many places so a 4x4 is really needed and recuced tire pressure obligated.

title: Abundance of game and spectaculer sights
text:
A variety of game  encountered, from plains game was impala, tsessebe, giraffe and
wildebeest to elephant and buffalo herds. Red lechwe, reedbuck, hippos and waterbuck where seen closer to the water. Predators include lion, cheetah, spotted hyaena and African wild dog and crocodiles.

title: Spectacular
text: We chose the Delta for the water and mokoro safari opportunities and Mopiri Safari Lodge provided all of this and much more (see individual review).  There is nothing more authentic than being pushed along in a (Mokoro) canoe checking for hippose and crocs.

title: Beautiful area and good game viewing
text: The area are beautiful, but it is very dry at and the water are less than usual.  We could drive to areas, which is usually only reachable by boat.  We saw a lot of game, but the cats was hard to find.  The roads was dry, but still challenging and bad.  Always beautiful next to the rivers and lots of animals, especially elephants.

title: Return visit
text:
We went to The Okavango nine years ago and swore to go back. This year we made it and it is still a superb place to go for wildlife, but changing and not for the better.

It is dry, arid, scorched. Many of the animals (the herbivores especially) are very thin because of the poor grazing. Also, the elephant damage is tremendous. On our last visit we remember dense bush, now there are many areas which are wide open and with smashed down trees.

Also, the number of vehicles has increased dramatically with many days trips from Maun. Often these seem to be old and poorly maintained vehicles. Frankly, limits need to be placed on access sooner rather than later.

We had amazing sightings in The Okavango, but worry that the damage caused by mankind is becoming overwhelming.

title: Dry season animal utopia
text: We visited Okavango at the end of the dry season -- it was VERY dry! -- so wildlife was concentrated around available water.  Lions, leopards, elephants, six species of antelope, baboons, giraffs, zebras, etc. etc.

title: Day trip
text: Truly one of the most beautiful places in Botswana. Seeing the baobab trees growing in the middle of nowhere was just exceptional. We highly recommend this place for a day drip and chill.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: An otherwordly oasis
text: Cool spot. Had a nice late lunch with my guide and spotter from the Kwando camp within the NP. It is quite far away though-so basically an all day drive.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Nxai Pan with African Bush Camps
text:
I recently spent 4 days in Nxai Pan with African Bush Camps, and didn’t want to leave. The camps are mobile: they change every week or so, and the pan, (my first salt pan experience!) was lovely. Lots of open views, prides of lions, springbok, raptors, bee eaters, bat-eared foxes and jackals. Very few other people.  ABC took great care of me: You gotta love the combination of canvas walls and compost toilets with a wine steward and remarkably tasty meals. 
My guide, Ken, was expert at spotting all manner of wildlife, wonderful company, and intuitively knew how best to position the vehicle for optimal photo opps.  I am very grateful for his good work!  I was a little early for the zebra migration:  they were arriving just as I had to move on, but this is a special place, well worth revisiting.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Nice campsite in a unique park
text:
Not for everyone but Nxai Pans is a unique experience.  Lots of sand and the animals are here but you have to be clever and a little lucky to find them.  We did see lions twice.  
The campground is good, the sites are a little close, however, the the toilets, showers and outside washing facilities are well maintained and clean. 

We drove the next day to Baines Baobab campsite and it was very remote and not really anything there. It was gorgeous though but we decided to not stay the night.  

The roads require a 4x4 to navigate so be prepared.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Great site, and very peaceful.
text:
Baines Baobab is an extraordinary place with large Baobab trees sitting on the edge of an extensive salt pan. Camp sites are situated around the pan but are miles apart. Each site is clean, and has a long drop toilet and bucket shower, but take your own water. 

We camped here for one night after staying on Ntwetwe pan and it was a great experience. We were only slightly phased by finding lion spore on the ground in front of the truck after we had set up camp. We expected to have a disturbed night but actually had a good night’s sleep in perfect peace. 

The drive into Baines is currently (September 2019) rather challenging, the long road in has deep sand and once heading towards the pan we had an extended wait while some trucks ahead of us helped release another which was axle deep. It was necessary to drive for extended periods in low ratio so go with a full tank.

We had wanted to go to the waterhole to the north of the park, and in fact drove part of the way there. However we had to turn back as the sand was far too deep and soft to venture any further. We were in serious danger of being bogged down. As we were a lone vehicle, with little other traffic, we decided that the risk of an extended stop in 38 degrees was too much.

The camp area was great, remote from other sites, well swept and with a long drop toilet and shower. Of course, there is no water, but we carried our own.

We enjoyed our stay at Baines, would we go back. Indeed yes, but probably at a different time of year.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Great experience
text: This is a very quiet area with limited animal activity but the camping experience is wonderful. It is absolutely silent on the pan at night and the stars at night, the dawns and the sunsets are beautiful. It takes a while to get to the Baines Baobabs on the very sandy road from the gate so recommend a two night stay to really soak up the atmosphere. Our teens thought this was one of the top highlights of our trip through Botswana.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Visit to the trees and driving around on the pans
text: Just visited the lower part of Nxai to visit the trees. Very worthwhile drive across sandy roads and plains. Recommended stop between maun and gweta.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Baines BaoBab – surreal landscape
text: Kwando Camp drove me here – we started late morning and got here mid-day. The road was sandy but you don’t get dusty because there is very little traffic. Carry a jacket and cap if you do the trip in July. I didn’t see any animals on the drive to or from the trees but saw a lot of  birds – Kori Bustard, Red Crested Korhaan, Northern Black Korhaan, Double Banded Courser, Bateleur, etc. Got there mid-day which was not the best time for photographs. I was anyway overwhelmed by the trees and could not find creative angles. If you are a shutter-bug, I suggest looking at some photographs beforehand so that you can capture the magical nature of the landscape like a pro. Look into the distance across the salt pan to see a mirage of water. Across this grove on the other side on the pan is a picnic spot under a solitary Baobab and rest rooms are available.

photos.caption: Baines Baobabs with overhead sun - early afternoon in July.
On the road to Baines Baobab

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Amazing island in desert
text: Excellent place for romantic stay on lonely island in salt pane. Bucket shower (if you bring your own water), BBQ and sleeping under baobab with milky way above it is unforgettable experience.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Camped at Baines - beautiful and private
text:
The 136km road between Maun and Nxai Pan has sections which are badly potholed so the drive took 1.5 hours. It was a 1 hour drive to Baine's Campsites once inside the park on a very sandy road. There are only 3 Baine's campsites and they are not right by the iconic Baobabs. Campsite 1 is on the island opposite the Baobabs, camp 2 further down that island and camp 3 further still, each with their own Baobab and quite a distance from each other. Long drop toilet and a bucket shower system but no water. There is a braai although ours had not been cleaned. The campsite and isolation is stunning with memorable sunsets over the pans. 
The game is more North towards Nxai Pan (South Camp) because of the permanent water source.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Starkly beautiful
text:
The cluster of enormous baobabs are reached by a long, sandy, 4WD road (about 45 minutes from the park entrance). The rangers will advise you which roads to use, depending on the conditions. The trees stand in stark relief to the flat white pans around them and are a welcome oasis for body and soul.
We camped overnight in campsite number 2 (a couple of kilometres from the trees) in a pretty spot with its own baobab trees, a bbq area, shower and pit toilet. Note there is no water at the campsite - you must be self-sufficient and bring everything in.
If you want to listen to silence, see the sky blanketed in stars, and feel disconnected from the hustle and bustle for a day or two then this is the place to visit.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Amazing and surreal
text: This place is truly amazing - walking across the salt pane I felt like on a different planet. I wish I was there in the wet season, but then roads will probably be close to impassable. Campsite is good, but there is no water available (bring your own). There is good bucket shower and toilet is clean.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Camping under the trees
text:
Well, you don't really camp "under" the trees, but the baobabs are so massive that you'll definitely be sleeping under their leaves. 

I highly recommend driving to Baines even if you're not camping--and even though it's a good distance from the main track in Nxai Pan NP--because the environment out there is so interesting and unique. Also, you have a better chance to see gemsbok (oryx), as they live in those desert-y kind of climates like the pans. (We saw one in the evening and then the next morning loping across the pans, which was really cool, and then we saw a small herd of them on the drive back towards the main dirt track). 

If you can, I recommend camping out there as well. It's a beautiful, weird, interesting place, and you'll be well alone if you camp at Site 3, as the other sites are clear across the pans (or, rather, you have to drive across the pan to get to Site 3). We camped in the middle of a raging electrical storm, and though I didn't get much sleep, I'm still happy to have stayed a night out there. 

There's a fire pit but that's it for facilities--which is no problem at all. The more natural the environment, the better! 

You need to book through Xomae Group, which I recommend doing online ahead of time, but we did luck out and switch to a night earlier while we were at the office inside the park.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Ancient Baobabs
text: Set on the edge of a salt pan these ancient baobabs stand majestic  Nice story attached to why they are there.  A must see visit when visiting the National Park.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Fantastic night stay in the desert and great activities
text:
We would highly recommend the night stay in the desert (for us it was an amazing experience). We loved the meerkats watching. The quad tour was also lots of fun.
Very knowledgeable guide. Don't expect to see a lot of game during the car ride though.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: amazing grove of trees
text: This is worth the long detour to see the grove of trees and the salt pans surrounding them.  very different from the other areas in the park.  some birds, not many mammals, as there is no water near here.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: really worth the visit
text: huge monster trees. long drive from hotel but much to see enroute making this a great outing all round.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: " Well Worth It "
text: Camped 1 night here.  Basic camping...drop toilet and you bring everything else.  Spectacular scenery and a full moon added to the ambiance.  Very good sunset onto the Baobabs . Well worth the drive into here on the very sandy tracks.  Saw a few animals and birds on the way into and out again.  Just a great place..Book ahead as there is only 4 campsites.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: About Nxai Pan National Park in general
text:
The park is quite small so you can roam most of it in one full day ( but it is worth staying longer ). 
Landscapes consist of bush near southgate, plains near Nxai Pan and Kgama Kgama Pan and wetlands around Kudiakam Pan ( which turns into a lake during the rainy season ).
Animal wise the plains feel like a miniature Serengueti with herds of herbivores ( we noticed big groups of 20+ girafes and groups of ostriches ).  The area is famous for the big elephant males who enjoy this mostly dry area.
The only carnivores we saw were jackals but we heard lions and saw some tracks.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Boababs and salt pans
text: The area is just beautiful, with all these baobab trees on the edge of the salt pans.  The camping sites are completely isolated and under beautiful big baobab trees.  There is no facilities at all, just nature to accompany you.  The roads are quit bad and there is not a lot of animals this time of the year.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Cool place for a picnic lunch
text: Baines Baobabs are approximately 20 km's from the Reserve gate on the Gweta/Maun road.  The trees are just on the edge of a really large salt pan.  We visited just for the day, and enjoyed a picnic lunch.  One can camp at the baobabs - you just have to be totally self-sufficient.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: For complete peace and isolation
text: A fairly long drive along unmade roads from the Nxai Pan National Park Lodge the Baines Baobabs location is reminiscent of the featureless pans of Namibia. For naturalists and historians this is an amazing trip into a remote and hence totally peaceful and tranquil area. I could have stayed there for hours just watching Oryx pad across the hardened plain. Truly a place of immense satisfaction.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: unusual to see so many Baobabs so close together.
text: An interesting visit to this area right next to the salt pans. Shame that some idiots have to scratch their names into the bark of the trees.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Seclusion in a beautiful environment
text:
We stayed here for one night and really enjoyed the stunning scenery and eerie landscape of the pans. The pitch we had was large and totally removed from any other so we had complete privacy. Being in the pan itself, we felt safe from wildlife. This is not a place to go to for several days but it's well worth a stop in. If you have the perseverance to deal with dire booking processes that seem to be the norm across Botswana.

The Nxai pan didn't give us much in the way of animals but passing conversations with another visitor suggested the day before had been much better. So we were unlucky.  That said, we had our most rewarding lion spot of the whole trip so we can't complain!

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Beautiful wilderness
text:
Very peaceful, away from it all place.  We had a puncture on our way so arrrived in the dark, but managed to find the campsite.  Incredible waking up to the pan and baobabs the next morning.  The only other people we saw were a few day trippers visiting.  We were pleased to see there is a toilet long drop properly set up and a bucket shower, both on concret bases.  
Amazing stars!

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Wonderful sight, worth the detour
text:
Bit of a detour off the main road, but worth spending a night camping here in one of the three nearby sites if you can.

Some of the biggest trees you'll ever see, something you won't find many places.

Camping right in the pan under a huge baobab was a great way to spend a night

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Unique experience: driving over a crusty salt pan to a private camp site under baobabs.
text:
After a rough 4x4 drive over the savannah you'll get to the first set of baobabs from where you can drive over to one of the three private camp sites (a few KMs apart). You'll be driving over the crusty salt pan where erosion of various sorts has created flakes and bits of various shapes and shades of green-gray colors. Unique.
We drove over and around the pan (on the tracks, of course!) at sunset and the pictures turned out beautiful.
 
The campsites underneath the baobabs are very spacious and has a very basic private ablution block. In our case, there was no tap or otherwise running water and as we had only had a few bottles of drinking water with us, no refreshing bucket shower for us..

As it is quite a hostile, dry, and remote place to camp, you have to make sure you are mentally prepared and have the necessary supplies with you, and then you may very well likely end up loving the unique charm of the pans and its baobabs.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: beautiful trees
text: Amazing to see these very old baobabs. Unfortunately, they are scarred by graffiti but still great to see them.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Pretty amazing
text: Well worth the long drive - plenty of game on the way and the baobabs are amazing. The pans in front of me baobabs had plenty of water, attracting birds, orix and zebras, plus elephants.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Worth the drive
text: Definitely worth going to see as you will see lots of different countryside and animals along the way. These trees are truly amazing and must be hundreds of years old.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Wonderful place
text: We camped for one night at Baines Baobabs, it was our second visit there, the first was 10 years ago, the campsite is basic but has a bucket shower system and a long drop toilet system but the location is spectacular. The road to get to Baines Baobabs was quite corrugated and has thick sand in a few places but generally not too difficult, the pans around Baines Baobabs cannot be driven after lots of rain so make sure before you go. The Baobabs themselves are spectacular and can be visited in a few hours or you can camp close by. we loved camping there as it is isolated with almost no people nearby, great for photography and star trails, In July it gets quite cold at Night so be prepared, I will definitely return one day.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Didn't visit Baines Baobab - only the Nxai park!
text:
We only did a short day drive to the salt pans an baobabs, but the scenery is very different from many of the more northern parks and reserves… 
We did drive to the waterhole as well, but in the middle of the day, so sadly we didn’t see any cats, only some elephants … 

But diffinately a place that deserves a couple of days!

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Stunning
text: We wondered where on earth we were going...but when we got there it was absolutely stunning. Camp 1 was great, good shower and a good long-drop. Sunsets and sunrises were beautiful. Most outstanding were the stars at night...bright, clear and the whole sky was full of them!

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Best kept sectet
text:
Camp site Nr 2 at Baines baobabs, 2 nights. 
Second visit. This place is not an easy drive, quite thick sand, need a good 4x4. We towed a trailer and got stuck, but the detour much easier than the old track. 

3 campsites, about a km apart each. Nr 1 best view on boababs with spectacular sunsets. A primitive bucket shower and toilet is provided, but no water or electricity. You need to be fully self sufficient. 
But the reward is absolute solitude, sunsets and stars to die for. 

Will I be back, I want to keep this for myself and come back every year!

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Unexptected treasure
text: In the middle of a salt pan. Not sure if you can reach it in rainy season. Be prepared: A lot of flies!

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Magnificent Campsite
