text: This is the most beautiful setting on earth. The sunrise and sunsets are magnificent. You are out in the open with no one near you. You need to take your own water with you. There is a long drop and a bucket for a shower quite nicely done and kept very clean.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Campsite
text:
Astonishing location for a campsite, across the pan and under baobab trees. Basic ablution facilities but a stunning and memorable location.

The drive into the reserve itself is a challenge, soft sand and uphill so make sure you know how to use your 4WD and the campsite is at least an hour from the waterholes so leave sufficient time.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Historic Site
text: Painted in May 1862 by Thomas Baines.  One tree was down then but alive and the trees are exactly the same now.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Nice to see, would not go again
text: Drove appox 70Km on dirt roads to see. They are lovely but not exceptional. Thomas Baines immortalised these trees in his painting so there is a sense of mystery when visiting  this area.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Dr Seuss
text: Eerie, ludicrous and gorgeous tree concentration on the banks of an enormous salt pan. During the wet season, it floods but in the dry season you can pick up large pieces of dried salt.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Beautiful  great  baobab  trees
text: comprise a clump of large baobab tree,rendered immortal in 1862 by painter Thomas Baines.Its  really  a  great experience for  one  not  to miss...great awesome pictures  too...

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Magical
text: Having read about these incredible trees we just had to go and see, nothing could have prepared us for the vast area these trees command.   The trip from Nxai Pan camp was an experience as the 'road' is very changeable from bumpy track to sand then across the salt pan. Amazing experience, not to be missed.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Quite a sight!
text:
Fabulous to see these ancient trees overlooking the pan that haven't changed one bit since they were painted 150 years ago.  

But why have they stuck an enormous bright orange sign in front of them?

Great area to picnic on the opposite side of the pan with a fantastic view back to the Baobabs.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Baines boababs
text:
The feature is of course the trees. They are magnificent.
One must however be aware that the road to the trees is heavily sanded and only for experienced off-roaders with a 4X4

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: The camp site to experience wilderness!
text:
This is a review for the campsite in Baines Baobab.

We were lucky to have the campsite no1, which is exactly opposite the famous seven sisters. (There are a few more campsites, all far away and apart from each other). If you are looking for a magic place to stay for a night in the absolute wilderness and with no human presence, this is the one! Private, remote, peaceful. Magnificent sunset. Owls and jackals howling around us. This was our favourite campsite in Botswana! 

This is a campsite that you need to have water, food, fire wood etc with you. There is only a long drop and a bucket shower. You need to book well ahead in advance, as there are very few places (we booked 12 months in advance and got the no1!)
A truly magnificent experience.

userLocation.name: Ashby de la Zouch, United Kingdom

photos.caption: The seven sisters, the view from our tent!

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Baines Baobabs
text: The Guide offered an all day excursion to the Baines Baobob's. This was well worth while and we saw a lot of game and sights (note:  we chose this has an all day excursions which combined morning and evening game drives.  Some guests may find this too long a day.  It worked fine for all of us).

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Amazing scenary
text: Combined visit from Maun on a daytrip. Hardly 2hrs drive and even on a long weekend very peaceful and quiet.  The scenery is amazing.  These baobabs are really worth the visit as is the Nxai national park.  Having visited many national parks in Southern Africa, and reading the books on this, I was surprised to see so much game, plenty of antilope, giraffe and zebra, and even lions.  Really worth the visit. And for an affordable price if you stay in Maun.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Don't miss this
text: It is such a beautiful and peaceful location, not to be missed. In any other country there would have been souvenir sellers and cafes but not here!The journey from Nxai Pan lodge was interesting and educational with our guide Robi and tracker "Shoes" stopping to point out birds and snakes including a python. We had an unforgettable picnic at the Trees - thank you Robi and Shoes!

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: Marathon trip to historic site
text:
The initial idea of spending a day to travel out to view a set of trees was not at all inspiring, however I soon realised it was not just about a tree or two.  Firstly, they are a group of 7 baobab trees which is unusual in itself. The trees are very old and are more recently (1860's) associated with European travel within seriously remote Botswana. Secondly, the salt pans are a typical example of where much of the water travelling into Botswana ends up. Worth a visit if you are there during the drier months. Thirdly, we saw lots of animals (especially giraffes) along the way as it was April and there was still plenty of vegetation around.

We were the only visitors during the morning, which was convenient as there are no amenities, only 7 trees and a lot of salt pan!  We arrived, took photos of baobabs, baobab fruit with insects, us with baobabs, ate lunch prepared by our guides and departed.  An interesting place, however it is a long trip from anywhere.  Make sure that whole journey and not just the destination is worth the travel.

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: great view
text: fantastic view to the Baobabs. unfortunately we cold not get close due to high water level, but trees were still greenisch just chenging color. you will never see seven Baobabs close together!

placeInfo.name: Baines Baobabs
placeInfo.locationString: Nxai Pan National Park, Central District

title: What a horrible place ..the worse campsite in Botswana if you can call it a "campsite"
text: I'm just absolutely gobsmacked that this place has such high reviews. People go to Botswana  to see wildlife and they usually have to drive pretty far to the campsites, This  drive took it to all new levels unforeseen for the whole world. Not only getting there really sucked, the signs   lie about how many kilometers it takes to get there (72 km sign says actually 100 km!)  and on the tire got awful drive  there was no wildlife , but just cattle and lots of it!.  I should have read the description before you attempted to get there. Seriously whose world travelers itinerary is to see a bunch of rocks and fossilized bird poop?!  No thanks so I turned around and went to another campsite more to my taste. On top of that, a friend of ours went there  and said there's no ablutions and the wind was so bad that they had to  physically hold the tent all night long  so it wouldn't blow away and there were  two strangers that drove around the camp at 2:00 a.m. in a pickup truck. This is the worst campsite of all of Botswana.  I don't get these people thinking it's good. It is God awful. If you want to see a bunch of cattle and drive to eternity for something that serves absolutely no point other than a lot of wind no water, ablutions ( not even those buckets you fill) and no toilet then to each his own

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Magical place
text: We visited 25 years ago and were amazed again about the beauty of this utterly remote place. It is surely worth a visit once in a lifetime. Very sad that elephants have damaged some of the ancient Baobab trees. The reception area was deserted, but staff came to collect our camping fee, as we had not booked. The pit toilets were amazingly clean and water in big containers are provided for flushing. There is no water or electricity available, so you have to be totally selfsufficient. Your vehicle is your lifeline here and should be in a good condition as a breakdown may result in waiting days for other vehicles to pass. Roads are only tracks but in reasonable condition this time of the year, as many vehicles have compacted the tracks. Do NOT attemt to visit in the rainy season or shortly after when pans are tsill wet, you WILL certainly get stuck !!

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Best sight in Botswana
text: We have travelled all over Botswana and this was our favourite sight until now. We had the chance of being alone there. We drove there ourselves, 4WD, lousy gps but an app brought us there without a problem

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Magical Place Far from Civilization
text:
Fantastic place in the true sense of the world. Serene and peaceful and a great escape from the real world. 

It is hard to explain how a group of rocks and Baobabs surrounded by nothing can be so magical, but it is. 

The excellent community project based at Mmatshumo will get you there if you lack a 4x4 at very reasonable rates. The facilities are basic but match the place itself. Just be aware that you need to be self-sustaining in terms of food and water, although firewood is available.

photos.caption: Sunset - a great place to introduce youngster to the great outdoors in a very safe environment,

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Sleepy granite giant
text: Kubu Island is absolutely worth a stop if you're at all interested in nature (particularly weird rocky outcrops with huge baobabs, there's even an archaeological site tucked away here). We planned out roadtrip around Botswana to incorporate a stop at Kubu Island and it did not disappoint. Travelling through the pans can be challenging at times but after the hours of yellow grass on the salt pans Kubu Island definitely stands out (although getting their is a bit of a challenge since it is poorly signed). Very glad that we opted to stay at the Gaing O Community campsite because it meant that we ended up having the island almost entire to ourselves and we could watch the sunrise in the morning.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Awesome Kubu
text: Staying at Kubu Island is always a great rewarding experience. Even though one must be self sufficient in as far as food water and showering. The campsites are far apart and set amongst the magnificent Boaab Trees. But the best time of day is at sunset and then the milky-way is painted above you at night.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Extraordinary
text: Kubu Island which is accessible from inter alia Gweta, is some 70 km south of Gweta along roads which leave much to the imagination as to how to get there. It is however amazing to find the boabab trees in the niddle of the salt pan, if however also not in the salt pan itself.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Fantastic sense of space and freedom
text: Situated miles from anywhere this is a place to experience Botswana open spaces. Take your own water, remove your own waste, and no power or WiFi means you experience the expanse and desolation  of the salt pans. We played cricket on the edge of the pan, the kids found clay in the pan and spent hours making clay animals which we fired in the camp fire.  The sunrise and sunsets were amazing. We were there at full moon so didn’t really experience the stars. We entered from the south and exited on the road between Nata and Gweta. The sand track from Kubu to the main road is sandy and bouncy and great fun. A 4x4 is recommended but my non 4x4 Fortuner and non 4x4 trailer did just fine.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Don’t drive from Gweta to Kubu Island
text: We stayed at Planet Baobab the night before heading to Kubu Island. Great lodge with good bar/restaurant and giant baobabs all around and lit up at night. 3 different people said That there is no road, only tracks that often lead in different directions with no signs from Greta to Kubu Island and they strongly encouraged us not to go for fear of getting lost. Our GPS died earlier that day so we ended up getting a guy to escort us there. Well after 3 1/2 hours of driving on crazy tracks through sand, dirt, with big shrubs scratching the camper, going over the salt pans we made it. There is no way we would have found it on our own. The guide said goodbye and we got a great site overlooking the pan. It was magical and we got great night sky shots and pics of the baobabs. We stayed there 2 nights and found a couple that had come in from the south which had an actual road which was so easy to follow(saw meerkats Along the way). Had a long trip back to Gweta but nice tar road and saw a lot of animals. So glad we went!

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Interesting but I wonder why campsites aren't along the perimeter of the island
text:
There are 13 campsites and you pick one on arrival so get there early. Only 1 had a view across the pan which we found disappointing having just stayed at Baine's Baobab campsites. We stayed in GPS 3. Long drop toilet. No power. No water. Fire pit. 
We had difficulty finding the camp coming from the North. Do NOT FOLLOW ORANGE BLOCKS - they lead you East across the pan to the soda ash factory if you can get that far without getting stuck. We drove South along the pan which was nice until we hit a fence line and had to drive West along it getting the car very scratched as many overgrown acacias.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Deep in the Bush
text:
Khubu Island
This wilderness camp is 47 km from Mmatshumo where the tar road ends. 4x4 vehicles are recommended.
The camp has no facilities and you have to bring all you will need with you. The sunrise and sunsets are the feature of this remote wilderness camping site.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: A must do best views
text: Only accessible with 4x4 went with out a booking no problem. came from the northern side can not do with a 4x2!! Went to book in payed in pulas think 400 if i remember correctly. He showed us were we can camp and we pitched our tent and went for a drive on the pans stick to the road. great photos was taken here. No wild animals so kids can play freely there. went out on the south side road much better, and one place you get to a view point on the road you will see lots of round pebbles this was were the water was breaking many years like a beach. on the view point you will see how big the lake was.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Stay over
text:
Decided to make Kubu a stay over point on the way to the north, we thought we would be the only people, only to find a few more had the same idea...bummer. In any case at least scenery was great, the ride was spectacular, and the long drop toilet unique. You need to be very self sufficient when going here...there is absolutely nothing in line of amenities (Except for that long drop).
Very important to have a GPS with at least "Tracks for Africa" loaded...there are no real roads here

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: A stark and beautiful landscape
text: Kubu Island is blessed with phenomenal natural beauty, endless skies and a precious sense of isolation which is unique and food for the soul. Possibly the best jogging spot on the planet. The camping facilities are best not mentioned, especially the cramped and smelly long drop toilets, Come for the view and the natural beauty.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: All Alone
text: When you need time to be all alone with yourself Kubu Island is the place to go. Nobody will interfere with you and you can enjoy beautiful sunset and sunrise pictures with the Baobab trees.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Camping at Khubu Island
text: Great scenery, pans are vast and boabab trees are huge. Camping site only have a long drop toilet, no other facilities. Some wildlife to see. We had a jackal at our tents at night. Beautiful place to watch the sunset and do stargazing.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: B-E-A-utiful!
text: After leaving the A3 between Zoroga and Nata, we drove down the 91km of dirt track in various conditions to finally reach Lekubu Island for the sunset: it was staggering. The same can be said about the sunrise.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Isolated and Free
text: Stayed at the campsite for one night. It's a bit rough camping, but the location is awesome with great photo opportunities. Would like to return and explore more

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Mysterious place
text: Huge campsites. There were only 2 other jeeps when we came here. Very special place to be and drive around. Just be carefull with the salt, don't leave the tracks. Easy to find with the free app maps.me . Toilets are a bit smelly, really a back to basic campsite. Environment wonderful!

photos.caption: don't leave the tracks, use maps.me for orientation

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: A must!!!
text:
What a beautiful place!! 
We have been there in first week of Sept 2017. Road from the south was dry (tried to access it from the North but there was water on the pans). Good to drive with a GPS with reference points as the road is not always clear to follow.  
No facilities on the island, but the beauty of the island and pan make up for it.
Island is peaceful, quiet, absolute silence, remote!
Slept under the stars with full moon. Picture that I will never forget!
This is a must if you are in Botswana!!!

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Striking and unspoiled
text: Kubu Island is a rocky outcrop in the midst of a vast expanse of salt pans.  We camped there for one night on our way through to Maun.  Be warned that there aren't any ablution facilities though.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Must see!
text: Lekhubu Island, also known as Kubu Island, is a must see historical site in the Makgadikgadi Pans, administered by the Botswana National Museum. The 65km route from Letlakane needs a 4x4 and takes more than two hours through the Makgadikgadi Pans.  We lost the route a few times, even back-tracked twice, because of a lack of indicators and a myriad of re-routes where people had been stuck in the mud before. We visited in August when the Pans were dry.  It will possibly be quite a treacherous drive during the rainy season. Kubu is an unexpected spectacle of rocks and baobab trees surrounded by kilometers of flat salt pans that blend with the horizon in all directions. One can see how it will literally be an island during the wet season. We saw many different bird species and signs of animal life - fresh antelope tracks and old elephant dung. This place deserves all the stars that covers it like a dome at night - for its setting and for its uniqueness! But sadly, for the price one pays compared to other camping sites, it lacks the very basics. There's no facilities, no water, only a few long drop toilets and a dilapidated house where people check on your booking and sell wood. And none of this information was supplied when we made the booking through the Gaing-O-Community Trust.  kubu.island@btcmail.co.bw

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Incredible experience!
text: We drove through from South to North and stayed the night on Kubu Island. An incredible experience! You cannot describe the beauty of a sunset on Kubu and the contrast and vastness of the salt pans! You must however be prepared to endure to see the beauty. The drive is long and slow and you need to bring everything yourself, including water. The camps have a chemical toilet now, which was very clean for the circumstances, but you need to be used to that sort of thing.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Kuba
text: Special place tranquil peaceful and very very quiet beautiful sunset and sunrise amazing to camp there

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: A dream come true
text: I have wanted to visit this island for years now and I am glad I did. The camp site is basic and toilet not good but we knew this. The views are amazing, I could just sit and look. At different times you can park a chair in different places around or on island and just look at views. A must see in my book

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Lovely evening
text: We stayed at Kubu Island for 1 evening toward the end of our time in Botswana. The trip there is not far on a GPS or a map but it takes VERY long to get there so best to plan for an early start too your day. We arrived a bit late but the camp site was lovely. There is nothing... at all... just you, your gear and nature. There are a lot of foxes and we saw some antelope but no sign of larger animals. The baobab trees are amazing and the sunset and sunrise... breath-taking. The stars in the evening were beautiful. We put out the fire and all light and sat in the middle of nowhere looking at the stars. Incredible. It is quite expensive for a place that literally offers you a piece of land, but I would say it is worth it.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Should be on your bucket list
text: Difficult to describe- you need to visit this when you are near. Long drive to reach the island itself and during driving you wonder if it would show up and be different from seen before since you are passing small salt pans, drive through sand, grassland etc. But then... the island appears and is so different! Large rocks with baobab trees in the middle of a large salt pan.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Great hiking and Camping, Really worth the time and trip, especially 4x4
text:
Awesome drive to get there.  Get to drive over an ancient water pan.  Camping spaces are all good, there is no way one is a bad spot.  Spent the whole afternoon hiking and walking.  There is a stone wall at the top that dates back to the 1200s, Also has fossilized bird guana.  That night was crazy as we had 50-60 mph winds, but our tent and 4x4 made it through.  A must to bring water, as there is none around there.  There are built in toilet holes that were surprisingly clean, be sure to have your own toilet paper.

Just a note, when you go thhhhrough Mmsathumo and come to a gravel toad, look a little to the right and you will see a small sign for Lekkuba.  It is CORRECT.  You really can't get lost, but it is sand and gravel for 17km.  WHen you get to the vet gate, if no one os there, open it and be sure to close it as well.Driving the rest of the way is so cool.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Kubu Island 4x4 stop
text:
Kubu island is perfect as a stopover as part of a 4x4 trip. There are a number of camping sites to choose from, each with its own long-drop toilet. Don't expect any luxuries here though. You will need to take everything you need along with you. The staff provided us with fire wood, but it is best to check with them before hand in case they don't have any. We went for a guided tour of the island, which was quite informative. 

If you plan to drive anywhere from the island across the pan I would advise you to talk to the staff first. Often the pan is wetter than it looks and you WILL get stuck, even in the best 4x4 (Toyota, obviously). We helped a bunch of people out of the mud on our short 2 day stay there. It is a nightmare to get a vehicle out of the pan once it is stuck. I would not suggest crossing the pan in a single vehicle ever. Always remember, even if the pan looks dry, it may be wet just below the surface. If you are foolish enough to drive over the pan, take a known route, don't try and make a new road. Take all the equipment you need to get unstuck, you will find nothing to aid in the pan, not even rocks.

Note that this is  a popular stop, and there may be quite a few people when you get there. Book in advance.

Enjoy!

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Excellent scenery: salt pans and baobabs but...
text:
We missioned there in 4x4 trucks (only recommended) and came from the North (Nata). It's a good track (when dry) but pay attention to where you driving because it's easy to veer off onto other tracks and get seriously lost. 

Entering the salt pans is awesome. Stay on the track as it's muddy every where else. 

Check in with the house on where to camp. Now BEWARE the "park ranger" there, Moola, tried to charge us double what is stated in the parks paper work. We new the price wasn't right and told him no ways. We paid and asked for a receipt. He laughed and put the cash in his pocket. 

He came around to check on us, in what seemed a sincere way, but for sure was trying to pull a long one on us.

Anyway, we camped for two nights. There are ZERO facilities beyond a couple random outhouses. 

The photography is awesome as the scenery is just unreal.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Wet but worth it!
text: Didn't stay overnight, but worth the wet sliding track to get to Kubu Island. We stayed for an hour, exploring the island and walking on the wet pans. Amazing place, will have to return when it's dry!

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: A overlanding MUST do stop over.
text:
Natural Beauty at its best. If your are passing through Botswana traveling from North to South or South to North, you must make time for at least a sunset and sunrise at Kubu Island. 

The campsites are Beautiful, hugging the west side of the Hill on Kubu island. The whole place is something else though. There is no water and the toilets....well, lets just say that the shovel and hike experience might be more enjoyable than using the pit loo's here.

We drove in from the South in October 2016. The rd was very dry and we had no problem. Driving out we took the North East route North to meet the A3 Between Zoroga and Nata. This was a beautiful very sandy drive. I would not recommend this route to anyone who is in a hurry or who does not have a vehicle with high clearance.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Lovely
text: We adored this place! It is pretty remote and we got stuck in a mad on the way but it was worth it. It is so beautiful out there. We have seen the most beautiful sunset and night sky ever. Watch out for spiders.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Wonderful place
text: I camped for one night at Kubu Island, the road in and out was mostly good with a few tough sections with deep ruts, we chose to go in the dry season so that we would not battle with getting stuck, I think if you go to Kubu Island in the rainy season you should be prepared for tough road conditions and possibly drive with other vehicles to assist if you get stuck.The facilities at Kubu are basic and no water was available and there is no shop to buy anything, you need to be self sustainable.The Island is beautiful and has amazing Baobab trees and huge big Granite boulders, it was nice and peaceful and great for Landscape photography and star photography, watching the sunrise was spectacular, I think a great stop for one night in a magical place.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Camping at kubu island
text:
Kubu Island is an impessing spot in botswana. First the way to get to the island through the pans, which can be a challenge, if there is a little humidity. If the rainy season has started, it's probably impossible to go there. If you are in the dry season, there are more rumours than actual difficulties. But it's still a trip. You have to stick to your gps, because there are several tracks which you better do not follow. You never know, where they bring you to. 
At kubu island you will find total stillness, beside some birds which nest in the baobabs. The evenly landscape gives so much peace to the eyes in the daytime and at night there stary sky is unbelivable. If you have moon, you will be surprised how bright everything is. You don't need a torch or anything to go for a little walk on the rocks. 
The camp site is very basic. So bring everything you need.
We stayed there two nights to really enjoy the stillness, peace and remoteness of the place. I would do it like this again.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Definitely worth the drive
text: Kudu island is unique! We camped here for two nights, (camping is the only option and you have to use four wheel drive) an experience like no other. There is nothing but the 'long drop' loos spaced between clearings in which you can camp. The Zimbabwe ruins are worth a walk as is climbing up to the highest point on the 1km long  Island, and going to the edge of the pan is like standing on the edge of the works with nothing in front of you.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Botswana Island style
text:
This is our fourth time back to Kubu island in the last three years, there is just something about this place the draws you back, the granite boulder, baobab trees and slat pans. This was also the first time we go stuck but it all adds to the adventure.
You have to bring everything with you but we always just stay for one night. You could spend two nights and explore the island.

photos.caption: On the way we stop to buy fire wood, not cheap.
We got stuck on route, traveling from Nata heading South

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Good for stopover from N to S or S to N
text: We went there from Nata,  4 hours of very sandy and bumpy road,  the worst St we had to drive in whole Botswana... In kubu you donnot have anything..  Rocks,  baobabs,  pan and sun...  Not adapted for children.  We reserved and paied 2 nights but came back in gweta after 1 night.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: DIRTIESTT TOILETS IN THE WORLD--OVERFLOWING WITH POO!
text: So, when there are not clean toilets, what do people do?  They use the bush.  As a result this place is littered with soiled toilet paper, and unfortunately, if you have to go you have to go.  What a pity that such nice place does not understand the concept of hygiene.  The road from Maun is one of the worst sandy roads you can imagine---apparently because they have a huge "RUNNING FOR RHINOS" event once a year where people fly small aeroplanes on the pans etc. etc.  What a pity that because of the price of money these people will allow this place to be destroyed.  They dont hesitate to take large groups of bikers who go wild on the pans, as all of this is money.  Surely we would have thought that the Botswana Government, when giving out such Community Projects will educate the people who run the place about hygiene and saving our lovely planet.    If you are looking for the toilet, just walk around, and you will smell it from about 5 metres way...dont even dare to open the door!  Why could the people in charge not just build new toilets when they see the toilets are full...maybe they dont want to face it either!  And in September/October, dont expect a single leaf...so make sure you take your own shade.  Sunset and the night sky is lovely.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Challenging access but worth the visit
text: We drove in from Nata but it took us five hours each way on a deep sand road - not for 4x2 vehicles...you will get stuck.   The site was larger than I expected and we would have benefited from a better guide to learn more of the history and mystique of this magical place.  There are a number of sandy campsites - not on the salt pan -  but no provisions, water or other supplies; you must take everything in with you. The 'long drops' were disgusting and the evidence of toilet paper in the surrounding shrub led to its own conclusions.   We were disappointed in the sunrise, it was partly obscured with dust or smoke during our visit but the extent of the salt pan was remarkable.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: ONE OF THE UNSPOILT PLACES IN THE WORLD, WORTH VISITING AT LEAST ONECE IN YOUR LIFE TIME
text: This place is in the middle of Millions of years old Salt Pans spreading 1000 Sq. KM.  Very rugged place can only be approached using 4X4 vehicles only from May to September as during rainy season they get full of water and non approachable  For miles and miles you only see white salt and no vegetation and can not go without a guide

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Beautiful, spiritual place
text: We visited Kubu Island on a 2-day excursion during our stay at San Camp. The rocky outcrop is dotted with baobab trees and is a beautiful, spiritual place with a deep and interesting history. I definitely recommend a visit.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Star trail at Kubu Island
text: We visited Kubu the 12 of July 2016. if you visit Kubu Island make sure that your vehicle is up to it. The road is a challenge. We travel   5 hours on 70 kilometers. The dust is everywhere. When you arrived at the Island immediately the beauty replace the bad road. The lady at reception is friendly and very positive about her work for the last 6 years. The campsite is big and can accommodate at least 3 groups of 4x4 trailers. You must bring everything with. There is wood along the road for sale, buy enough. There is only a long drop (very suspect). If you go to Kubu the main activity is photography. Make sure you scout the area well before sunset. This was one of the most   beautiful places I have ever visited.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Never again
text:
Coming from the North, Dead and dying trees interspersed amongst brown grass while driving for 3 1/2 hours on a rough dirt, rock, and sand road with many places to get stuck will bring you to Kubu Island. Along the way you will see donkey, horses, and cows but not a single bit of wildlife. 

There are NO facilities here: no water, no electricity, no abolution blocks, no communication. All this for just 468 Pula. 

Get out of here driving south on the seasonal access road across the pan ASAP. This hole is hell on earth!

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: A very humbling experience
text:
There are more baobabs than I was expecting, and if you spend enough time walking around the rocky outcrop you may be lucky enough to spot a bonsai baobab that managed to pop up among the rocks - I'd love to know how old this little miniature version is?!
The sun set and full moon rising was spectacular, and the silence is incredible.
I'd love to return with a new moon to be able to experience the stars better - light of the full moon does dampen the stars a little.
There are many camp sites, and although one is able to pitch camp relatively far apart, it can become disturbing when others are active or social at night - perhaps do enquiries to try and avoid groups (we spent most of the early hours of the morning listening to a large group pitch camp... noise travels very far here, especially when others are oblivious to the disturbance they are creating).
Be warned, the pit toilets are horrid, especially in the heat of the day.... so watch your step as many obviously choose to make a litter box out of the surrounding veld or sandy patches...
Take everything you may need (water, sleeping and cooking equipment, etc.) as there is absolutely nothing there, and take everything back with you! I hope that those whose visit will help preserve this magnificent escape from reality.
We will definitely spend 2 nights next time so as to explore the rocky outcrop more!
The staff that tended to us were very friendly.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Tree Fallen!
text: The Baobab tree has fallen in 2016 but this does nt detract from a memorable experience. The drive is also interesting as it tracks David Livingstone's journey.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Bucket list no 1
text:
Ever since my first visit to Kubu Island, I wanted to return to this magical place.  We were on our way from Maun to Nata when we decided to take a detour to the Makgadigadi pans.  We phoned and got a campsite.  

The road to Kubu is challenging in the dry season and I would not venture there in the rainy season.  This is part of the mistery of the place.  In the middle of the pan you find this granite island filled with age old baobab trees.  This is a dry camp so you need to bring your own water.  The long drop toilets are not the best and we used the nearest tree with a shovel.  Wood is for sale, but we were ripped off.  For Pula 18 we got 5 pieces of wood where two years ago we got a wheelbarrow full.  I think were also overcharged as SADC citizens, but as we arrived late, could not do much about it.

Apart from logistics, this remains a magical mystical place like nothing else on earth.  The stars are so bright and everything is so quite.  The sunset and sunrise with the hundreds of baobabs is something to behold.  This is a magic place and something to put  your Bucket list.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Stars and silence
text: The brightest I have ever seen the stars and so quite that you can hear yourself think! Make sure you are on the island (between the hundreds of baobabs) before sunrise as you will never see a more beautiful sunrise ever again! Perfect camping experience!!!

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Magical and mythical
text: We flew in by private aircraft to take place in the annual Race for Rhinos air race, sponsored by Botswana Tourism. As such, it was not the normal way to travel there, and it was also quite busy with temporary accommodation and lots of aircraft. However approaching by air and landing there gave a magnificent view of the surrounding pans and emphasized how beautiful and magical the place really is.

photos.caption: My son and I at the aircraft in front of the island.

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: The most magical place on earth
text:
Once you get to the island you are hit by the mystical feeling that surrounds you - this dried up lake that has spurned the so called island is a place to come and feel at 'one' with nature and the universe. We arrived at sunset, just an hour to go before we saw the sun sink and the moon rise. There is no wood to be salvaged on the island, so make sure that you take your won or buy from the gate when you book to come. 

It was still warm as we pitched our tents for the night - this did not stop us lighting a small camp fire, getting the chairs out and just sitting and watching the night sky appear and the milky way unfold before our very eyes - it was truly amazing. The temperature drops rapidly in the early hours and you need a warm blanket - sunrise was equally spectacular with the bright red sky playing with the eyes 

I recommend a good walk around the island, it takes about an hour and a half - you can do this by yourself our there is a warden there who is more than happy to walk with you and point out the areas of interest - which is the rock formation and the stunning old Baobab trees - this is why people come, to see them in their glory 

You won't be disappointed even if it is a pretty hard drive to get there and not to be attempted without a 4x4

placeInfo.name: Kubu Island
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Fresh local eats and lovely company
text:
Had a delightful time with Lucy at her farm, seeing the thoughtfully grown fruit & veg, and glimpsing some local village life while accompanying her around. 

For groups, different activities can be organised, but since I was there alone - I just enjoyed the quiet campfire vibes and excellent food.

Speaking of - the food I had here was the best I had in all of Botswana. Dinner was traditional dishes made from fresh produce straight from the farm. Breakfast was epic - with eggs & fruit from the farm, honey from the farm bees,.. you get the idea. 

An excellent option if you’re close to Francistown.

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Unique and special experience
text:
We stayed at Kuminda Farm for just one night (perfect location between Nata and Gaborone) with our two young children (7 and 5) and it was absolutely brilliant. We stayed in the Rondavel which was a unique experience and one we won't forget. 

As many other people have said - Lucy is an incredible host and we highly recommend choosing the 'traditional food', which was utterly delicious! We were only sorry we couldn't stay longer and benefit from traditional dancing or the cooking lessons! 

It was the little touches too - the flowers in the bathroom, the kids were allowed to collect the eggs from the chickens, and the company - Lucy was great to chat with! Thanks again to Lucy and Fiona and everyone else at Kuminda.

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Peaceful and unplugged!
text: We spent a night at Kuminda Farm on our way from Francistown to Maun. We were travelling with our 2 teenagers. We all loved it! The chalets are very comfortable with beautiful shweshwe quilts with each chalet slightly different from the next. There are two stunning rock kopjes (small outcrops)  you can climb and you can have a walk around Lucy's amazing organic farm. The food was home grown and delicious and we were amazed to have organic blueberries in our breakfast in the middle of drought prone Botswana! Sitting around the fire under the enormous starry sky we felt completely at peace and unplugged from this troubled world. The whole place has a very genuine, authentic feel to it.  If you get a chance, stop in. You won't regret it.  Lucy's energy alone will hook you in!

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Sisterhood get away
text: Where would I stop off on my way to Maun or Kasane - Kuminda Farm. Such a traditional place and  experience with sophistication. I just love the hosts especially Lucy who is so willing to go the extra mile to make sure your experience is exceptional.  Bird life and organic gardening is so informative. The traditional rooms are so clean and charismatic and the chalet with a self catering kitchen is lovely. I love the fact that there is catering or self catering as you choose or book. And if you want to camp, that's also available. Thank you Lucy for always being a gracious host  whenever we stay. Highly recommended.

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: 100% recommend
text: This place is gorgeous and Lucy is such an amazing host. She is so welcoming and such a brilliant chef. The rooms were clean and so warm in the winter. I would 100% recommend. We stayed one night as a stop between SA and further into Botswana and it was a perfect, comfortable and relaxing stay.

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Warm Botswanan hospitality at its best!
text: A perfect stop over spot on the way from Jo'burg to the swamps.  The rooms are simple, clean and comfortable. Then the dinner…wow… Lucy is a very talented chef, and put on an awesome spread including some local dishes….and plenty of it.  Much of the food was home grown, and the Kumida farm chilli sauce is a winner!  The authentic buildings are wonderful, and the conversations around the camp fire memorable. Thanks for a great night.

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: lovely and interesting stay at Kuminda Farm
text:
We stayed at Kuminda Farm for a night between Francistown and Maun on our recent trip.  We slept in a village-style hut and had an interesting tour of the organic gardens and the farm's beautiful animals.  Very peaceful and rural, welcoming and friendly.  For dinner the owner, Lucy, made us a fabulous feast of local dishes, and we spend the evening outdoors by the fire with her talking about the farm and local Botswana culture.
Lucy so kindly gave us a ride from Francistown, then back the next day, and got us on the right bus to Maun.
Thanks Lucy for a great visit!

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Warmly welcomed with dinner under the stars
text: Upon arrival we were greeted by two very friendly gentlemen who work on the farm. Lucy arrived shortly afterwards and showed us around her beautiful organic farm. We had a traditional dinner with Lucy around the camp fire and it was magical, a truly special evening. The farm is so tranquil and we highly recommend visiting Kuminda!

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: A one night stop between Gaborone and Kasane
text:
We started our road trip in Botswana by a stay overbight at Lucy's Farm.
Great discussions, lovely home made dinner and morning discovery of the surrounding villages

Nice experience that we recommend.

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: An African jewel
text: We stayed at Kuminda Farm in August 2016 and had the most unforgettable experience. Our hostess Lucy made us most welcome, is a wonderful cook of indigenous African food and an incredibly knowledgeable and kind conversation partner. We will never forget the evenings under the stars with her and her husband John when she gave us so much insight into the life and cultural background of the people of the area and Botswana in general. We felt more like friends than paying guests and where overwhelmed by Lucy´s hospitality. For those who want to know more she even offers meetings with local people and, in our case, a visit to the primary school of the village. Kuminda Farm is a place of unspoilt beauty with its authentic huts built and decorated by local women, basic but very clean and functional ablutions and an extremely friendly and helpful staff. We camped there with our rooftop tent and it was a perfect hideaway, absolutely recommendable for people who prefer the small and authentic places to big campsites or hotels and who appreciate a personal and special atmosphere. Thank you, Lucy!

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: perfect farmstay for old and young
text:
The Kuminda Farm was our last stay in Botswana before we left to Simbabwe. 
It was a perfect mix of nature, farm and relaxation. The staff was awesome and very friendly. They showed us around and the children had a lot off fun with all the animals, especiallly with the chicks! 
We'll definitely coming back once.

Thanks to Lucy and John for that lovely memory

especially Minna will remember Kuminda due to "Hundi" ;-)

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Superb experience, this really is authentic Botswana, off the beaten track in every way
text: we stayed for two nights and just had the best time from the indigenous cuisine superbly cooked by Lucy and her team on an open braie under the stars to relaxing in the hammocks in the afternoon shade after visiting all the farm animals and walking through this dramatic landscape. We stayed in a lovely thatched Rondavel, the camping area looked great too with all the facilities you would expect. Apparently they have a lot of cultural events also, unfortunately there weren't any when we stayed but looked like they would be fun. Our host Lucy has created wonderful retreat including amazing massage if you want one, (I did and it was amazing!). Go visit when your travelling through Botswana!

photos.caption: Rondavel we stawe stayed in the ronedval on left with the braie in the centre and eating under t

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Great hospitality, great cultural experience!
text:
Kuminda Farm is really a great place to experience Botswana and Francistown. We stayed over for two nights and had a wonderful time with our host Lucy and her friend.

Lucy made us feel right at home (away from home). She introduced us to the people in the villages and made us great meals consisting of local cuisine.

We explored her farm that had various plants and birds for the nature lover and at night we sat around a bonfire gazing into the starry night chatting the night away with a glass of wine.

It was truly a magical and very memorable experience that will always stick with us and we are very grateful to have met Lucy, such a gracious and enjoyable person, she truly adds to the experience and goes out of her way to make you feel welcome and comfortable.

If you are looking to experience Botswana in its true form, then Kuminda Farm is the ideal destination.

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Staying at Kuminda farm
text: My wife and I stayed at Kuminda farm late September and we had a lovely time. Our hospitable host Lucy took us to the Independance ceremony in the town nearby to experience a local celebration of the event and it was awesome! The farm is nicely situated in a quiet surrounding and the food is freshly prepared. Staying at Kuminda farm was very special and a highlight of our vacation.

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Tradition, culture and aardvarks
text: We stopped over a couple of times on our trip around Botswana. A little oasis in the bush with really great hospitality and a traditional taste of Southern Africa away from the tourist spots. Highlight was campfire evenings and good conversation with our hosts who were full of useful information.

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Excellent place to stay
text: Stayed at Kuminda Farm on our tour round Botswana. The accommodation was comfortable, quiet and the farm produces some lovely food. Lucy introduced us to various aspects of local life including  taking us to a funeral and a wedding in the town, both of which were fascinating experiences. I have never seen a sky at night, anywhere, like that from  Kuminda, it is quite extraordinary. We were able to engage with local life at Kuminda and it was an excellent part of our stay in Botswana, we couldn't recommend it more highly.

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Excellent experience!
text: What an amazing gem right between Nata and Francistown. The owner as well are the staff are friendly and knowledgeable. The food and accommodations are excellent! This farm provides a great cultural insight. It is a great place to relax and learn! We loved our stay at Kuminda Farm.

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Loved it!
text:
Bij aankomst werden we meteen verwelkomd door Lucy en haar team. We kregen een drankje aangeboden en werden meegenomen op rondleiding op het domein. 
We verbleven hier 2 dagen en we hebben ons geen enkel moment verveeld! 
Het typische Botswaans eten, gezellig kampvuur, de regendansers, de leuke slaapplekken... Alles was er tip top in orde. We kregen zelfs de kans om familie te ontmoeten van Lucy. Een zekere aanrader!

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Muy recomendable
text: El motivo inicial de la estancia fue una parada para partir en dos días nuestro paso de Kasane a Sudafrica. Pero se acabó convirtiendo en una fantastica tarde-noche de relax, conversación y una perfecta cena tradicional, que ayudamos a preparar para pasar el rato y participar de la cocina con el equipo de Lucy. La cena consistió en ensalada, pap, panocha de maiz, salchichas y pollo, una especie de pisto y sobretodo destacar unas descomunales espinacas cocinadas con cacahuetes triturados. Nada especial, todo sencillo, pero bueno, acompañado de la conversación de Lucy, vino sudafricano y las estrellas y los ruidos de la noche. Que más se puede pedir? Nos alojamos en un chalet de 2 habitaciones, 1 baño y pequeña cocina, básico, pero limpio, en el que sólo encontramos a faltar, por decir algo, una nevera y un ventilador en las habitaciones. La ducha con poca presión, pero suficiente para ducharse. Poco más se puede decir, venir expresamente seguramente no valdría la pena, pero si te coge de camino, no lo dudes. Encantados de haber colaborado con Lucy en su proyecto, felicidades a ella y a toda su gente

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Natur pur!
text:
Die Kuminda Farm liegt eine 3/4 Stunde nordwestlich von Francistown an der A 3 nach Nata. Es ist ein großes Gelände mit ein paar kleinen einfachen Häuschen. Der Bau der Chalets und Rundhütten mit Naturmaterial und die Anlage der Gärten erfolgte unter der Vorgabe der Bewahrung der vorhandenen Natur. Ein großer Biogarten liefert ständig frisches Gemüse für die Küche, aus der vorzügliche Speisen kommen - von Chefin Lucy selbst gekocht. Aus ihrer Hand stammt auch die gesamte Planung für den Bau und die Ausgestaltung der Anlage mit ihrem üppigem Baum- und Buschbestand und den kleinen Wanderwegen, in deren Mitte ein großer Felshügel mit herrlicher Aussicht auf seine Besteigung (wenige Minuten) wartet. 
Sie hat sich damit einen Lebenstraum erfüllt. Lucy ist eine echte Persönlichkeit mit hoch interessantem Lebenslauf. Im Nachbarort Marabelo aufgewachsen, hat sie mit uns eine Rundfahrt in die Umgebung und in das Dorf gemacht und hat uns die Entwicklung der letzten Jahrzehnte so nahe gebracht, wie es besser nicht hätte sein können. Es war eine Freude bei und mit ihr zu Abend zu essen und ihren Erzählungen zuzuhören. Dieser Ort ist ein echter Geheimtipp - noch!

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Maravillosa Lucy y maravillosa Kuminda Farm
text: Lucy y todo su equipo son maravillosas personas. La atención es fantástica, y su proyecto de granja ecológica en un entorno tan duro como el Kalahari es admirable. Además su comida tradicional setsuana es deliciosa. Para repetir sin duda

placeInfo.name: Kuminda Farm
placeInfo.address: Francistown/Nata Road Marobela Village, Francistown Botswana

title: Amazing explored enjoy
text: Ok was there back in 74 ish as a kid, deserts don't change too much. I spent around 3 nights there back then stayed near bushman settlement. They took us tracking leopard on foot, dug cool drinking water in buried ostrich eggs en route. We caught a snake too, they prepared it for eating, being about 9 I passed that opportunity.  I recall making stick den with help, living wild, bonding with those amazing people even trying their clicking language and customs. Amazing memories, please visit if in Botswana you will not regret it.

title: Extreme Heat
text: Amazing place with amazing wildlife. The Meerkats were a real highlight but just a great experience was had in temperatures above 40.

title: hot hot hot
text: only drove through the dessert but the heat is insane, white dry sand everywhere and in the distance can only see a blurry horizon, goats and cattle everywhere which amazes me in these conditions.

title: Just what the doctor ordered
text: We spent 7 days camping at kori and sundays pans in the CKNP and it did not disappoint. There was nothing to tell the private camps apart from the national parks camps, their amenities were identical. But the kori camps are on a through road and we had just to look up to see other campers on their game drives...showered dust on us as they passed. The Sunday camps are remote and gorgeous. Staff at the gate were friendly and welcoming. They were out of firewood to sell, which is an issue since you are not supposed to collect once in the park. Kori camps also have the unfortunate position of being near the workers camp...one could hear them at night and they drove the tractor past us four times a day. However, still one the last wilderness areas on the planet and unfenced camp sites add to the atmosphere.

title: Amazing desert , amazing wildlife and local bushmen inhabitants.
text: My favourite desert of all time and I mean hot and sandy not a raspberry tart. I was here for several days and went trekking on foot with bushmen tracking leopard, snakes. We even ate snake, drank water from buried ostrich eggs on well worn hunting paths. I hope Botswana resists temptation to dig up the desert for diamonds from foreign pressure would be shame to lose this amazing place.

title: Ablutions at Deception valley campsite in bad shape..
text:
We stayed at the CKGR  (rooftop tent) at one of the deception valley campsites, we've been here before several years ago and found it quite rewarding for wildlife, although this time less luck, even when staying for a few hours next of one of the few waterholes.

We got appointed a campsite, but as last time, we only saw one other couple, so could (luckily) chose our site, as some had still some rubbish around, some ablutions were in bad shape, and seen it are long drops... Bucketshowers didn't work.. So, some work for the NP to bring it back in shape.

Is it worth going here, hmm, difficult, it's a boring drive to get to the gate and from there it takes you again 1 hour to get to the pans, If to go, I suggest to stay for a few days..

title: Kalahari Rest Camp
text: A very comfortable self-catering cottage after a long haul from any South African border post to Kang, Botswana ( on route to the Delta or Namibia).  The bird life is fantastic!  Be prepared to have all you need for the kitchen handy, as it is truly self-catering - no cutlery, crockery, etc.  Comfortable beds and bedding is provided.  There is also a great little bar and restaurant, but a little pricey (but on a par with most other camps in Botswana.

title: Deception valley
text: stayed 2 nights in Central Kahlahari on BOGA-campsite. Kalahari was green due to lots of rain previous weeks. Monitored lions and cheethas hunting - of course many of ohter desert animal including oryx and sprinbok

title: Endless landscapes only sound coming from animals
text: I liked the vastness and desolation of the desert beautiful. We camped three nights in the wilderness of the  Kalahari Game Reserve with only sounds of roaring lions, hyenas, etc. Only here you can possibly see the Kalahari lion, with its beautiful black manes. And you need a good guide!

title: Into Darkest Africa
text: Roderick and I spent a wonderful holiday camping in our off road Trailvan, with our friend Genie Retief and Shen & Ian Coelthard. Africa is HUGE! The sky is even bigger. We had leopards nonchalantly stroll trough our unfenced campsite, met wonderful travellers from Europe and spent star spangled nights around a huge fire, with me singing songs and a special moment for me, was when I sang about the Kalahari in Afrikaans and the young lady from Austria said: "No, we don't understand the words, but it must be a song for HERE, because I can hear the open space and solitude in your voice."

photos.caption: The visitor to our Camp - Feels weird to be ignored by it!

title: Exceptional Photo safari
text: Over 10 days we travelled to 3 camps in the Okavango Delta, an area of 8,000 square km.  photo opportunities and animal encounters were extraordinary.  The experiences at each camp varied, from desert conditions to delta conditions.  From watching a herd of herds of elephants taking mud baths, watching leopards in trees and then following them on their hunts, lions roaring in the evening just next to our Land Rover; zebras, giraffes, wildebeest, warthogs, hippos, baboons, birds... We were at the Wilderness Safari camps (Kalihari Plains, Xigera and Chitabe, traveling by 12 passenger planes between the camps.  Our photo trip was arranged by Natural Habitats.  Dave Luck was an exceptional expedition leader.  Our trip had 6 travelers using two Land Rovers for each outing.  Camp staffs were exceptionally friendly with fine food and some evening native singing.  Each cabin had a large comfortable bed, shower, toilet, fan...  From a photographic vantage point, the opportunities greatly surpassed my expectations.

title: African Adventure Safaris: Central Kalahari Game Reserve Botswana
text: Amazing Trip to a remote Area of Botswana in Dezember 2011. Camping under the stars in the wild, beeing kept awake by the calls of lions and hyenas at night. Saw loads of Kalahari Lions in mating season. Loads of Oryx arriving in the Reserve. A place not for the faint hearted but luckily we were well looked after by the team of African Adventure Safaris. Ant sharing his longtime and profound experience about wildlife and the bush with us and serving every evening after a long day of doing safari a great dinner cooked at the camp fire. Would do it again any time!

title: Kalahari Game Reserve, Botswana Africa
text:
Located in the Central Kalahari Plains Reserve in Botswana, this concession stands alone. I wouldn’t think that such a remote site would be alive with so much wildlife. My husband and I were there towards the end of January, 2013. 

The Kalahari Plains Camp is operated by the Wilderness Safaris tour company. We spent 3 nights here going on game drives each day. We saw Oryx, springbok, steenbok, cape fox, cheetah, elephants, black mane lions, goshawk, secretary bird and 1000s of migrating Marabou Stork, plus numerous bird species. The vast expanse of the plains is awesome to behold and teaming with wildlife.  One morning, our guide took us to Deception Valley where researchers, Mark and Delia Owens were based for 7 years, studying predators. It was here where we took a break, stretched our legs and enjoyed the beauty of the surrounding acacia trees.

Our raised tent was spacious with hard wood floors and king sized bed. Bathroom was clean and spacious as well with plenty of room for my toiletries. We even had a wonderful private deck to enjoy the views of the Kalahari Plains during the midday or relax by the soaking pool. The service was excellent. I enjoyed the meals and the camaraderie of the other guests. You could charge your batteries for camera and cell phone, etc. at the main lodge. No internet. I didn’t miss it.

This Safari game trip was planned by an agent of Wilderness Safaris Company, Discover Africa located in Beachwood, OH, U.S.  Wilderness Safaris is an African based company that does not do direct booking for U.S. clients. It has its own concessions in Botswana, fleet of planes that escorted us from one concession to another. We stayed at four sites, three in Botswana and one in Zambia. The entire operation is well organized. 

My husband and I are retired and travel a great deal.   I have always booked trips with group tours. This is the first time I booked a custom tour. I’m glad I did. We had all the comforts of being looked after as if on a group tour plus the enmities and service that comes with personalized attention of doing it our way. This is the best of two worlds.

title: Anthony Holley- Across Botswana 4x4 drive
text: An absolutely amazing trip. Spent four weeks doing a self drive from South Africa, through Kgalagadi Trans-frontier National Park, through the central Kalahari desert onto the Okavango swamps. Then through Moremi, Chobe and onto Victoria falls. Finally down the East of Botswana to the Limpopo. An incredible adventure- more game than you could imagine, spectacular sunsets, remarkable late afternoon thunderstorms, at times challenging terrain with unbelievably remote camping. Arranged to spend Christmas at a lodge namely: Tau Pan- couldn't fault it. Another wonderful break from the camping, was Stanley Safari lodge at the Falls in Zambia- a truly decadent experience! Just do it! Andy at "Drive Botswana" is a excellent starting point in planning a trip.

title: Wow! What a wonderful experience
text: We stayed at the Kalahari Game Lodge and it was just the most beautiful place imaginable. Each small bungalow, with its dome shaped thatch was superbly equipped, and again the food was out of this world. The game drive was interesting because it took us to a San people's resettlement village - a very sad place, since the government has insisted that the San, or as we know them in Europe, The Bushmen of the Kalahari, no longer live their thousands of years old lifestyle, but moved them into houses. It was a sobering thought and well worth seeing for myself what it means, as I had seen these wonderful people showing their way of life on a previous trip to Botswana, and what a huge loss it is to the world that they can no longer live their own traditional way. On a brighter note, watching Meercats and watching Ground Squirrels was like stepping into a TV wildlife show and every bit as entertaining. A very memorable visit all round.

title: Grasslands Camp-Kalahari Desert
text:
Definitely worth a visit . We flew from San Francisco, to London, to Johannesburg, to Maun and then to the Kalahari to Grasslands Bushmans Camp. What a journey and what a place to end up. It was perfect!  We were so tired and exhausted from traveling and it was so hot when we got there - like 115 degrees and no air conditioning. Thought we were going to die. Our hosts were welcoming but a little distant. There were only 4 other guests in camp and they were only staying one night which meant we had one night all to ourselves. The waterhole provided so much entertainment, it was like an African soap opera , always something going on but you could never be sure what to expect. So many animals, they all came to you, you did not have to go out looking for them. Our hosts warmed up and after their other guests left and we had  a very intimate experience and such a fab time.  We had the host and the whole place to ourselves, in some situations, that might not be so good, but in this case, it was fantastic. Our own private place and our own private guide.
Tien  took us out to meet the Bushmen and what a great experience. He also took us to meet the wild Dogs
 and lions that he has on his property. What a great experience. There was a full  moon while we were there and so we sat up late at nite watching all the animal activity at the waterhole
 and surrounds. 
This is not a luxury place to stay but the food is great, the wildlife viewing is great and if its not too busy the host will be great. We had a great time. I highly recommend it.

title: DeGraaff Grassland Safaris provides a wonderful window on the desert and San (Bushman) culture!
text: I only spent two days at DeGraaff Grassland Safaris (Grassland Bushman Lodge), but it was special, and reasonably priced. Lodging consists of beautiful, spacious cottages of brick, tile, wood with thatched roofs. Food and drink were excellent. Trees around the cottages and the large meeting and dining area provide shade during mid-day. Mornings and evenings one can tour by 4WD vehicle or on foot, and see the abundant wildlife (lions and jackals, oryx and eland, kites and eagles to list but a few). Unique to Grasslands is the family's relationship with the San community, allowing a window into their knowledge of the desert plants and their cultural activities, through fascinating demonstrations. If you come to see the delta, make sure not to miss the desert, you'll be most pleased you did!

title: Ultimo giorno in Namibia, indimenticabile
text:
Abbiamo visitato la zona in Nambia alla fine del nostro tour di 10 giorni. E' una vasta distesa sabbiosa di colore rosso con piante e tanto verde, non si può paragonare al Namib, sono differenti, entrambi stupendi nella loro particolarità.
Dal nostro Lodge escursione nel pomeriggio in fuoristrada accompagnati da una guida locale e dalla nostra guida Alberto. Panorami mozzafiato, colori e sensazioni bellissime. Al tramonto spettacolare aperitivo su una duna, ricordo indelebile.

title: Se ami la Natura,sicuramente un Must del tuo viaggio in Sudafrica
text:
Partiti da Cape Town con un'auto a noleggio, abbiamo percorso miglia di chilometri fino ad arrivare nel Parco Nazionale del Kalahari.
Attenzione: se avete intenzione di entrare nel parco, noleggiate una Jeep! So che sembra un consiglio ovvio ma i noleggiatori non si faranno scrupoli a dirvi che con qualsiasi auto si può raggiungere perché le strade sono percorribili...Bugia! Il sentiero, ovviamente , è sabbioso e se non si va con l'auto giusta si resta bloccati, come ho fatto io. Esperienza assolutamente da evitare, fidatevi sulla parola : portate kit di primo soccorso, crema solare protezione minima 30,spray contro insetti,cibo e tutta l'acqua che potete e non allontanatevi mai dall'auto .Anche se i Campi-Fortino in cui dormire segneranno il vostro nome e la vostra destinazione prossima per controllare che arriviate alla prossima tappa, non aspettatevi salvataggi cinematografici e non andate in giro dopo il tramonto, i predatori sono a caccia di notte.
Stupenda esperienza!

title: Tramonto mozzafiato
text:
L'ennesimo scenario mozzafiato di cui ci siamo inebriati durante il tour in Namibia!
Deserto roccioso rosso che dà il meglio di sè al tramonto.

title: Posto unico
text: Uno dei parchi più belli del mondo.. È vero che l africa ti rimane nel cuore. Importante il rispetto delle regole e nelle stagioni più calde rifornirsi di acqua

title: Immersi  in  un  ...  documentario
text: L'esperienza   in Botswana  è  bellissima  ,   si  è  costantemente  immersi  nella  natura  ,  animali  ovunque  e  di  tutti  i  generi  ,  come  vivere  in  un  documentario , l'importante  è  essere  al  posto  giusto  nel  momento  giusto  ...  a  qualsiasi ora  del  giorno  qualcosa  ...  succede  in  natura!

title: Muito legal de visitar!
text: Lugar maravilhoso! Conheci varios locais e seus estilos de vida, vi elefantes cruzando as estradas, avestruz, alem de um por do sol incrível!

title: " Mitico P. N. Kalahari ... Inmenso , único "
text:
Resulto una experiencia increíble ¡ La verdad no esperaba disfrutar tanto , ni de ver tantos animales . Suerte tuvimos a raudales como no , desde que entramos ¡ según nuestro camión de deslizaba por esas tierras rojizas senti la magia de África .

Un P.N.Transfrontier que hoy lo forman la unión de tres parques , una verdadera joya , tanto en paisajes desérticos fabulosos ! como en fauna sin duda . 
Desde su entrada con bonitos y bien integrados edificios , en su entorno un complejo hotelero con confortable alojamiento .

Fue mi primer dia de safari , que lujo por favor de abistamientos .Desde un leopardo que desde muy lejos el chofer capto a día de hoy aun no se como lo vio y la suerte de estar en el lugar y en el momento oportuno junto a la poza de agua ¡ Que maravillosa sensación verle como se aproximo a saciar su sed ....Temimos por los animales que ante su presencia formaron escuadras de proteccón , que instinto .

Todo un lujo de momentos unicos sin duda , luego vendrian leónes de melena negra desperezandose y marcando territorio , oryx preciosos , springbook , aves y mangostas o familias de avestruces con su prole y tantos más .

Sería por la tarde de regreso cuándo tendriamos otro momento inolvidable ¡ Cinco guepardos juntos , se animan a ir de caza !!
Y ni en la mejor pasarela veriamos nada semejante , preciosos es decir poco , maravillosos y elegantes .

Ya de regreso seria el atardecer el que colmaria la magia de un gran dia de safari y tras un amanecer fantastico sonrei ¡ Que me depararia el segundo día , hoy os puedo asegurar que fantastico tambien .
Un parque que colmo nuestras expectativas , bueno a falta de suricato que no tuvimos a tiro de objetivo y eso que son un simbolo en las guias , pues no los vimos .

Pero como quejarse si vimos los mas esquivos y dificiles , con fotos excepcionales . Fue dificil conciliar el sueño a mi retina acudian la fauna , a modo de pasarela particular y la vegetación de arbustos espinosos en flor del Kalahari .
Y un poquito de ellas comparto con el resto de viajaros , invitandoles a que vayan .

title: La grande sete
text:
Vasta distesa sabbiosa dell'Africa meridionale.Copre il 70% del territorio del Botswana,lo Zimbabwe,il Sudafrica e la Namibia,di cui la recensione.A un'altezza media di 900m.
E' il quarto deserto al mondo per estensione.Nella parte nord-est vi si trova una delle più grandi miniere di diamanti del mondo.
Abitato dall'antico popolo dei San(Boscimani).Vi si trovano molti animali,tra cui l'elegantissimo Orice.Paesaggi stupendi,sabbia rossa a perdita d'occhio...Imperdibile!

title: Fantastisch dieren spotten
text: Drie volle dagen doorgebracht in dit park en het verveelde geen enkel moment: hoogtepunten waren luipaard van dichtbij, idem honingdas, dubbele jachtpartij van 3 jachtluipaarden, net gemiste oryx-kill door troep leeuwen. Het leven zoals het is in dit park, en niet te druk.

title: Прекрасная пустыня
text: Проезжали через нее по trans kalahari highway из Габароне в Виндхук. Вечером. Очень запомнилось то, что есть несколько отворотов с хайвэя ко всяческим постройкам, маленьким достопримечательностям. Вдоль дороги местами растут цветы и их специально поливают, очень красиво. На пути мало трафика, поселков практически нет. Попадаются животные, особенно если свернуть с трассы на какую-нибудь параллельно идущую дорогу. Есть достопримечательность, которая нигда не отмечена в интернете: The lonely tree - это одиноко стоящий баобаб среди буша. Красивое место и какое-то нереальное, будто его там не может быть. Были там на закате, потрясающе красиво: кровавый закат и одинокий баобаб среди пустоты на много километров вокруг. Советую.

title: I Boscimani
text: Sono stato 5 volte nel deserto del Kalahari, le prime due come un normale turista, poi ho incontrato il popolo dei Boscimani e tutto è cambiato. Il Kalahari senza di loro, offre una natura mozzafiato ma spoglia del vero significato di quei luoghi. Per una miniera di diamanti, il popolo dei Boscimani è stato maltrattato e costretto a lasciare la propria casa. Per me, che mi occupo di Surviving, i Boscimani sono stati i miei maestri, nativi capaci di sopravvivere in una terra tanto ostile. Il mio messaggio è: andate nel deserto del Kalahari perchè è un luogo spettacolare, unico al mondo ma pretendete di conoscere e vivere a contatto con questo popolo fiero di esistere.

title: Que experiencia!!!!
text: Estuvimos 2 noches en bush camp en el delta. Fue una de las mejores experiencias, noches de luna llena, todos los sonidos de animales que se imaginen, natacion en el delta. Las caminatas al amanecer y por la tarde , lo mejor , elefantes , zebras, hipopotamos , jirafas, monos, serrpientes, impalas, y hasta 2 leonas que nos hicieron asustar y mucho. Por las noches habia que quedarse dentro de la carpa porque no sabias  con que te podias encontrar afuera  y algo de razon habia porque los sonidos eran impresionantes. Obviamente volveremos

title: Gorgeous landscape
