text: This is a gorgeous, and very untypical-Botswana, walk. But not everybody can do it: you need to be a bit agile and not be too afraid of hights. Guide is included in the high entry price, and obligatory.

title: Moremi Gorge
text: Beautiful hidden gem in the western part of Botswana. Lush green and friendly waterfalls. Knowledgeable and passionate local guides.

title: Breathtaking view
text: Beautiful place Moremi Gorge, like an oasis in the desert. From the restaurant you have a breathtaking view. The climb up on the hills is an nice hike with wonderful fresh water streams and the waterfalls on the rockterraces on the way up were magnificant. It is quite a climb but worthwile for the experience and scenery you get back for it. Only the groups were quite big. On top you see the vultures flying over.

title: Fantastic
text: Great service, amazing rooms and a beautiful view. Everything in the rooms was clean and the food served was yummy. Nice cocktails and a beautiful pool.

title: Had an amazing time during the walk to the waterfalls,we were equipped with information all the way.
text: My best moment was when we took photos the guide was very helpful and wow what beautiful pictures does nature produce!!

photos.caption: We will go as high as the water fall

title: Fun stay
text: Stunning natural views. The campsites are extra clean equipped with rest rooms and a sink. Friendly staff members from groundsman to manager. The walk trail to the gorge is wide enough to allow a guest to come out without a single scretch  A trip to Go Moremi Gorge is an epic experience not to be missed.

title: travelling though the streams i.e. stream 1 upto 3
text: Moremi Gorge is the place to be, people should go there and enjoy, that's a historic experience. Climbing those hills is like you are at Mount Kilimanjaro. I enjoyed Moremi Gorge

title: Amazing Stuff
text: Goo Moremi Gorge was so lit. The guide was amazing and his passion about the place was just out of this world. I was also impressed by the fact that the Gorge was so clean. Great!

title: GOO MOREMI GORGE
text: The place is soo cool. the tour guides know what they are doing. the culture is amazing. it is some kind of a historic place. i did hike when i was there. i loved the gorges. they are so beautiful. the breeze is what i needed to relax. the food is also amazing. the pool location was strategic, facing the mountains.

title: I enjoyed the hike.
text: It’s was a longgggggg walk from our camp but totally worth it. Although we didn’t get to go to the actual Gorge we were able to trek to a beautiful scared waterfall. The water  is crystal clear and if you are lucky you might get wild figs if the monkeys don’t get to them first.It is a rocky trek so proper shoes and clothing is highly recommend. It took about an hour to and from the waterfall. The history of the Gorge is so scared that you’re not even allowed to whistle for fear of summoning the ancestors. I would totally visit again and take the 6 hour trek to the beginning of the Gorge.

title: Good experience
text: Beautiful scenery. Best to visit this place in winter because it is quite a long hike and the temperatures can rise to over 40 degrees in spring and summer

title: What an experience! An awesome jungle experience
text: Goo Moremi gorge is the place to be! The experience is exciting. It is really in that place that you see the greatness of God. The creation power: those waterfalls, the jungle, the rocks, just that nature... The beauty of that place will wow you. The guides are of professional standard. You will indeed be fascinated and refreshed. Please visit Moremi gorge, you'll never be disappointed.

photos.caption: These are my gals on this tour(@ Moremi gorge).....at the 3rd waterfall
You are given these sticks to support yourself where its slippery, not to fight anything,heheheh
At the top there....approaching waterfall number 3. This is where you get the thrill, Adrenalin

title: What an awesome place!
text:
The place is easy to reach, not very far from Palapye.

The tour guides were very good and the walk through the bush to the waterfalls was just beautiful. The water from the springs was also very pure, and natural freshness oozes everywhere.

This is a place for one to relax their mind.

The highlight of my trip was the Sir Seretse Khama alarm stone. I discovered that African traditions and beliefs are very much alike, as in Shona we actually have a saying 'Gomo rawa - meaning the mountain has fallen' which means a King has passed on, and that saying being validated by real events as in the passing on of Sir Seretse Khama made me to be a proud African.

This place has many things similar to Matobo Hills in Zimbabwe, mostly the sacredness.

I feel Moremi Gorge is not fully marketed to the world as this is a proud Batswana monument.

title: Beautiful Gorge
text: Our's was a day trip. Very attractive and naturally beautiful location. One can enjoy many small waterfalls, even if it is not allowed to enter into water. We took around 2 hours for the Gorge walk. One guide  was with us and he was explaining everything. Beautiful location.

title: AWESOME PLACE
text: This is such a beautiful, awesome place to discover for yourself, refreshing jungle with waterfalls and rocks.First time to discover the place even though i'm a Motswana,  I feel its not marketed well as many don't know the place. The stuff is great as well.

photos.caption: fun experience,climbing rocks & crossing over the water stream
beautiful chalets with outdoor shower and braai area
walking through the jungle with sticks to aid your walk

title: Beautiful walk with a competent guide
text: The gorge offers a nice walk to a small waterfall, about 2 hours round trip, together with a competent guide, who can tell you all you want to know about the animals, trees and plants you see along the way.

title: Great Braai facilities and awesome waterfalls
text:
In such a barren and isolated area, Moremi Gorge is lush and refreshing and waterfalls are beautiful. 
We had a work Braai and facilities great and clean in a camping area.
We then had a guide to go up the waterfalls and it was the best. It was like we were in the Chobe.
Worth the trip - so nice

title: Moremi Gorge - An Oasis!
text:
Exciting to see a Waterfall in Water scarce Botswana!
While the climb unto the top is moderately difficult, as it is not advisable for differently-abled or very old people, but it is an exciting experience to walk through the rain-forest like vegetation with the stream running continuously under your feet with few rope clinging locations......!  Need about an hour and half to go up and come down, what made the trip more exciting was that we could spot few Elands as we drove back from Gorge to the Gate!!

title: A little gem!
text:
We visited here not knowing what to expect however we're pleasantly surprised! 
The hike is hard in parts but the scenery is very rewarding!
The guide was very interesting and knew a lot!

title: Difficult access, but great place
text: If you are visiting Old Palapye cultural site with it's great Old Church, do not miss Moremi Gorge. Deep in the forest, with water and ancient rock paintings, it is a place to remember. But, prepare for a long walk, as car has to be left long behind. If you have 4x4, you could come to the Old Palapye site, and the best is to park there. But if you come, you will face beaty of the nature in all its facets - big forest, water springs, great gorge. Breathtaking experience.

title: Natures Finest
text:
If your looking to do a fitness trail/hike this place is worth the visit, between two mountainous structures , this thick green green green vegetation with all animals inhabiting it , not to forget but the fresh water stream running right through is truly the cherry on top of it all.
Loved the experience

title: Magical and Serene
text: Moremi Gorge heritage site about 1 hour east of Palapye.The Moremi-Mannonye Community Trust charges a small fee to enter this  Magical place.The trust employees people from the village ,Our young  guide Zuma who is extremely knowledgeable and passionate is amazing .No drinking alcohol or smoking in the area.A must see

title: Wonderland
text: Most beautiful gem in the hills of Botswana. A little Eden hidden away in a gorge. Lovely walk and scenery.

title: Dream vacation
text: It is an amazing experience and very relaxing .laxury Charley's that bring you closer to nature,through the waterfalls and culture of the people of moremi,trees,hills and and an Eco friendly charlet.

title: Memorable Experience
text: Moremi Gorge is absolutely amazing. You are taken on a guided tour where you get to see the endangered cape vulture and other birds, hike through beautiful rock formations, waterfalls and rest at a rock believed to have rolled down a cliff the same time a famous chief died symbolizing death of a great leader. All this transmutes the experience into something completely spiritual, refreshing, tranquil and different - something fun, engaging, and deeply filled with nature.

title: Short visit
text: Great walk to do, with knowledgeable guide. Remember to take good hiking shoes as you have to clamber over rocks, across stream, and cling to a rack face. Well worth the effort.

title: Moremi Gorge stay
text: The chalets were first class - well equipped and spotless. We did the gorge walk with Guide Zuma who was knowledgeable, friendly and helpful to us four oldies (68-72). We would highly recommend this place but signage to get there could be improved.

title: Amazing
text:
what a place this is , truly spectacular in all ways possible. especially the friendly staff.
I recommend this stop to anyone looking to explore botswana natural beauty.

title: Worth the time
text: We stayed just one night here. If we got back there, I would stay two, and do a lot more of the walks that are available. This is place is run by locals at a top class standard. Well worth the visit. It does pay to have a booking for a campsite. Lonley Planet was out of date with that, and the siting of the campsites. Opposite to waht Lonely Planet had. Beautiful place. If you are short of time, or not keen on a walk. Drive to the Gorge entrance.

title: Waterfalls, forest and birds of prey
text:
As you leave the hot, dry car park it is hard to imagine that in just a few minutes, on foot, the terrain is so cool, lush and green. 
The walk to the top is 5-6 hours (round trip) and be prepared for a challenging climb up and down the gorge.  I walked to the 3rd waterfall and waited for my group to return which was enough and a beautiful place to enjoy nature.  
We saw a hyena print and heard frogs along the way, otherwise plenty of birds.
The guide was very informative and a must to navigate the large rocks and escarpments.

title: Campsite
text: This was our first stop over on our way to Chobe. The camp site is magnificent. The ablutions were very clean with hot water to shower . All in all, it's a camp site we will definitely stay at again.

title: Out of the world, the most serene,beautiful  and affordable travel destination
text: Simply breathtaking! I never knew we had these amazing places right here in BW, the place is full of mysteries, and we enjoyed the tales as eloquently retold by our and amazing guide Zuma [he was  the highlight of our trip!] came here with my friends at a paltry BWP 500. The chalets, outdoor shower and the gas braai stands were rather refreshing. The gorges and ever-flowing water were inexplicably magical and the passionate Zuma made the tour extra enjoyable! I'm definitely coming back either with family or alone just to enjoy the serenity and some moments of self-reflection

title: breathtaking beauty,a wonderful people
text:
one night was not enough! we booked a 2beds, and 1bed chalets..The people are really helpful and warm. The truest African manners i haven't seen in a long while!impressive! the elderly staff members are poetic in their speech,it tickled the deep tswana roots in us.
The chalets were spotlessly clean,with the finest finishes and an awesome view!!!
We appreciated the quietness and intimacy of the place..
then the gorge!its "beauty" is an understatement!..one of life's treasured memories..it would have not been so breathtaking without Zuma!!This guy must live forever!!!!!! He knows the gorge like his own name,we felt safe though there were quite a number of snakes,! His appreciation of his forefathers and his passion of culture preservation just made us fall in love all over again with this place!!! If you ever see this, "Thanks Zuma,you are a rare gem!"Twist,thank you for the warm smile and being the "photographer", we liked your friendly smile!
we are definitely going back,SOON!

title: An Awesome Experience of Culture and Nature
text: The quietness of the African bush, full of mystery sounds of the night. Excellent camping sites, beneath huge Marula and other trees, where you wish to just stay another night... and don't want to leave in the morning.  a Mixture of sacred cultural beliefs and the home of breeding vultures. An African destination to revisit again and again, and find the deep secrets of your own heart amongst the oasis like water pools in a desert land.

title: ideal Stop over or weekend get away.
text:
Beautiful appointed one and two bed roomed chalets self catering all you need to bring along is your food and drink . Well kept camping sites for those wanting to camp .
A must is a guided walk up the gorge very spiritual .......
The only downside is there are no shops in the erea so you really have to see that you have brought everything with.

title: You wont think you're in Botswana!
text:
What a magical place! Lush green forest (even in dry season). Clear running water, beautiful waterfalls and pools all year round. And rare vultures in the cliffs as well. Excellent guides who know a lot about the area and help you with some of the tricky rock climbing.

Tar road all the way until Moremi village then it is mainly sand which could be problem for 4x2s in the wet season. Staff at the entrance were among the most welcoming and friendly I've met in Botswana.

Chalets (Separate review) are excellent too

title: Delightful "Getaway" from Gabs
text:
Just 4 hours from Gabs, this was a wonderful overnight getaway. The accommodations were beautiful--full sized bed with mosquito net, kitchenette (sink, 2 burners, refrigerator and gas grill plus dinnerware, silverware, pots/pans, strainer, spoons, tongs, rolling pin, you name it, it was in the cupboard), and bathroom with outdoor shower. The only thing that would make it better would be more privacy (we could hear every word our neighbors were saying while we were on our deck and they were on theirs).

Now onto the gorge--amazing! It's so hard to believe that amid all of the winter brown in Botswana there is this little green oasis! We hiked to waterfall 5 which took us 2.5 hours round trip (with rests and stops for pictures). After that hike, we walked on the path from the chalets to reception, which was surprisingly strenuous because it's over sand. The next morning, we woke up for a 6:30 hike to see the vultures. Well-worth the early alarm! I really can't describe how beautiful it is, you'll just have to see it for yourself!

title: Breathtaking!
text: You can more than literally "get lost" in this breath taking place. Plus, the cultural history of the majestic gorge makes you appreciate and respect it even more.

title: Goo moremi gorge acccommodation
text: Stayed here one night and would have loved to stay more. The accommodation was fantastic in a self catering bungalow.  The guide Twist was great and took us into the gorge a sacred site for the local people.  Very reasonably priced. Able to get through with two wheeled vehicle as now have bridges over river and sand is firm.  Took walks to bird hide and watched endangered vultures soaring up above. Fantastic experience.  Need to ensure that you have all your food with you as no real store in the town.  Might need 4wd in wet season.

title: A must see if in Botswana
text:
A community run project, now with 6 excellently equipped chalets - outdoor showers, indoor bathroom small kitchen and gas brai/BBQ. One of the best places I have ever stayed, it felt like a real luxury outing but was only P450 (30GBP) a night for two of us.

The gorge itself is very impressive with a choice of walks from 90 mins to 5 hours. For the longer ones good shoes and some athleticism is needed. Cape Vultures add to the attraction. Guides are compulsory for the longer walks and while there is no charge a large tip is really deserved.

They are hoping to build more chalets and add a restaurant in the near future as well as introducing Zebras.

title: Community run project which is well worth a visit.
text:
Moremi Gorge is situated in the Tswapong Hills near Palapye but well away from main roads.
There are really good campsites here with good showers and toilets. All reasonably priced.
The reserve provides a guide who will take you for a walk to the gorge itself, which is really impressive. You can watch cape vultures coming and going from their nests in the gorge's vulture colony.
Zuma, our guide, was really knowledgable, pointing out the tracks of animals including python and leopard. The place has a really wild feel to it. The village of Moremi is also historically interesting ,as the whole village was moved back some years ago away from possible flood danger near the gorge itself. Your guide will tell you about it.

title: Worth a visit!
text: Only one night at Moremi Gorge is not enough. The campsites are really great with nice braai facilities and neat and clean ablution facilities. Great hikes that should also be done. The approach road may be a challenge in the rainy season and should then only be done in a 4x4.

title: Fantastic and personal service from Manager.
text:
Love visiting Moremi. Chalets beautiful. Excellent service from manager,' Marie' who personally took us on trails and very knowledgable about the environment, wildlife and surroundings.
Beautiful birdlife and waterfalls.
An absolute must for a day trip or overnight. Campsite not suitable and believe still to develop.

title: A lovely place for a little solitude
text: I stayed at the absolutely lovely Moremi Gorge Lodge, which is well run, amazingly quiet and an all around fantastic place to stay. Even the owner went into town the night I was there, leaving me with the crickets, the Kudu and the baboons. The approach road was a struggle, as it goes through some shallow pools, so the only way across was to drive fast enough to make it to the other side without sinking. Perhaps it would have been easier in a 4x4? Also, when they say self-catering, it is a wise man who buys his food in Palapye before he comes: food in nearby villages is expensive and poor quality, as well as being difficult to find. Still, when the accommodation is this charming, and the walk itself is this lovely, this all becomes part of the adventure.

title: Bush Trip
text: A must stop on your bush trip itinerary...been many times over 3 decades. Plentiful game and remote so you are not overrun with neighbors as you take in the sites.

title: Moremi Gorge near Palapye
text:
Moremi Gorge is a wonderful days outing. A series of beautiful crystal clear pools leads you to the top of the gorge. Enjoy the abundant birdlife and sub-tropical foliage. No accomodation in the village but suitable for a days outing from Palapye (40km away)
Tar road all the way to Moremi village where you register at the office and pay about P40 per person. A further 8km leads to the foot of the Gorge.  The 8km is suitable for 4x4 or something a bit tougher than average car.  You can safely park at the foot of the gorge where you either hike up (not too physical) or swim through the series of pools.
A wonderful day outing.

title: Nette geführte Wanderung
text:
Die kurze geführte Wanderung in die Schlucht (rund 90 Minuten für Hin&Retour) ist interessant und empfehlenswert. 

Schöne Landschaft und gute Erklärungen vom Guide.

title: Mooie wandeltocht
text: We hebben de tocht gedaan tot en met de derde waterval. Sommige stukken zijn aardig steil en daarbij ook nog glad. De tocht duurt ongeveer anderhalf uur. Je kan ook nog een tocht van 5 uur maken. Tica heeft veel uitgelegd over vooral de flora.

title: The creator of the entire Delta
text: Obviously, the Okavango River is responsible for creating the Okavango Delta.  But the river itself is worthy of special attention because of all of the animals it draws during the dry season.  We were there in late May, at the end of the dry season before the rains came and surprising, the river really the only place where one sees water...the delta is completely dry (especially this past year).  So regardless of season, the Okavango River does not disappoint with all of the animals that it draws as well as its own natural beauty.

title: Must see
text:
Amazing pure nature, untouched and beautiful wildlife. 
Mokoros are used for transportation, pole drivers are experienced and nice.

title: Ride the boat
text: What a fun experience to take a boat safari through the delta.  Definitely recommend the opportunity as you will experience more wild life than you can imagine...

title: good adventure
text: We have a good experience in Botswana with Bush Baby Calls,,we saw many elephants,impalas,loins,hyena,rhinos and a lot of birds,it was vey good experience we will comeback in future

title: Te whole trip was fabulous
text: Amazing from the moment we stepped into the dug out canoes.  Scenery, the experience, the animals we saw and the location we were taken to for our camping adventure.  Thank-you Sunway Tours, you are amazing.

title: Elefants, Elefants, Elefants.
text: Great location to view Elephants. It is so great to see, when they run into the water and drink, play etc.

title: Beautiful area
text: Very tranquil and uncrowded. Excellent for birds especially if you have a good guide. Go in  a mokoro or small boat and in a small party so that the wildlife is not  disturbed.

title: Flora and fauna
text: This river is life for this people in this area. Always fresh fish in small local restaurants Okavango river is very good for swimming on hot days

title: "Draught"
text: The Okavango river is the main water supplier for the whole delta. Due the lack of the usual amount of rainfall during the last 2 rain seasons the amount of water is low so the wildlife is much more concentrated around the river banks then usual. Mokoro safari's are departing from much further way's in the delta as they are used to, so be aware of long drive distances to get there unless you are already staying in the neighbourhood.

title: Gorgeous
text: Gorgeous region and loads to watch. A British Summer visit has the advantage of being Botswanan winter so not too many biting insects on the river though worth covering up anyway. If you can get out on the water, this is stunning.

title: Beautiful guided walk after boat ride
text: When in the delta you should ride one of their classic boats. You're right with nature abs may doze off a hit if the sun hits you hard. Once you walk on foot you'll track elephants, hippos, zebras and wake right up!

title: Tranquil
text: Overnighting on a houseboat on the Okavango river must be considered one of the most relaxing and tranquil forms of spending a holiday. Watch the wildlife and nature slowly go past as you drift/sal down or up the river.

title: Wow - Just go and see it
text: One of the wonders of the world. You must go and see it. Concerning that long term drought affecting the delta. It makes seeing animals easier but one more negative effect of climate change. Enjoy it while you can and support the locals who are keeping this wilderness in prime condition.

title: Mokoro Ride is Awesome; Bushman's Walk is just OK...
text:
An absolutely wonderful and unique experience.  The mokomo ride through the Okavango Delta and bushman's walk was part of an itinerary designed by our travel agent and was truly one of the highlights of our 10 day trip to Botswana.  The Okavango River is absolutely beautiful.  A definite must do!

As far as the Bushman's Walk goes, the only down side was that although it was winter the sun was intense and the heat was sweltering  while we were walking (approximately 2 hours) so I can't imagine what it would be like in summer.  Just be prepared with a cap or hat to shield your face from the sun, good walking shoes and plenty of water. Fortunately, you have the option of opting out of the walk if you're not physically capable or just don't want to do it, which I would do if I did it again.  Even though we did see a lot of animals (giraffe, zebra, antelope, hippos) along the way, we had already seen them while on safari.  Several of the mokoro driver's stay back during the walk in case there are those who don't want to walk.

title: I want more!!!
text: Ive done the One Day Mokoro Trip organized by The Old Bridge.I really enjoyed the experience of being in a mokoro, enjoying that peaceful and quite time. Once on land, during the “game walking”, we saw a giraffe, many wildebeests, some elephants and many many hippos. We also learned a lot from the guide about the local fauna and flora. If i had more time, I would definitely do more days of this experience.

title: Nxamaseri River Lodge provides great access to the rive.
text: 3 hours by road, 25 minutes by plane, this Lodge is located right on the river and is accessible by boat from the landing strip or road.  Remarkable bird sitings, close, but not too close, views of hippos and crocodiles, along an idyllic remote section of river.  Also, very close to Tsodilo Hills (2 hours by "road"), wher wall paintings of ancient San people are located.  Fish, an excellent guide, leads both on river and in the Hills.

title: Okavango river vrom Divindu in Namibia to Shakawe in Botswana.
text:
This is a great stretch of river and provides opportunities for game viewing, birding and fishing. We have stayed at Drotsky's Cabins on 2 separate occasions. The camp sites are large and are close to the jetty where you are able to organize boat trips on the river.

The lodges are very comfortable and the restaurant provides excellent meals. Staff and management very accommodating. Well worth a stay if you are in the area.

photos.caption: Elephant bull on the Okavango River

title: From Shakawe to Maun
text: The river provides water to a variety of wild animals, birds and some of the wonderful indigenous plants. The water which is relatively 'clean' harbors fish species of great value.The waters allow for a great time through boat cruising and mokoro drives to experience the best of the Okavango River and tributaries of the delta.

title: Watch out for the Crocs
text: Don't be surprised if you see hippos grazing on the bank or crocs slithering along the shoreline. And the lilac breasted rollers have got to be one of the most beautiful birds in the world. But be safe. This isn't Disneyland.

title: Community Mokoro Safari Beats All
text:
We had the most fantastic Mokoro Safari in the Okovango Delta. 
The community guides were went out of their way to make our trip really special. I recommend booking directly with them as they provide an excellent value for money mokoro experience (much cheaper than the lodges or other organisers). They cater for all, individuals or large groups -   self catering or fully catered. These people deserve our support. Photos attached

For community booking contacts please e-mail maureenjrudham@gmail.com

title: beautiful place
text: The animals coming to the river to drink was amazing.  bird diversity was great.  beautiful sunset and sunrises as well.

title: Houseboat accomodation
text: As part of our tour, we took a speed boat 1.5hrs up the river to our houseboat....our accommoadtion for two nights. Saw lots of birdlife, wildlife etc and think this was one of the best ways to experience the river.

title: The Heart of the Delta
text:
I was recently in the Okavango Delta for the fourth time and have to say that the Okavango River remains as enchanting as ever. It's one place that will never bore you and you'll always want to return to. 

The birds and wildlife are simply awesome. The sunsets are just outstanding.

title: Lots of animals
text: I did a sunset cruise on the river saw lots of animals. Hippies, crocodile, elephants and birds. The guide did some explaining but over all the river was relaxing and sunset was great

title: Amazing!
text: Make sure you stay overnight here.  It is an experience you will never have again. Sunset and sunrise here will stay with you forever.

title: Wonderful experience
text: Took an evening cruise, saw lots of elephants on the shore and browsing in the marshes. Felt sometimes that some of the boats are too intrusive and disturbed the animals. The hippos were also floating amongst the reeds and several crocus basking on the shore. Good section of bird life.

title: Mokoro-dug out canoe
text: The journey took us about 1 and a half to 2 hours. Our local poler-the person who steered us through the rivers of the Okavango did a great job of getting us to the island camp. He pointed out small white frogs clinging to the reeds and many other wildlife and birds along the way. This was such a relaxing way to travel. AMAZING.....

title: Okavango delta
text: I honestly love our Thamalakane river. It's beautiful and you just can't tired of its beauty. Watch out for the hippopotamus and crocodiles now and then.

title: 1 NIGHT STAY
text: We were a group of 6 people travelling to the Delta where we camped for one night in one of the island in the Okavango Delta. On the arrival we did a mokoro trip for 1 hour 30 minutes to our camping area where we took a shower and a cup of tea then we did a walking safari for 2 hours on the late afternoon where we came across a herds of breeding elephants, Hippo, and the herds of wildebeests together with the birds like an African data, Jacana, Heron and the White Great egret, and went back to the camp where after supper the residents performed some dance which was interesting.

title: Take a boat trip on the River from Drotskys Camp
text: Dont miss this, it is amazing. The guides are really good and the river trip a must do! You can also do a bit of Tiger fishing...what fun!

title: Holidays
text: One of the wonders of the world a place for a nature lover to visit with out a doubt. Travel by 4 x 4 and camp along the river in camps provided

title: Mokoro
text:
Fantastic experience taking a Mokoro canoe through the delta area. We were first on a fast boat, then put in to a mokoro and guided up the river. We saw a variety of wildlife including hippos and elephants plus tiny frogs, and a variety of birds. 

It was a unique experience and so much fun. We had a short walking safari on land and lunch before returning to the boat launching area.

title: Lourens De Jager
text: Okavango is the only river that starts in Angola and never reaches the sea, but ends up in the Okavango delta. A must to see. Abundance of bird and wild life. Most beautiful sunsets and what is better than a nice sundowner on this river. Beautiful lodges all along the banks of the river and no other place to find peace and just appreciate nature. A must to experience!!!

title: Awesome, did a mokoro boat trip
text: We spend 4 days in the park and did a mokoro boat trip in the far north-west of the park. Bring loads of water during the dry season. It was over 40 degrees. Great for bird watching!

title: The best ever experience!
text: We assembled at the old bridge backpackers for a cruise up the river on the south side of the Delta. It was an experience of a lifetime! Threre were five os us in our party and we enjoyed a 2 hour jaunt up the Delta with a very knowledgable skipper. We took masses of photos of wildlife and viewed the most spectacular African sunset. The cost was a mere P120 per head.

title: beautiful view
text: The Okavango river has its sources in Angola. The best way to explore the river is to take a mokoro boat ride. For those who can afford it, you can choose to take a flight to the middle of the delta.

title: A Boat cruise with African Secrets Safari company
text: Serene wonderful beauty, Enjoyed every minute. Thank you Island Safari lodge for recommending this activity during our stay.

title: A Fantastic trip on the Okavango River
text:
Our 6 days on the Okavango River with Okavango River Safaris was one of the high-lights of my life!  
We have lived in and travelled Southern Africa for 50 years and rate Okavango River Safaris owned and run by Jacques Conradie as amongst, if not the best.
We have just returned from a six day Okavango Delta river safari experience which I find hard to describe - words cannot express this experience.
We left Maun at about 10h30 - had a wonderful lunch on an island that Ace [our guide] found - saw lots of ellies, hippos, buffalo and bird life, arriving at the camp site at about 18h00 where, Jacques, Mush and David were just finishing erecting the tents and Jackie was just finishing getting his 'kitchen' sorted out.
The boat was extremely comfortable [large enough to accommodate 9 passengers with ease], and had both a large canopy and ports for charging batteries - cameras etc.  Also on board was a large cooler box filled to the brim.

There followed 5 absolutely fantastic days.  The camp site, on the banks of the Okavango within the Moremi Game Reserve was wonderful - we only saw one other boat, twice - department of water affairs - and not another sole for the whole of our stay. 
Reasonable size tents, very comfy beds, outdoor loo [with a decent loo seat] and a shower right behind each tent - almost on-suite, a basin and mirror alongside the tent. 
 Most meals were in camp - breakfast and dinner under the open sky while most lunch was set up under a gazebo.  Other lunches were on islands and one actually in the water [table & chairs - swim, sit, eat, splash!].  The food served was absolutely fantastic - full breakfasts; lunches, one hot dish and a variety of cold meats dishes and salads with daily freshly baked bread, cheese and biscuits;  dinners - three course and the best deserts one could get in a 5 star restaurant!
Days started with cereal & fruit, then a walk [saw quite a bit of game], back to camp for a full breakfast, then out on the boat until lunch time [or later if lunch was thus organised], after an afternoon zzzzzzzzz out on the boat again ending with sunset drinks and snacks before returning to camp for more drinks & snacks around the fire, lots of chatting, then dinner and bed were we lay listening to the lions roaring [every night - one night they passed next to the camp], ellies, [actually had them in camp the one morning], hippo's and a myriad of night birds calling.  The nights were fantastic.
 The days on the river - no words can describe the beauty of the surroundings, palm trees, enormous groves of trees,  the clarity of the water [can see every grain of sand, every plant and stem on the water base - crystal clear water], the hundreds of water lilies and other water plants the thousands of water birds [and land birds].  Many, many ellies both on land and in the water, just as many hippo's, croc's, letchwe, buffalo, impala, giraffe, wildebeest etc.  
Our guide and host, Ace was not only one of the most knowledgeable guides that we have ever been out with, but also one of the best hosts we have had on similar trips.  In fact, all the staff were fantastic.
The 'pictures in my mind' of these five days will live forever.

title: Great day out
text: Highly recommend going to chief island far Maun although it is a full day trip. We did not see much on the island itself but we saw a lot on the trip there! Hippos and elephants - yay! Bit chili in the morning so wear a jacket !

title: Great trip
text: Unfortunately the fishing was bad but evidently out of season and gill netting by the locals.still need to get a tiger fish

title: Okavango River
text: This river forms a life supporting delta that attracts countless varieties of wildlife and therefore safari guests.  An ideal time to visit is their winter when temperatures are comfortable and there is water from recent rains to support browse for the animals

title: Definitely add to your bucket list
text: I did a scenic flight and this is just breath taking and well worth doing.  I saw plenty animals including Lion, Rhino and plenty others.

title: Tiger fishing, Mokoro and sunset cruise
text: We enjoyed so many unique and fun adventures on the Okavango River.  We would especially recommend going Tiger Fishing, as well as going on a mokoro trip.

title: Quite a trip
text: A great trip throug the Moremi Wildlife Reserve to the main Okavango River. So quit and so peaceful. On our way towards the river we saw elephants, giraffe, baboons, zebra, etc etc..... Just before we ended our boat trip an elephant crossed the river. So nice.....

title: Spectacular!
text:
The Okavango river is one of the most impressive and beautiful rivers I've ever been to.

The amount of wildlife and birds that you get to see when exploring it is simply remarkable.

Unmissable!

title: MOKORO TRIP CAN BE DONE CHEAPLY.
text:
HOW TO DO IT? 

You can easily bypass he exorbitant prices offered by the lodges and agencies. 
The standard price range offered by providers is 680-900p (68 - 90USD). 

If we (a couple) did our overnight trip with our lodge, we would have paid 360USD. 
Instead we paid 70 USD.

Instead of going with intermediaries, we went straight to Okawango Kopano Mokoro Community Trust, paid 6.8USD pppd (per person per day) fee. Next day we picked up one of their emploees in our car. He showed us the way to Mokoro Village. We were introduced to a poler there, whom we paid 20 USD per day per group, another 5 USD for having our car looked after and 2 USD pppd for mokoro seat rental :). 

You will find OKMCT easily, it is in the same yard as the Helicopter Horizons (marked on google maps). 

In terms of revenue, we left much more cash with the community, than we would have if we went with an agency (we would have done only a day trip for their price). The agency pays mokoro polers the 20 usd per day per group and your entry fee. The rest is transfer, in some cases food, and above all, a huge profit margin. 

IS IT WORTH IT? 

The no-intermediary price- definitely yes. 
360 USD- not really... 

If you've been to Caprivi Strip, you'd have done something similar, but having seen loads of hippos, crocs, buffaloes... Here the area is huge, reeds are dense, wildlife is scattered. We saw zebras and ostriches and only heard the hippos. 
Sleeping in the wilderness, the sky full of stars, the mokoro ride itself - a beautiful experience, but for a long term traveler, definitely not worth 180 USD PP.

title: Okavango is a big deal
text:
Okavango river is a major river in that it flows to the Delta that creates flooding in March and June to feed the water starved wildlife of these huge reserves in Botswana and Namibia. 

Reaching the mouth of the Okavango in the North, we took a Mokoro boat (traditional dug-out canoe )ride to a lower down in the panhandle of the Delta.  We enjoyed the tranquility of the river.  And birdlife is prolific: egrets, Saddle-billed Stork, cranes, Scarlet-crested sunbirds to name a few.  Although we did not see much game, the boat ride was peaceful and zen like.

title: African sunset that takes your breath away
text: If you want magic, then take a boat an enjoy a magnificent afternoon to this overwhelming River  watching an African sunset that will take your breath away. Bonus, you will have the opportunity to observe the life of the peasants living on the shores.

title: Stunning
text: Stunning sunset.The population density is so low in Botswana, that you will see a lot more wildlife than people!

title: Do a mokoro trip!
text: I can recommend the river full heartedly it's a wildlife gem. I must say it's the most relaxing way of travel I had in my life with mokoros .

title: Amazing reserve where elephants play daily in the River
text: We wrapped up our 10 day vacation in Botswana at the Serondela Reserve in Chobe and what a way to wrap up!  The Serondela Reserve put on its best show for us and we loved every moment of it....lions with their young, elephants playing in the river and boatrides past hippos cooling themselves in the shallow waters before turning around and warming themselves on the banks of the river.  All this and amazing sunsets too!  Definitely a highlight of our trip and we can't wait to return.

title: Amazing wildlife
text: This is an amazing reserve with a wonderful range of wildlife, all looking very healthy. Things are very dry this year but it's a fantastic place for a visit.

title: Incredible!
text:
We had previously been to Kruger and Sabi Sand in South Africa, which we all loved.  In comparison, the herds of animals we saw here were much, much larger.  Additionally, the river provided rich and varied experiences.

We visited here on a guided overnight trip.  While we did see private vehicles, I would not recommend it.  The terrain is NOT suited to cars, and the reserve is so big, I don't know how you would know where to go.

The huge herds of elephants, hippos, cape buffalo, etc were incredible.  We also saw a group of 3 lions one day, and a group of 4 the next.  Let's not forget the absolutely magnificent leopard!

This park is incredibly sandy, and we saw both private cars and a tour jeep stuck in it.  The roads are also incredibly bumpy - like I was seriously glad I had on a sports bra; I would think twice about this if you have back issues.  The dust and heat combine to make you filthy; our one night of camping was enough - we loved it, but were super excited for a shower at the end of it.  I would not wear contacts with all that dust, either; even if you don't wear glasses, you might want to wear sunglasses while the vehicle is moving.

Vehicles must stay on the road here.  Please bring binoculars and a real camera (not your cellphone camera) for a much, much better experience.

title: Beautiful on land and sea
text:
When I first thought about visiting Chobe National Park in Botswana, I saw all of the wonderful safaris and campsites/lodges available deeper in the park. Unfortunately staying over night and spending more than a day was not going to be possible.

Luckily, the day trip taken from Livingstone with Bushtracks Africa was available and so that was booked. 

Wow!!! If that was just a sample then I can imagine how wonderful the longer safari trips could be.
This was a land/water day trip. We entered through the Sedudu gate near Kasana and drove on in. The red sand is beautiful as are the trees. 

We started off by spotting a group of mongoose followed by impala. Those things you can't miss. They're everywhere. There's Kudu, buffalo, giraffes, elephants too and eventually a sleepy lion. In the distance we spotted a gorgeous sable antelope but it stayed away. 

After having lunch at the Chobe Safari Lodge, we cruised around the river nearby and there we spotted even more wildlife but some were a lot closer - like crocodiles, water buck, buffalo, and even some birds too. There was a nice group of elephants that decided to cross the river in front of us so many boats stayed around to watch.

Want birds? The beautiful lilac breasted roller, the little bee eater, a variety of hornbills, spoonbill, ibis, the African Eagle, as well as Goliath Heron and plenty of others can be found here. If you take a day trip, be sure to ask your guide to point out some birds because they really are gorgeous. 

If i came back to Botswana, I would definitely visit Chobe again and most likely for an overnight to experience sunrise, sunset, and all the parts between!

title: Plenty of Wildlife!
text: Been there 5 times in the past few years, and it disappoint again last week. We saw so many elephants, as well as a brown hyena and a leopard! Really cool day driving around the park!

title: The place to be and great animal sightings
text:
When we all do Botswana, we have the urge that Chobe/Serondela is just an entry point and the real places to go to are Savute, Linyanti and Moremi. I was wrong - Serondela had a lot to offer.

All the animal sightings are pretty much on the river front drive. Saw the Big 4 of the 5 (no chance of Leopards) and saw lots of Lions. The Chobe riverfront is beautiful and you must do a couple of boat trips - ideally an early morning and a sunset cruise. Not many places offer you the chance to see animals from the "other side" of the water.

The plus side of Serondela is that you could stay in the park or keep it cheaper and drive in from Kasane each day.

Great park, very convenient and great animal sightings on a single, not too challenging road. Only downside is that there is a fair amount of traffic from all the lodges at prime sightings.

title: Parking arrangements attrocious
text: We used the parking arrangements as per their website and instructions. I asked their representative if it was safe.  All three of our vehicles was broken into. Afterwards my guides found out that they could have made much safer arrangements. This is very suspect.

title: THE place to see the wildlife
text: I don't think there is an animal in this part of Africa that we haven't seen in the Chobe National park. Large families of elephants, prides of lions (one of them devouring recently hunted buffalo), buffalos, impalas, kudus, hippos, crocodiles, baboons, variety of birds etc, even a black mamba. While self-drive is an option, I would say that one needs a good guide to take the most out of it - our guide Laki from Chobe Bekwani was fantastic - very passionate and knowledgeable about local wildlife, he was even able to find a massive pride of lions followings their tracks. Overall, would highly recommend spending a few nights in a neighbouring lodge (we stayed in Chobe Bekwani, and it was a real treat) and to go on game drives as well as on a Chobe river boat tour. Also, Botswana is a very welcoming country, people are genuinely nice, friendly and relaxed.

title: National Geographic in real life
text:
We came here our last full day in Africa and were amazed at the number and variety of animals we saw. There were herds of elephants nearly every 20 minutes or so--some just crossing the road, others crammed under the shade of a tree, taking a bath along the side of the road, or enjoying a mud bath along the shores of the Chobe. The river supports large herds of animals, including Cape buffalo, impala, hippos, giraffes, and of course, many elephants.

The highlight of our day was seeing a pride of lions feeding on an elephant (our guide told us it had died of natural causes). There were about 6 lions patrolling what they considered their kill. Two jackals and a few vultures tried in vain to share their spoils, but they were chased away by the lions. It was as if we were watching a nature documentary, but only about 100 yards from the scene. This was one of the most exciting sights of our entire trip, which included 8 safari drives in Kruger.

We ended the day with a river cruise, where we saw many beautiful exotic birds and animals grazing on the island in the Chobe River. Chobe had a greater abundance of animals than Kruger (though we loved our time there), so if you're in the area, make it a point to visit.

We arranged the safari with our guesthouse in Livingstone, Zambia and were driven from Livingstone (45 minutes) to the border of Botswana. A 5-minute boat ride across the river will get you to your guide, who then drives you into Chobe. This was one of the best days of our African adventure and well worth the time and expense.

photos.caption: herd of impala grazing along the Chobe River
African skimmer, a rare endangered bird

title: River Safari A Must
text: The guide here was outstanding, showing hidden birds, snakes, and hippos.  Two hours was just about the right time on the boat.  We saw some hippos head off an attack from a croc.

title: A can not miss!!!
text:
We rushed a bit through this park, we only spend 4 hours in it, but still we got to see much more wildlife than we had expected – such a good surprise!    

But the park deserves more time than that, you should schedule a whole day (at least) for it!

title: Favorite game park
text:
After visiting 5 parks in Southern Africa, this was my favorite. Spent the morning on a "river" safari. We had a "birder" in our group and he thought he was in "heaven". He was able to identify more birds in this three hour river safari than his whole previous two weeks!! Fun to observe animals on the islands and in the water especially the hippos, crocs and elephants.
Afternoon was a land safari where we saw many more animals that 3 days in Kruger Park. 5 mins into the park we came across a leopard. This was during the heat of the day when cats are usually hard to find. Also sighted three lions. Of course, the elephants were everywhere...literally hundreds at a time. 
The ride is a little rough, so be prepared....but so worth it!!

title: Wow
text: Chobe is a must see and easily accessible from livingstone in Zambia. We saw buffalo, elephants, lions, warthogs, hippos, giraffes, baboons, and much more. The guides were excellent and the tour was top notch. Incredible safari experience!!!!!!!!

title: Feast for the eyes
text:
Great Reserve, beautiful setting.
Lovely lion sightings and beautiful view points over the Chobe River. Only thing spoiling it was GP registration cars! Too many vehicles at sightings.

title: Loved This Place!
text: I truly think this is the greatest safari experience in Africa.  The setting, the guides, the proliferation of flora and fauna are spectacular.  The lodges range from budget (well may that's an oxymoron...they're all pricey) to extravagant.  We chose the "mid-level" and they were quite beautiful and sumptuous. It's best to air-hop and spend a few days at different locations to really experience this place.  you travel in open jeeps which, at first, is very unsettling as the animals are just yards away and hard to believe they won't attack you (unless you stand up).  We did have a little run in with a leopard while he was having dinner...don't do that.

title: Incredible number of animals
text: The Serondela Reserve is part of the Chobe river front of Chobe NP. It is easy to access (especially if compared to the rest of Chobe NP) and provides the best wildlife experience that I ever had so far. A must do if you are in the Kasane Region.

title: Elephant city
text:
You want to see Africa's endangered elephants? Then don't go to Serondela. They only have non-endangered elephants - plagues of them. They claim there are 120,000 elephants but I think that figure is wrong because we probably saw that many in Serondela alone.

A pretty part of the park with a good diversity of wildlife. It is popular though so can get a bit crowded. For example, if you see predators you'll probably have to share it with 20 other vehicles. On the up side, your elephant encounters will be intimate.

Enjoyed it a lot and would highly recommend Serondela.

title: Elephants & Hippos
text: This watery paradise on the Chobe River, was home to many, elephants, hippos and water buffalo. It was great to see the elephants walking across the river to get to the grazing areas on the other side, with trunks in the air like snorkel, groups went over under the watchful eyes of sunning Nile crocodiles. Stunning

title: No disappointment here
text: If you want elephants, you will see plenty here. Along with hippos, crocodiles, warthogs, impalas, and more. The river cruise is far more interesting as you can see how much the animals love water.  You can also see just how fast elephants can swim.

title: Loved this intimate lodge
text: Wow, we checked into the lodge not knowing what to expect and wanted to stay forever. This lodge only hosts a possibility of 8 people- there were 6 the whole time we were there. That means that when you go our for game drives ,you get to see the animals right up close and personal. The food at the lodge was delicious ( I recommended tot he cook he write a cookbook ) and plentiful. You can't beat this place.

title: More elephants than you can imagine
text: The mama elephants keep the babies in the middle of the herd, a bit hard to get a clear photo shot. Fortunately, our guide knows when an elephant is about to act up. We have kept at safe distance through out.

title: Superbe endroit
text:
Que dire du LUXE, pas de BLING BLING, savourez l'instant présent au Serondela Lodge, la quiétude de l'endroit et ses animaux qui passent devant vous !
Nous voilà revenus en France, après notre petit périple Namibie Zimbabwe et Botswana, mais nous aurons un souvenir du lieu, agrémenté de la chaleur du propriétaire (qui parle français) pour nous expliquer la vie namibienne et autres.

Merci à Bénédicte de AFRICA UNDER CANVAS, de nous avoir fait connaître cet endroit

Philippe

photos.caption: Un vieil éléphant que n'a plus de molaires pour se nourrir dans le BUSH !

title: 動物の楽園
text: 本当に最高の国立公園です。たくさんの象にライオン、そのほかの動物たち。とにかく何でも見られるといってしまってもいいかもしれません。4WDでガイドさんとまわれます。

title: Splendida Botswana
text: E' stata una esperienza diversa dalle altre zone dell'Africa (Namibia - Sudafrica - Kenia ) e sicuramente molto più interessante. Eravamo in 4 ed avevamo tutto a nostra disposizione. Siamo stati fortunati perchè più volte abbiamo visto i famosi  "big five" che non a tutti è dato vedere. Lo consiglio a tutti anche se in verità è un viaggio un po' costoso.

title: Ein toller Park mit unzähligen Tieren
text:
Wir - zwei Frauen - hatten gelesen, dass nur 75 Selbstfahrer am Tag in den Chobe Park kommen und erst ab 09:00 Uhr. Allerdings waren uns die angebotenen Touren zu teuer - ab 4 Personen 100€. Nur 4 Personen finden sich nicht. Die meisten fahren selbst durch den Chobe Park. Also haben wir auch unser Glück probiert. 

Wir waren 08:00 Uhr am Sidudu Gate und sind problemlos - mit 4x4 - rein gekommen. Der Eintritt für 2 Personen und KfZ kostete 290 Pula. Die Riverfront ist eine Einbahnstraße. Streckenweise verläuft sie auch zweispurig, so dass Gegenverkehr kein Problem ist. Mit unserem Mietwagen sind wir als absolute Anfänger gut die Riverfront entlang gefahren - 4H war ausreichend. Wir haben jede Menge Tiere gesehen: Paviane, Elefanten, Vögel, sogar Löwen aus etwas weiterer Entfernung, Antilopen/ Böcke und Nilpferde. 
Wir sind bis zur Serondela Picnic Site gefahren. Nachdem die Tiere immer weniger worden, wollten wir den Ausgang Richtung Natanga nehmen. Der Weg war okay - streckenweise hatte ich dennoch 4L eingestellt. Irgendwann kam ein etwas sandiger leicht steiler Anstieg, den haben wir uns nicht getraut zu nehmen. Wir haben gewendet und wollten den Ausgang über die upper road nehmen. Katastrophe. Auch dieser Weg war machbar, jedoch schmal und zugewachsen. Nonstop sind Äste am Auto entlang geschliffen und die Äste haben uns die Spiegel umgeklappt. Übrigens sind beide Wege von absoluter Einsamkeit geprägt. Wenn etwas passiert, ist man völlig auf sich allein gestellt. Also haben wir nochmals gewendet und sind wieder Richtung Riverfront gefahren. Kurz vor der Riverfront sind wir doch noch im Sand stecken geblieben - einfach aus Unkonzentriertheit nach den vorangegangen Versuchen alternative Ausfahrten zu nehmen. Aber in der Nähe der Riverfront war das kein Problem. Dort fahren genügend Guide Touristen durch den Park, die uns geholfen haben. Der Ausgang an der Riverfront verläuft parallel zur Einbahnstraße  bzw. gabelt sich die Einbahnstraße auch ab und an in zwei Wege.

An der Riverfront an sich sind wir 2 - 2,5 Stunden bis zur Serondela Picnic Site gefahren. Die Routen sind im Park ausgeschildert. Man findet sich also gut zurecht. Eine bekannte App maps-.. zeigt auch alle Routen innerhalb der Parks an. Es war als Anfänger kein Problem die Riverfront entlang zu fahren und den parallel verlaufenden Weg Richtung Ausgang zu fahren. Traut Euch. Alles machbar - auch für Anfänger - solange man nicht Richtung Natanga fährt oder die upper road nimmt.

title: Te sientes inmerso en un mundo lejano, perteneciente a los animales de cuentos
text: Cada día, con frío pero bien abrigados, nos subimos al coche para ser conducidos hacia adentro del Parque, y nos quedamos en silencio frente a la belleza del lugar y con anticipación de lo que nos traería de aventura el nuevo día.  No nos fuimos decepcionados en ningún excursión, y de lo contrario, cada salida nos sorprendimos, maravillados con encuentros cercanos con los animales (demasiados para nombrar acá) y aves de abundante variedad. Al contemplar los animales y aves de bien cerca, con un guía profesional que además supo de cada detalle de la naturaleza, fuimos plenamente inmersos en la naturaleza pero desde la seguridad y comodidad del vehículo. El viaje en bote que permitió observar a los animales desde el río nos dejó con avistamiento de docenas de "Carmine Bee Eaters" en un árbol, cosa que jamás olvidaré, más cocodrilos, hipopótamos, leones, búfalo, y aves de toda variedad.  Fue un cuento hecho realidad. Recalco la belleza del paisaje y de cada animal.  Lejos lo más lindo que he visto.

photos.caption: Elefantes bajando al río al atardecer.
El Río Chobe, un paseo de tranquilidad para ver paisajes bellas
Refrescándose en el pozo - entre babuines, girafas, cebras y antilopes

title: Parco fantastico struttura deplorevole
text: Faccio una premessa.. il punteggio basso che ho dato al parco non è relativo ai paesaggi, alla natura nella quale è immerso o agli animali avvistabili.. fantastici.. ma alla struttura (campsite ihaha)fatiscente, sporca,trasandata, e non curata. Il personale passa il tempo in ufficio a fare giochi con il telefonino.. mentre sarebbero da svuotare i bidoni delle immondizie che vengono prodotte dai turisti per evitare che le scimmie disperdano i sacchetti nel Bush. L'acqua calda era insufficiente, non ci sono mappe dettagliate dei percorsi effettuabili e nessun tipo di servizio minimo. Ora... il tutto diventa inaccettabile se viene richiesto un pagamento giornaliero di 30 dollari solo per entrare nel parco e di 40 dollari a testa per pernottare in piazzole inadeguate.In ultimo aggiungo che viaggiamo da anni in Africa.. e tutt'ora la stiamo attraversando con la macchina di nostra  proprietà.. questo solo per dire che non si tratta della lamentela sterile di una persona abituata al valtur.. ma di viaggiatori che conoscono piuttosto bene il continente e che sanno adeguarsi. La presa in giro e l'approfittarsi delle situazioni .. e' altra cosa però

title: El paraíso de los Elefantes
text: El mejor Safari que he hecho por Africa. El recorrido en barco por el río Chobe es una maravilla. Relajado, con una vistas excelentes y plagado de animales, especialmente elefantes que disfrutan a lo grande en el fango de las islas que hay en el río. También hay muchos búfalos, hipopótamos, cocodrilos, jirafas, cebras, impalas y uno que me encantó, el aguila africana.

title: sin ninguna duda el mejor safari que he hecho en mi vida
text: llegué a Chobe después de visitar varios países en Africa y ver muchos animales pero no me podía creer la suerte que tuve al poder hacer un crucero de un día alrededor de la isla de Bostwana de Sedudo. Pude ver hipos, elefantes, bufalos, impalas y cocodrilos como si estuvieran a dos metros de mí

title: tanto poco famoso quanto bello
text:
Ho visitato parchi in Namibia, in Sud Africa, in Kenya. Il Chobe è il più selvaggio di tutti. Lontano dalle rotte turistiche, più affollate, ti permette di vedere gli animali in completa solitudine. Da visitare esclusivamente con un mezzo 4x4 efficiente. Le condizioni delle piste sono peggiori che nel Kruger e nel Etosha.  Anche i panorami sono favolosi.
Unico neo appunto le condizioni delle piste.

title: Parco bellisimo e forse unico
text: Prima di vistare il parco Chobe eravamo stati in Sudafrica al Kruger; molto bello, ma nel confronto con il Chobe non c'è gara. Al Chobe abbiamo visto moltissimi animali: leoni, leopardi, elefanti, giraffe, zebre, impala, kudu, ippopotami, coccodrilli, bufali, facoceri, sciacalli oltre a tantissimi uccelli multicolori. Uno dei pochi animali che al Chobe non è presente è il rinoceronte. Consigliatissimo.

title: elefanti, leoni, leopardi dappertutto!!!
text: Il parco del Chobe è davvero spettacolare, Contraraiemnte ad altri parchi Africani più conosciuti non c'è molto traffico sulle strade, le jeep non si incolonnano mai e il numero di animali che si vedono supera l'immaginazione. Abbiamo visto di tutto: dagli impala ai leopardi, ed un numero impressionanate di leoni ed elefanti.

title: Mängder med djur som man kommer riktigt nära
text: Game drives i gryningen var fantastiska, med perfekt fotoljus, gott om orädda djur som var aktiva och nyfikna

title: Safari à Serondela sur la rivière Chobe
text:
Serondela est une place de pique-nique dans la zone nord du parc national de Chobe.
Nous avons fait un tour en bateau sur la rivière depuis Kasane, puis parcouru la zone nord et la zone de Savuti en safari privé. C'était simplement magnifique: éléphants, girafes, hippopotames, lions, léopards, crocodiles...
Il y a nettement plus de monde dans la zone nord, et moins dans la zone de Savuti. Dans les deux zones, ça vaut vraiment le coup de partir avec un guide avec radio: ils se communiquent les belles rencontrent, et gèrent le trafic pour éviter les embouteillages. Et bien sûr c'est un gros avantage d'avoir un 4x4 ouvert plutôt qu'une auto de location fermée!

title: Absolutely worth a visit.
text: Beautiful National Park, spread out over thousands of hectares. The drive through the park is beautiful and the area around the Boteti river is truly gorgeous- a miniature Serengeti plain, so to speak- with hundreds of animals- zebra, antilope, elephants, hippos, crocodiles, vultures, pelicans and other water birds, etc.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Overnight on the Kalahari
text: ISAAC is a remarkable guide. He knows the animals and the stars. incredible evening. We had stayed in Le Too le Tau and safaried out to the salt pan.  Incredible evening of food, music, and stars.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: It was awful
text:
I actually stopped at a nearby lodge on route north to show my family the pans. Nature is predictable so the fact that the pans were very full and very little opportunity to actually get close to them is nobody’s fault. But it was the case. We had no place to park or just sit and enjoy the pans. No birds in sight.
The disappointment was that we were told at the gate that a lot of “locals” were inside. There was one look out point and there were probably 50 people there. It was a massive party of people falling over themselves with bottles of alcohol in hand. It was such a disappointment as we were made to feel unwelcome and unsafe. We left. So in and out of the pans in less than an hour. P300 poorer and we can claim we have seen Sowa Pan. Not a pleasant experience at all.

We saw some Wildebeest, which you can see anywhere.
I will never go back to the Bird Sanctuary, but if you go, then go in the week as I assume weekends are reserved for parties.
Last I was there it was February 2019, less summer rain and in the week. Lots less people, less water and a lot more birds.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: True African experience
text: Until you have been there you will not be able to understand what is so special about this place. I’ve seen it bone dry where you see kilometres of flat sand and I’ve seen it looking like a brown ocean. Both are special and it is totally worth stopping off for a visit. Beware the sand! It may look dry but you are likely to get stuck!

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Great spot. For the landscape. Less for wildlife viewing
text: The landscape itself is the highlight here. Ofcourse you get to see quite a bit of animals, but in those 4 days we didn't get to see any cats for exemple, so it's no Moremi or Chobe.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: A must see experience.
text:
These are one of the largest salt pans in the world.
It was our first jeep excursion during this trip. We saw so many different animals just driving and walking through the pan. At one point we got stuck in the salty sand and another jeep of our group pulled us out. Even though I have gotten stuck with a jeep before (in Dubai): What an experience this was for my wife! You should definitely come here and bring a lot of time and a camera!!!
