title: Salt Pan
text: San Camp is on the edge of the salt pan, so it was an extraordinary visit on many counts.  The size of the pan is amazing and very interesting.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: When you book it, make sure that the organiser is familiar with  Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
text:
We have booked a trip to Makgadikgadi Salt Pan with Pastor Maswanganyi from Swangs safaris as a part of our 10 day tour from Johannesburg to Victoria Falls. In the program we were promised ‘the opportunity to spend some time in the company of the local meerkat colony’.  When we have arrived to Nata lodge from where our tour should start, we were told by the local guide that we will not see the meerkat colony, because it’s 500 km away, and we will not see the sunset, which is Nata speciality, also, because the time the tour was booked for was too early. 

We have learnt a bitter lesson not to trust tour organisers and check everything. Now we also know that we need to go to Planet Baobab to see the meerkats of Makgadikgadi Salt Pan, which we will definitely do during our next trip to Botswana!

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Flat land perfect desert!
text: What an experience, wild, flat and inhospitable but seen from a quad bike with night falling, open fires, a BBQ on the sand and a night under the stars (and the clearest, brightest night sky I have ever seen) made this a truly unforgettable experience of Africa at its very best. Just go.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Great day on the flats
text: We spent a day with our guide driving around this park.  saw lots of animals and amazing other worldly vistas.  Giant, ancient  Baobobs and a cobra were highlites

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Serene vastness
text: I was a bit sceptical about this visit as it was a break from the wildlife. I couldn't have been more wrong. Seeing the sun set and rise over these flat, stark landscape was stunning. The curvature of the earth adds to the feeling of the vastness of the pan.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: our visit to the salt pans
text: this is  truly one of the most amazing places on earth . Our Guide Oyapu took us for both early morning and night drives on the vast expanse of just white salt for miles in every direction . The night views were stunning with clear views of the milky way and millions of stars ! Our guide was very knowledgeable and the sundowner or night downer was a great way to end the evening !!

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Eerie, remote and loved it
text: The Makgadikgadi Salt Pans are an absolutely phenomenal habitat that hugely differs from Botswana's immediate surrounds. Seeing the change from small shrubby tree to seemingly endless plains of light yellow grass where cows, horses, donkeys, and native birds abound was beautiful. We travelled from Mmatshumo at the start of the wet season and would only recommend this route if you have a sturdy 4X4. We camped on Kubu Island which is absolutely worth exploring if you're already headed out this way.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Views from the air are absolutely amazing
text:
We flew from Gweta over the Makgadikgadi Pans via Khubu Island to Francistown.
The views of the pans from the air is absolutely spectacular. 
It appears like a massive and endless white beach as the light illusions make the horizon appear blue in colour on a clear day.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Amazing Experience
text: Sleeping on the pans was truly unforgettable. Quad bikes and BBQ dinner included. Truly once in a lifetime!

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: The big expanse of the Makgadigadi
text: Travelling across the Magadigadi always brings much excitement as can almost see the curvature of the earth. One also realise how insignificant one is in such ancient surroundings. Love it!

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Extraordinary experience
text: Although this salt pan dims in comparison to the white salt pan in Bolivia, this salt pan with its brownish white salt crust has its own attraction. We were fortunate to spend a night on the salt pan at full moon.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Stredges for hundreds of miles
text: This pan, which you can cross by car or squad is the result of natures whimps million years ago. It's a giant salt pan stredging for hundreds of square miles.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Vast expanse of nothingness
text: Fascinating area - totally flat and grey with a fine layer of salt crust over the dry mud. Not much wildlife save for a few ostriches but a great place to experience a truly wild place. It is even better at night; with no light pollution the stars are fantastic. Astonishing.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Adventure for the not so afint heatted
text:
Khumaga wilderness camp
This camp is in the Makgadigadi pans, and you have to cross the Boteti River to reach it. They have only camping sites, without any electricity.
Ablutions are clean and have electricity.
Costs are a bit expensive as you have to pay for camping as well as Park fees

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Life changing
text: The walk across these salt pans is a highlight of my life. An unforgettable experience that challenged my sense of survival. Total peace and wide skies.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Peaceful under a vast canopy of sky
text:
The drive out onto the pans at sunset was a magical experience as the sky darkened from blue into pinks and golds. The pans stretched out for miles around us.

As soon as the sun was gone the biting cold crept in.  You'll need several layers of clothes, warm jacket, and a warm hat.  With these and the cosy fire and a plentiful and tasty BBQ dinner you'll be able to relax in your deck chair and admire the huge canopy of stars. It was peaceful and quiet.  A chance to get away from everything else.

We were provided with very comfortable beds - they each had a waterproof canvas outer, and inside was a thick mattress, sheets, warm duvet and a hot water bottle (with water heated up on the camp fire). Lovely.  I didn't get cold at all during the night.

There was a breakfast of hot tea and muffins, which was served at dawn around the fire.

We did this tour of the salt pans from Planet Baobab.  It was almost a 2 hour, bumpy drive in a 4WD from there. We didn't see a lot of animals along the way but saw several birds.  

A top highlight was the visit to the meerkats  Amazing experience to be able to get so close to them and walk alongside them as they made their way back to their den.  They were aware of us but seemed not to be bothered by our presence. After that, it was a short quad bike ride for around 15 minutes on the salt pans.  Two people per quad bike, which is not ideal for safety.  However, you can stay in the 4WD vehicle if you wish. Bring a scarf to cover your mouth and nose from the dust while on the bikes.

Don't miss this trip.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Meerkats
text: we loved the meerkats. It is amazing to meet the guy who got them habituated to people without ever feeding them. our kids loved the quad biking experience.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: One of the top spots of our Botswana trip
text: We loved the trip to the salt pan so much, a sundowner in the middle of the pan, total silence, no lights, no disturbance, you need to do the trip if you happen to be in the area. It seems that Jacks Camp also offers overnight stays during winter, this would be a good reason to come back.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: If you are near you must go and sleep on the Pan
text:
Our travel agents booked through Gweta Lodge, which was where we set off from. We stopped a couple of times on route to look at boabao trees, termite mounds and meerkats. All were interesting but nothing compared to the pan. 

It was the most surreal experience. Sat there in the vast nothingness, waiting for the sunset sipping a beer. There were just three of us and a staff of 4! so we really felt we had a vast area to ourselves. I think it would be different with a bigger group (certainly noiseier). Sleeping without a tent under big african skies was truly memorable. I have never seen as many stars. 

If you are anywhere near this part of Botswana go on a trip that lets you sleep on the pan (not all do). It was worth every penny.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Good national park - worth a visit
text: We visited the Park while staying at Camp Kalahari. We did see an Aardwolf in late afternoon- a serendipitous find. The roadways are very rutted and we did have to leave before dusk, limiting how far we could go inside. Nevertheless, very enjoyable.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Massive area
text: It was quite wet when we drove out to the salt pan so could not get out that far without the risk of getting bogged down and leaving more than a footprint. A massive area of nearly 5000 square km's. Desolate and beautiful at the same time!

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Absolute Serenity
text: Yes this is truly an amazing and unique place. Quite frankly I could have spent hours just sitting on the pans with a Gin and Tonic as this area is a healthy escape from modern society.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Great Story Behind It
text: Our day at the salt pans was amazing! In the morning we had hot drinks on the edge of it. In the afternoon we had a quad bike experience of the salt pan. On we stopped for a blindfolded game and drinks. It was beautiful!

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Would hope for more viewpoints so one is not overrun
text: Just too many people stop here so you see people, rather than animal, tracks everywhere - from car tires, to bike tires, to feet.  People keep extending further and further to try to get that perfect clean picture which creates tracks even further.  All I can say about this place is that it is interesting but not earth shattering.  Some garbage is floating around as well.  I think it would be a fabulous place to look up at the stars on a clear night as it would be on the ocean with nothing to block the horizon.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: The Dead Zone
text:
Not to be confused with its "sister park" Nxai Pan (though technically, Nxai Pan is part of Makgadikgadi, apparently)--which was awesome--Makgadikgadi Salt Pan NP was "littered" with dead animals. 

I understand death is part of nature, and how many of us who go on safari are even hoping to see death in some fashion (say, a kill, perhaps? Or at least big cats feasting on a kill). But here? In a half-day's worth of driving--starting at the entrance closest to the entrance for Nxai Pan (I forget the name), but not going to the pans, as they were too far away--we came across: 1 dead wildebeest, 2 dead cows (yes, cattle graze down by the river), and 7--seven--dead zebras. 

Again, I get that not everything one sees while game driving is going to be alive, but this much death in a relatively small space? Something strange was definitely taking place, and it made the park really eerie. Also, at some point, it's nice to see something actually living. (We did see one bull ele down by the river, which was good). 

The signage was confusing, we saw more dead animals than living animals, and the whole place was just kind of creepy and weird. 

I suppose if you go to the pans themselves, and during the zebra migration or perhaps another time of year, this park could be cool, but our experience was sort of the opposite. 

The good thing is, since it's part of Nxai Pan as well, one payment gets you into both reserves--and Nxai Pan was fantastic.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Not to be missed great views, different animals
text: If you have the chance to visit the salt pans and the famous Baines Baobab trees please do so do not miss it, might be a long drive but worthwhile

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Think "Moonscape" in the dry season!
text:
We visited the pans by way of a "walking with meerkats" excursion (which was really interesting - but not reviewed here). The grey, dry soil going for miles and miles in the winter (September) was interesting to see but not a touch on the rest of Botswana (Chobe, Khama etc.). We are not into camping, so our hosts decided against Kubu Island and it was the wrong time of year for the large flocks and herds. We saw one lesser flamingo on a little pond beyond the grey Sowa Pan, but the pans themselves were dry and barren. 

An interesting site - but not one to spend too much time on at that time of year.

photos.caption: Lesser flamingo not far from Sowa Pan

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: The Salt Pan is far far away....
text: The book is deceptive on where the Salt Pan is from the north.  A bit of bad planning on our part admittedly meant we couldn't visit the Pan itself but went game viewing within the national park.  This needs planning and don't believe the books.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Awesomness, Beauty, Peace
text: These amazing open flat pans we visit approx. 4 times a year, many times in the wet and many times in the dry. they never fail to amaze, the curvature of the earth, clearly visible. There are some DONTs, such as "stay on the visible tracks", will allow you to visit the two incredible Islands, in the middle of nowhere. Kekonje has no facilities at all- but that suits us 100, Kubu, unfortunately has become a hotspot, money is demanded to visit, ablutions (long drops) are disgusting. but never the less, we will and continue to make this a regular stop and visit (we found other campsites, which are far more attractive and friendly)

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Extraordinary
text: Honestly when coming in botswana too many people pass this amazing desert and it is in my opinion a huge mistake! The landscapes are amazing, very unique and allows to have a really different experience during the trip in Botswana. It is simple it was our best experience in this country. Landscapes are totally surrealistic, you can see the meerkats, the San bushmen, endemic animals like hyena, depending on the month you go there you may see the migration, in October we saw just the begining. It is fantastic and totally worth to spend 4 or 5 days there

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: surreal landscape, fantastic scenery and lovely merkats
text: what is it to be on the moon, probably something you can experience here. And if it's been raining, it's another dramatic landscape that unfold at your feets!

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Silent nights
text: We decided to do something different than usual on our trips. What an adventure it was. We arrived after a bumpy road to the adventure camp where we stayed two nights. It was very quite with the most beautiful sunset and sunrise.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: wonderful place.. soul searching
text: the silence of this place reminds you of what is really important, to keep yourself balanced in the busy hectic pace of city life. over night out in the pan if you can. you will not forget it.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Stayed at San Camp
text: Perfect for a short stay..we did 3 nights.  For viewing game, seeing meerkats, quadbiking, horse riding.  Lovely comfortable camp.  Unique environment.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Ask the locals about the conditions of the pans
text: Fortunately, we asked about the conditions of the pans at Gweta Lodge before heading to Lekubu island. The guy told us that the pans are still wet if you try to reach them via Gweta. Therefore, we took the alternative route about 15km before Nata. He also told us that they pulled out a car the other day and it took them 14 hours for the recovery and that two other cars were in too deep so they had to abandon them. For more information, watch the Top Gear Botswana Special (S10E04).

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Amazing experience.
text: This place is out of this world. It’s like being on the surface of the moon, and there is nothing at all to see for miles around. It’s so flat you can see the earths curvature and the stars, with the benefit of an unobstructed view and no light pollution are spectacular. Spend a night here if you possibly can. It’s great.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Great place but cold
text: Great photography out on the plains. Be aware that it can get extremely cold when the wind is up. Dress in layers and look into how you can do trick photography on the plains prior to going.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: the quad bike ride across the Salt Pan
text: A unforgettable experience from start to end - the staff looked after us so well - The Salt Pan is something very different

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Camping at Tree Island
text: The campsites are on the edge of a salt pan, with no facilities at all.  It is easy assessable by 4x4 vehicle and also easy to find.  The area is very quit and there is not a lot of animals this time of the year.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Sunset
text: This is a completely different landscape from surrounding area. A few large water holes where I saw several large herds of elephants, buffalo and zebra. Also hippos and a few relocated crocodiles.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: ATV into the Salt Pans
text: We drive ATVs into the salt pans as the trucks were too heavy. About 20 minutes in, there were no trees, landmarks anything to get your bearings. We played a little game of trying to walk back to our ATV's blindfolded. It's amazing that how much we depend on our sight to correct our shortcomings. Everyone's step is biased either left or right. I managed to walk relatively straight, but some others literally walked in circles. We had our sundowner drinks there and were treated to a beautiful sunset! The trip back in the dark was challenging, but fun!

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Must Do!
text: We booked our overnight excursion to the Salt Pans through the Gweta Lodge. The Gweta Lodge is a beautiful place. In the afternoon we were driven to the salt pans in a game drive vehicle. On the way we stopped at a massive Baobab Tree and also got to stop and watch the meerkats. The guides dropped us off on the edge of the pan and we walked to our camp site - it's like walking on the moon. The guides built us a fire and prepared dinner. We got a sleep on mattresses directly on the pans - without tents - so we could see the stars all night. In the morning the staff prepared breakfast and afterwards we drove back to the Gweta Lodge. It is definitely one of the best things I did in Botswana - would highly recommend.

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Never seen so many zebra!
text: We did a game drive along the Boteti River in the south of the Makgadikgadi National Park.  We were astounded by the amount of game - mostly zebra and elephant and, of course, Impala.  We have never witnessed this many zebra ever in one reserve - awesome!

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Wonderful Silence
text: Take a guided tour, you could become disorientated at night, ride onto the middle of the Pan and set up to watch the sun go down. Late afternoon, prepared with, dry, white wine some carpccio and as the sun drops, the perfect peace is breath-taking!

placeInfo.name: Makgadikgadi Salt Pan
placeInfo.locationString: Makgadikgadi Pans National Park, Central District

title: Summer Solo travel
text:
One of my my most memorable vacation experiences! My 3 night excursion was very activity filled, the food was amazing and the rooms were very clean!

And the Staff!! ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ serenading me upon arrival with a welcome song and catering to my every conveneience! Notable shout-out to Shadee and Phefo! I will definitely be returning soon!!

placeInfo.name: Khwai Concession
placeInfo.locationString: Moremi Game Reserve, Okavango Delta, North-West District

title: a superb reserve
text: Diverse wildlife population and habitat. So much to see every day and never disappointed. Jeep, canoe, boat and walk safari available, just ask at camp or your guide.

placeInfo.name: Khwai Concession
placeInfo.locationString: Moremi Game Reserve, Okavango Delta, North-West District

title: Great wildlife
text: With our guide from our camp, we saw so many animals here.  The area is big with a lot of grassland that gives cover to the animals.  If we drove ourselves, we never would have seen so many animals.  Our guide got us to see  a leopard (3x and once with a kill), zebra, elephants, giraffe, a wild dog, a hyena, and a lioness in the tall grasses with her 3 small cubs.  Great place to view amazing animals.

placeInfo.name: Khwai Concession
placeInfo.locationString: Moremi Game Reserve, Okavango Delta, North-West District

title: Our first leopard sighting!!!
text: Great game drives and not heavily populated with tourist.  Mush of the time we felt we were the only ones. At most there were only 4 vehicles on a major sighting such as feeding lions.   Wildlife sighting was challenging given the season but encounters were high quality, up close and personal.    And got to sight and spend time with our first LEOPARD after multiple safaris!

placeInfo.name: Khwai Concession
placeInfo.locationString: Moremi Game Reserve, Okavango Delta, North-West District

title: Very exclusive game viewing experience
text:
Incredible game rich area and as you are on private concession, we had intimate one of one undisturbed viewing.
Incredible

placeInfo.name: Khwai Concession
placeInfo.locationString: Moremi Game Reserve, Okavango Delta, North-West District

title: Wonderful reserve
text: Great area to see a wide variety of animals and plants in relative seclusion. Few other people; viewing is kept to a 3 vehicle maximum. Guides work hard to find animals.

placeInfo.name: Khwai Concession
placeInfo.locationString: Moremi Game Reserve, Okavango Delta, North-West District

title: Leopard at last!
text: We have been on several safaris over the years but my husband has never managed to take good photos of leopard. Until we visited the Khwai river and camped at the Hippo Pool with Walk Botswana. Here he finally found his dream photo shoot, a pair of mating leopards who were oblivious to the cameras and posed beautifully! And there were also many lions, some of whom visited our camp, and an array of other animals and birds. Great place, though our guide thought it was quieter than usual for wildlife!

placeInfo.name: Khwai Concession
placeInfo.locationString: Moremi Game Reserve, Okavango Delta, North-West District

title: wild and so accessible
text: This is a place where you drive around and just see the animals and birds that abound.  It's full of nature and easy to encounter what Botswana has so carefully protected.

placeInfo.name: Khwai Concession
placeInfo.locationString: Moremi Game Reserve, Okavango Delta, North-West District

title: A 25th wedding anniversary to remember
text: We were blessed to stay in three awesome spots in the Khwai. We were at Machaba as well as Sable Alley and Khwai Bush camp. The staff and service at all three was brilliant but the game was the star of the show. We live on the Chobe river where game viewing is had to beat but WOW.... every day we had 4 out of the big 5 up close and personal. I highly recommend this area

placeInfo.name: Khwai Concession
placeInfo.locationString: Moremi Game Reserve, Okavango Delta, North-West District

title: The hyena's a mating lions were the highlights.
text: Beautiful game-watching and guide expertise- we were with July and he knew what he was talking about.

title: Ditto Moremi
text: Moremi and Kwai are separated by a small river, home to hippos, alligators, water birds of all kinds. You will see all your favorite animals up close, and in a less busy park they seem to act more natural. Just a very special place.

placeInfo.name: Khwai Concession
placeInfo.locationString: Moremi Game Reserve, Okavango Delta, North-West District

title: December trip -- fantastic concession
text:
Visited with Sango safari camp in late December, and had some fantastic sightings including large groups of elephants, lions (including some that had climbed a tree which was pretty crazy), wild dogs, and an absolutely beautiful group of denning hyenas with their pups (easily 15+ of them).

The denning hyenas have dug a spot right in the middle of the road so you're able to get really close to them (some of the pups were even gnawing on a tire of one of the trucks) and we've heard they're there pretty much every year (unless something gets really off with the weather one year) so they are really amazing to check out.

The park is really green this time of year so would recommend a guide to support your spotting and also so they can coordinate with the guides from the other camps. The cars are able to go off-road here which helps as well in the rainy season so that you can get closer to the sightings when you do find them.

placeInfo.name: Khwai Concession

title: Great place for game viewing

placeInfo.name: Khwai Concession

title: Surprisingly unique destination
text:
At first I was focussed on Moremi - and then got very positively surprised by Khwai. They do have some very unique spots there - just at the doorstep from the Moremi Reserve. Many of the Camps are in the concession, not in the GP, which is separated from the concession by a river. You find very unique spots there: A Hyena den in a collapsed termite hill which hosted a lot of families of hyena at a time. A Mokoro spot where I was surrounded 275 degrees by elephant coming 20m to the car. Very unique plalce with the same wildlife as Moremi. 

As anywhere in Botswana: Check time when you go there as scenery and wildlife differs a lot within the year. 

Definitely going back. Five-Star-Safari-location.

If you can find a less frequented concession, and there are many it seems, go elsewhere.

placeInfo.name: Khwai Concession
placeInfo.locationString: Moremi Game Reserve, Okavango Delta, North-West District

title: Breathtaking.  Worth the paperwork
text:
There is no doubt that this is something of a hidden treasure. It is not easy to get to - a long and corrugated 60 miles from Letlhakane - but worth the effort.  On arrival in mid April there were only 3 other couples in the whole park. Over 6 days we only saw 3 other vehicles, but 26+ elephants, 8 lions, herds of springbok, family groups of kudu, hartebeest, wildebeest, giraffe, ostrich and dozens of bird types.

It’s a bit of a palaver booking and paying. The camps within the reserve ar administered by Bigfoot Safaris and need to be booked prior to arrival. Entry to the park is controlled by DWNP and must be booked ahead and paid for on arrival (in cash!)  
Because we were travelling and had little airtime and spotty wifi we managed to arrange to pay Bigfoot over the phone but DWNP required a meeting with a ranger in a Choppies carpark upon our return.

We stayed in Molosi 01 and Maleswe 02.  Both camps are close to pumped waterholes. You can see the waterhole from Maleswe and are on the elephant commuter route to/from at Molosi (where elephants had wrecked the bucket shower and tried to push over the latrine.  But hey! That’s what you’re paying for.

title: wild camping at its best
text: Yes this was  a fantastic game reserve. Lions walked right past our tent. we rented a stunning4x4 from Choe4x4 in Maun. Drove through the Kalahariand spent our last three nights in kutse. we saw Cheetah, elephant Lion and san people. its thick sand but our land cruiser was very powerful and the thick sand was no problem

title: What a wild place
text:
We travelled up to Khutse in June 2019 from Durban and stayed at Molose for 3 nights, and then at Mahurushele for 2 nights. The park itself was just as we’d hoped – Adventurous and Wild!

You need to take everything with you – which includes enough water and supplies, as well as petrol/ diesel, and other necessities like wood/charcoal etc (You might not see another person/ car for a few days – at one stage we went 3 days without seeing another vehicle!). At the campsites there is just a long drop and no running water, with a bucket shower if you take your own water.

We weren’t experienced 4X4’ers and took an Isuzu 4X2 which still dealt decently with the sandy roads. We did get stuck once and needed to dig ourselves out which took about an hour – lucky we took a shovel! Most of the roads were fine for a 4X2, with a few sandy patches which were a bit dicey but which we managed to get through.
I’d definitely recommend taking a shovel and closed walking shoes with you in the car, in case you either need to dig yourselves out, or need to walk if your car breaks down etc. However it was encouraging to see that the parks officials did track visitors when they were expected to leave the park and will come find people if they haven’t left on the date they’re supposed to.

In terms of the animals we unfortunately didn’t see as many as expected. The pump at the Molose watering hole had been broken by elephants about a month before we visited. We still did see tons of elephants and springbok (21 springbok each day for 3 days to be exact – which clearly meant there weren’t many predators around). The only predators we saw were bat-eared foxed and a rogue African Wild cat near our campsite. The best camp for animals appeared to have been Khutse Pan where there was lots of open veldt and an open waterhole (this is close to the park fence but appeared to be the best place to stay in terms of looking for animals). 

Overall, even though we were disappointed with not seeing many animals, it was an amazing experience!

title: To barren
text: This is a wonderful wildlife park .... so close to Gaborone.  Sadly there are hardly any animals around to view.  This is due to the lack of water holes.  They need to sink a lot of boreholes for the animals.  This will attract more wild life .... and more tourists.

title: Amazing
text:
The place is amazing a very good spot out of town..we really had fun though .we managed to see a lot of game including lions i guess it was our lucky day.i wont hesitate visiting again any time. 

The camping facilities are not the best but they are in a good state and very neat.big up

title: Green semi desert!
text: Khutse was amazing! We saw lions at molose waterhole, kudus, elephants and a herd of gemsbok in our 2 days camping safari at Khutse 9 campsite

title: This place is wild
text: We stayed here on one of the Khutse pan campsites, two nights. At the campsite was just a pit toilet and an enclosure for shower, no water. Most of the spots didn´t have any big trees for shade. There were no other visitors, so we had the whole place for ourselves. That was nice and gave a feeling of remoteness. We really loved it there, though would have liked to see more animals, we just saw some antelopes and birds and one jackal and a wild cat in two days. There was some water at the nearby waterhole at the Khutse pan, so I wonder why such a lack of animals. Staff at the gate were very friendly. I would recommend this place for those who want to enjoy wild nature not seeing many other people, and those who are ok with not to see so many animals.

title: Great Weekend Getaway
text:
Been planning the trip for about 3 weeks, after making the booking through Bigfoot Safaris and Tours in Gaborone, we eagerly traveled the 260km (100km gravel/sand) to Khutse. Unfortunately we couldn't get the same campsite for 2 consecutive nights as all camps were already booked was which was a pain as it necessitated a move, which meant build camp, break camp, build camp, break camp. As it happened we later found out that the weekend was completely sold out due to a SA public holiday. But in the end the change of scenery was nice. But definitely wont attempt this in summer.
Day 1 was at Molose 4 - very clean and neat and quiet, as it is well away from the other 3 campsites in the area. 
We went down to the waterhole for sunset and sun downers and to hopefully see some game, unfortunately what we saw was pretty shocking, 2 separate groups of SA reg groups parked alongside the waterhole on both sides out of their vehicles sitting on camp chairs with their tables and braais in full swing. That wasn't even the most shocking. The 1 group allowed their 3 children clearly under 10yrs of age to play at least 30mt from them, nearer the waterhole... All I could think was these people must have rocks for brains or perhaps they thought they were at the Vaal dam for the weekend. The other group were not much better as they too were sitting and standing around their bar table completely oblivious to the fact that they were in the Kalahari in a wildlife reserve in a lion area with confirmed sightings of lion at that waterhole for the past 7 days. Besides the fact that none of the prey animals would ever come close to the water with them there so what they were hoping to see there amazed me. The thirsty giraffe stood about 1000m away before eventually moving off. Needless to say we also moved on and found somewhere else to watch the beautiful Kalahari sunset. After a delicious BBQ dinner by the fire we were treated to the most spectacular star filled sky that I have ever seen in my life, made possible by a moonless night. 
We had chilly good night sleep and after making our "amarula" coffee and still in our PJ's we took a quick drive to the waterhole to see the sunrise, and perhaps an animal or two - although we beat the masses there, it was not long before they arrived to set up camp against the waterhole and started their Gas cookers to boil the water for coffee. We didn't hang around and went back to camp to have breakfast and break down camp to move across to Khutse Camp #9 - Also nice and clean and the previous campers had left us a log of firewood (standard camping etiquette) this campsite has a beautiful large acacia tree. Toilet was Clean and Bucket shower was working. Resident mongoose paid us a visit and the Hornbills made us feel welcome. Khutse pan has large numbers of springbok and we saw a family of 8-10 Black backed Jackal there too.
After another great sunset and a BBQ dinner we sat around the campfire and admired the awesome night sky. We had a cold night but slept well, and only woke up once in the early hours to hear the lion roaring in the distance. The Jackals woke us up properly though at around 5.30am but we didn't mind, and were soon up to make coffee and tea for our early morning sunrise drive. We decided to head north to one of the pans close by, and were so happy we did as rounding a corner we were met by a Cheetah Female and her two 4-6 week old cubs. First Cheetah sighting in the real wild! excluding private reserves and Game parks. This was the real deal! 
So our final Game sighting List included: Elephant (a new and welcome addition to Khutse)/ Giraffe/ Red Hartebeest / Gemsbok / Kudu / Jackal / Steenbok / Sprinbok / Ostrich & Cheetah. Many Birds including quite a few raptors which is always nice.
What you need to remember to take: Plenty Water (drinking and bathing) / Firewood / Good Camera / Binoculars are essential / Bird and other reference books, besides all your usual camp equipment. 
We can't wait to head back, only this time we will avoid SA long weekends as it seems Khutse is becoming very popular with our SA neighbors. We don't really mind them as long as they respect the rules and laws of Nature - it would be very sad to hear someone or someones' child became a statistic of the food chain, and what the repercussions of that might be...Until the next time!

photos.caption: Khutse - Place of Space and Skies

title: Great if you like being alone in the bush
text:
We stayed here for 6 nights and in that time only saw 5 vehicles!  There had been plenty of rain in February and March so the grass was high so you only saw animals on, or very close to, the tracks or at the pans.  We stayed at 3 different campsite, Moreswe, Molose and Khutse. 
You have to be prepared to take everything with you (including water) as the only facilities at campsite are a long drop toilet, bucket shower and a fire pit.  We were glad that we's taken our own 12 volt shower as at two of the sites the bucket showers were broken. It's 100 km of reasonable gravel from the nearest town, Lethlakeng, and then sandy tracks in the Reserve - the 70 m from the gate to Moreswe took us about 2 1/4 hours. 
We enjoyed seeing animals at Moreswe Pan and Khutse Pan but especially  loved being back I the bush on our own.

title: very good place for a weekend trip to Kalahari
text: the camping facilities are very nice and well kept, the area - if you like the Kalahari - is very pleasant, you'll see quite some game including elephants and you may be lucky spotting a lion as well

title: Khutse, my new Favourate
text:
We entered Khutse from the North traveling through the Central Kalahari Game Reserve. We were not planned to stay over, just a drive through. Well, we were disappointed that we did not book to stay over. Lots of game and the park is well runned. We did not see any other vehicles in the park.
The camps are unfenced with long drops and bucket showers.
We came across lots of Lion track's. 
We booked to explore Khutse in April-May and looking very much forward to the trip.

title: Great Escape
text:
What a place to go and visit if you don't want to see any people for days -- if you lucky -- or just a vehicle or two.

Booking through Bigfoot tours - google them - and speak to Lucia, she has always been helpful in the past times we went camping in Khutse. 

Go for at least 3 nights as that will be worth your while to enjoy the emptiness. Stargazing is spectacular on a moonless evening and you don't need any light when it is full moon. You can hear the planes going over from Europe to give an idea of how quiet it does get.

Camped at Mahurushule / Khutse / Khanke / Moreswe and each of these have a pit latrine and a place where you can hang your shower or use the bucket that is supplied. Khutse pan campsites can be a bit noisy if there are other people as the noise does carry far on a silent evening. Make sure you do douse your fire every night to avoid it spreading into the veld and cover it with sand, bury the ash before you leave to give your fellow campers a nice experience.

Firewood / water and fuel is essential and you need to ensure you have this to be self sufficient for the time that you are in the reserve. Take your rubbish back with you and discard it at the gate. The road from Lethlakeng could be either dusty and rough of wet and slippery, depend on the time of year that you visit.

Some spots to go for a viewing is Khutse Pan / Moreswe Pan (far south of the park) / Molose waterhole. You can see lion / wild dog / elephant / springbuck / duiker / giraffe and then if you do take some time, good spot for birding - owls / eagles / vultures and a big variety of predatory and other birds.

Great break-away spot for a long week-end, closest place to Gaborone and a similar experience as CKGR. Bush camping at its best.

title: Know What You're Doing!
text: As a Botswana resident, be advised that Khutse is not for the first time safari-goer. The main access road from the capital can be poor, with severe corrugations. Game can be sparse. There are virtually no facilities and you must be self-sufficient in water, fuel and food for the duration of your trip (including a reserve), and you MUST take your rubbish back to the gate with you when you leave. You are not permitted to collect firewood in the reserve so this must be obtained in advance and carried in with you. You will need your own camping equipment and a strong 4x4 vehicle and a sense of adventure. You need to book in advance through Big Foot Tours (Google them) who can also organise payment of park fees to the Department of Wildlife on your behalf. Regard your trip there as primarily a wilderness camping experience and you're unikely to be disappointed. You COULD see lion, leopard, cheetah, wild dog or you might see none of them. All of them are free to wander into your campsite at any time, so be vigilant and watch your kids (or leave them at home). I have been there dozens of times and it is brilliant, provided you come properly prepared and with realistic expectations. Plan your visit for at least 3 nights to make the journey there worthwhile.

title: visit to khutse game reserve
text: A game reserve too much far away from the city.Reaching to kutse game reserve is very difficult.No pakka roads are available.Roads to kutse is totally desert type.Going through own cars to  a game reserve is horrible .we have seen deers ,small pigs,ostritch,wilder breeds and monkeys.my daughter enjoyed this trip very much while her 7 days visit in botswana.the staff of game reserve were very cooperative .I recommend to people to go the khutse game reserve with their family but for no camp.

photos.caption: my daughter at kutse game reserve
with my daughter at the entance of kutse game reserve

title: Great out of town spot
text: Most people recommend 4x4 vehicles to access Khutse Game reserve and Central Khalahari Game Reserve, I must say you can make it even without a 4x4, if you are renting a car, 4x4 can be expensive, if you are on a budget holiday, just get a high raised car even if its a  not 4x4... We went on a day visit to Khutse and CKGR, we had 4x4 but never had to use the 4x4 feature, we we lucky on the day, we saw lions, cheaters, Ostriches, Springboks, Giraffes, Gemsboks and other popular antelopes found in Khutse

photos.caption: Spotted a cheetah in the border of Khutse and CKGR

title: It's a strange place to visit
text: They seem to want you to have reservations, but the people I was traveling with (who had lived in Botswana) couldn't figure out how to make those required reservations. We went, were told we couldn't have a reservation. They were "full". There were no other cars, no indication anyone else was there....we asked if we could go in and they again said we could not have a reservation, but this time they added that we could have admission. I have no idea what all happened there. Maybe the fee we paid went in someone's pocket. We saw some animals, but not too many. Their sign implies there are more animals to see than there are, for example there's a zebra on the sign but none in the park.

title: Perfect Outdoor, Camping Place
text: The is a great getaway with family and/ or friends. Its great during summer because winter the coldness of the wild can be aggresive. There are some entertainment spots far from wild animals. Its is a breather as its far from the cities and towns. I recommend it for those who need to leave town for sometime.

title: Nice Drive from Gabz
text:
Khutse is one of my favorite spot for a short wilderness trip from Gaborone, the capital city of Botswana. Game is bit less dense here and the landscape is typical karoo bushes. Park has got mainly three waterholes where the animals frequent. I have spotted lions but no other cats though they say Cheetahs can be spotted at times.

Other games are also low, you may find antelopes like, Hartebeest, Zebras, Oryx, few Giraffes etc. Birds like Vultures, Rollers, Kites and Eagles can be seen.

Khutse is a very good park for a quick break from your routine days at Gabs and a one night camping would be great. The camps have only Pit /long drop Latrines and must carry enough water for your stay. Camp sites are not fences and predators are free to roam, its not advisable for the little kids to play around unattended.

title: A good couple of nigjts
text:
We stayed here two nights and found the game reserve fairly quiet - people and animals (sadly). 
Roads are accessible by 4x4 and are fairly ok, very bumpy and lots of dust! 
The park itself is reasonably priced, the camp site fee was a bit of a shock.. 
The camp site was ok, amazing location right next to the wild life and the stars are amazing. Pit toilet and diy shower were fine! 
Bring lots of fire wood, you can stock up on water at the gate!

title: Khutse the place to have to love
text: Khutse Game reserve is one of the places you either hate or love but most of the people love it. It has minimum facilities and you have to take it with you. Fun place with lots of good animal and bird viewing

title: Remote and breathtaking
text: Chutes can be difficult to reach without a 4x4 vehicle, especially during the rainy season. The trek makes the destination that much more unique. It is easy to imagine Botswana in the early days here and it instills a sense of awe and appreciation for the indigenous people from here.

title: A Little Disappointing...
text: I found it underwhelming. Some of the campsites had no real view though I had read they did. The bush is often difficult to see into for km after km. What really brought it down was the behaviour of other self drives. Picnics outside the vehicle at waterholes and they ask why they're not seeing game. Kids balanced on the top of Fortuners...In short this didn't make me want to come back. Positive - the President's camp site is lovely.

title: A nature lover must!
text:
We drove to and from Khutse Game Reserve from Gaborone (Gabs) in one day and spent about 6 hours there.  You do need your own 4 x 4 vehicle as the roads are dirt with some deep ruts in spots. It is fairly easy to navigate and is inexpensive, cost about P420 for 3 of us and our vehicle (Fortuner 4x4).
We saw many different animals to include 15 giraffe, springbok, ostrich, hartebeest, gemsbok, and wild dogs.
The road getting to Khutse from Gabs was paved until we got to a little town outside of Bagwasi, it was dirt road the rest of the way..
The staff at the gate are very friendly and informative.
Be sure to sign the guest book!

title: Wild camping, close (ish) to Gabz
text: Khutse is a great game reserve that is about 3-4 hours from Gabz.  It is hit and miss on the sightings front but when it is good, its great.  When it is not giving you the predators (lion, leopard, wild dog, caracal, hyena typically) just enjoy the birding and plains game, and of course being in the bush.  You need to be fully self sufficient as the campsites don't have water provided.  You do get a loo and a bucket shower.  Moonless nights result in some of the best star gazing you will experience.  Big Foot Tours are who you book the campsite through.

title: Camping at Khutse- not for the faint hearted
text:
We were lucky to have camped at Khutse in our last few days in Botswana. The drive on the dirt road itself was interesting as there is hardly a person  you'll get to see after a while.We stopped over at a place to have quick lunch and as we were having our lunch, there came some bushmen...they were nothing like how we see in the movies, they were wearing T-shirts and capris, women in skirts, but clothes were shabby. As we had no language to communicate, we just smiled at each other and we ended up sharing our pasta and coke with them!
 Khutse is a lot drier than game reserves up north like Chobe and Maun. Nevertheless, this place still has plenty of lions. Lovers of the big cats, as we are, we have no reasons to regret our visit to this place. There are areas of clearings interspersed with areas of bush.Spotting game in bush is not all that easy but as we had visited in november, it was hot and we spotted game at the water holes.We spotted giraffes, springboks, gemsboks and kudus but the most memorable was a lioness walking on the road with her two little cubs, it was absolutely adorable and she continued walking on the road in spite of our presence, for pretty long! Other than that we spotted some six different lions and lionesses at various locations in the reserve, which was a lot more than our expectations!. We went with our group of friends to camp there. We were allotted a nice camp site,with a single tree in the centre and a pit type toilet. Day was pretty hot but it became cooler by the time we pitched our tents in the evening. We had a nice barbecue and a wonderful farewell party with the only music being the sounds of the jungle. After we slept, it drizzled and to our thrill, when we got up, we saw lion pug marks over the freshly drizzled soil right on our camp site! We were all so excited with the idea of a lion visiting us while we were asleep!

Again, a few things which must be kept in mind before planning is that you must have a four wheel drive to reach this place, as its almost a 100 Km of dirt road from lethlakeng. Its better if you have at least two vehicles for backup in case of a breakdown which had happened here with another of my friend. The last fuel station is at lethlakeng, so carrying extra fuel is a good idea and so is carrying everything you need to eat and drink. Not many people come to camp here, so it gets rather lonely, like we were the only people to camp in the whole reserve when we went. So, again, its better to travel in a group than a couple alone or something.There is a resort a few Km short of this place, but I have no idea about how it is. Overall,an interesting place to camp for a thrill seeker but not a place for the faint hearted!

title: A real adventure in the bush
text:
We spent just one night camping in Khutse, but it was a real adventure for us. It took us over 6 hours to get to Khutse from Gabs due to construction past Molepolole (hopefully completed by now as we went in September 2014) and the quality of the dirt road (our vehicle lacks rear shocks).

You're required to have a 4x4 to enter the park (they will ask at reception) and you're going to want a vehicle with decent clearance as the ruts in the sand are deep. Don't be stupid like we were and take your Rav4 Jr or you'll probably get stuck. Miraculously we didn't, but if we had, we would have been stuck for awhile since there was only 1 other group in the entire park. Ideally, go with a group and 2 vehicles. Be sure to pack extra petrol/food/water just in case. Also, bring your own firewood because we didn't find anyone selling alongside the road, so after sunset, we had nothing to do but go to sleep. 

We stayed at Mahurushele Pan #3 and it was a great camping site under a big tree. We walked to the pan for sunrise/sunset and had a lovely view of grazers and birds (Kori Bustard/Secretary bird). We would have like to have stayed at Molose or Moreswe to watch the watering holes, but we couldn't make it that far in our vehicle. We listened to the birds sing us to sleep and woke up to something sniffing/breathing outside of our tent (likely a hyena, but we didn't look). This was my first time camping anywhere with large animals and it evoked a fair bit of anxiety (I've since camped in Chobe & Khama Rhino Sanctuary, and ever time, it's a bit tense). We didn't see any predators, but we didn't feel bad because no one had seen anything except hyena in the past week. Check the log book at the entrance to see what people have been seeing.

All in all, we had an enjoyable trip. We both decided it was worth it for the Kalahari sunrise/sunset over the pans! I'm not sure we'll have time to go to the CKGR, so I'm glad we made it to Khutse!

photos.caption: One of the watering holes at Khutse I or II

title: One of a kind wildlife experience !!!
text:
Are you a nature lover to an extent where you can drive on your own, camp, live, eat and be close amongst wildlife rather than sleep in luxurious chalets and go game driving with managed groups? Do you like wildlife as they are suppose to be. i.e wild? Do you want to enjoy Africa a little differently from the usual style? 

THEN KHUTSE IS YOUR BEST & QUICKEST BET (Located less than 250kms from Gaborone, the capital city of Botswana)

I am indeed proud and happy that i have included this marvel which is home for 1000s of wildlife lovers when they want a get away from Gaborone or those 4x4 enthusiasts who wanna pass through the Mighty Central Kgalagadi Game Reserve. Khutse will be their 1st stop. 

A rustic game reserve located about 100kms from the last filling station point & big village called Letlhakeng, Khutse Game Reserve was once part of the CKGR. It was later separated for better management i should guess, else CKGR which is now the 2nd largest wildlife reserve int he world, would have been 1st largest wildlife thanks Khutse made separate. Yellow Stone of USA takes the 1st position but i can guarantee that the wildlife and action that happens here is unmatchable.

Khutse, a relatively small game reserve is packed with adventure if you go at the right time of the year and to the right camping sites. The booking is currently done via a private tour company located in the capital city (a simple googling will take you to Bigfoot tours) and they give enough info about the park and also help you hire vehicles to drive in (its a strictly 4x4 zone and you need a little bit of driving skills to handle the mixed terrain which starts with gravel from Letlhakeng (about 110kms to Khutse) and then completely loose desert sand throughout the park.

Lions are the big cats found quite often here while Khutse is also home for Cheetahs and Leopards but quite small in number. Khutse boasts of many campsites but my personal favorite and mostly in demand site is Molose. It has about 4 campsites of which one located very very close to the famous Molse Pan & Waterhole. A pride of 17 lions are currently hanging around in this area and if you are lucky, you can spot them drinking water at Molose. 

Khutse is also home for several species of birds, other mammals such as Hyena (both Brown & Spotted), Bat eared fox, caracal, jackal, and some types of snakes too.

In my 9 visits to Khutse i have seen Lion only once as i always go on crowded long weekends where most campsites are full. Rainy time is not the best time to visit due to road conditions and little chances of seeing animals. Best time is Sep/October when its dry and not raining much. Or around February when the rain gradually reduces but it still hot. Why, because the animals come closer to the waterhole during dryer periods.

But that doesnt restrict a camping experience in the wild so if you don't have choice, Khutse is still worth a visit once anytime. Highly advised to go with adequate water, food, medication and other requirements as there is no connectivity whatsoever and just peace.

There are loads of information in web portals about Khutse & camping in general in that area. Hope this information is helpful and please ensure that you have a 4x4 and try avoiding going in just 1 vehicle so that if you are stuck inside the 2nd vehicle can assist.

Thanks

title: 쵸배 국립공원과 또다른 분위기에 초식동물과 사자가 많이 서식하고 있는 곳입니다
text: 게임리조부 10km 전에 숙박 시설이 있으며 게임 리조브에는 야영을 할수 있는 시설이 되어 있는데 물과 야영할수 있는 준비를 해서 가면 사자를 볼수 잇는 기회가 많으면 사막 지역이라 4X4 자동차가 필요 하며 맑운날 야영을 하면 아름다운 하늘을 만끽할수 있어 좋다.

photos.caption: 쵸배 국립공원과 색다른 동물과 쵸원에 아름다움
야영을 할수 있는 가니 샤워장과 캠프파이어장 텐트 카라벤을 설치할수 있는 충분한 공간이 있다

title: интересно
text: Приехали, договорились на месте за 120 баксов, что примем душ, переночуем в своей палатке на территории и на утро - экскурсия. Пригнали джип - только гид и мы - несколько часов катались по Калахари, смотрели разных антилоп и птиц, бегали за некоторыми и много фотографировали. Слегка замерзли, но было очень классно! =) Надо учитывать, вы едете искать животных, а не смотреть их. Это не зоопарк.

title: Excellent animal viewing no matter what time of year you go!!
text: We were actually at Moremi  in May, at the end of their dry season before the rains come.  We thought it might be easier to see the animals when there were fewer places for water, but our guide told us that regardless of the time of year, there is plenty of animals to see...and boy, was he right!  We were there for three days, so we had a total of 6 drives and on each drive we had an amazing experience.  From early morning lion kills of a zebra to the late afternoon elephant family playing with their kids in the mud, the viewing was some of the best we've ever had.  Definitely will be going back!!

title: Nothing like it!  Go now!
text: The Moremi is one of the special places on earth.  The largest inland delta in the world never disappoints!  The flora and fauna are indescribable!  Enjoy!

title: Excellent combination of both water and land
text: This game reserve is worth the visit - you can see both land animals such as elephants and antelope as well as water animals such as crocs and hippos.

title: Moremi Game Reserve, Botswana.
text: Unfortunately we on spent one night at Khwai Camp on our way from Savuti to Maun. Khwai campsite has large treed sites and the ablution facilities are in excellent condition. A representaive from SKL, who manage the campsite came and spoke to us and informed us of the game drives within the area and what we were likely to see. A small herd of Elephant passed close to the camp and we were visited by a Spotted Hyena during the evening.

title: very good experience
text: we saw many elephants,hippos,hyenas,chettah,impalas,the experience of botswana and crew of bushbaby calls was very good

title: Super Game Drive
text:
Totally recommend for game viewing and game drives. 
Exzellent Location for your vacation. Done with Letaka.

title: never elsewhere 15 lions in a day
text: I have already experienced Botswana parks in the past  but never Moremi before: well  it is really  wonderful, not only for the high number of animals we were able to watch but  mainly beacuse they were very close to us and the surronding landscape  was amazing: colors, trees, water pools. Moreover it is the first time that I see a total of 15 lions in the same day ( 1 big group of 7 and  smaller of 2/3 each).  Apart from the natural beauty of the park itself  our guide  did a great job ckecking  all the  remote corners and following the footprints left by cats on the ground.  I am pretty sure that he made the difference

title: Unspoiled paradise
text: We have been going to the Okavango and Moremi GR for 20 years now and find it among the more beautiful and pristine places in Africa. The Botswana govt has done a good job of limiting access so that it does not seem overcrowded.

title: See the big five
text: It sometimes takes a lot of time patience to see the big five but we managed to even though our view of the rhino were just the head and horns running away from us through the bush.

title: Animals in beautiful surroundings
text: After having been on safari in other parks for more than 3 weeks, we have discovered new animals here, in beautiful surroundings. Recommended.

title: "Deep Sand"
text: Moremi Game reserve is a part of the Okavango Delta. Normally it is one of the greenest and water holding part of Botwana but due a lack of rainfall last summer there was less water than usual this time of year. Due this reason the roads are very dry and have become deep sand on many places so a 4x4 is really needed. Reduced tire pressure is obligated. The NR is rich of wildlife and entry is swift when prebooked and entry fees already paid at the bureau in Maun.

title: Excellent game reserve
text:
The Khwai area of the Okavango lies along the northern boundary of the Moremi Game Reserve. This is an unfenced
boundary allowing wildlife to move freely between the woodlands in the wet season when water is plentiful and back to permanent rivers and lagoons in the dry season. The Khwai area offers the same wildlife experience as the reserve with the added advantage of being a private concession which means the ability to do walking safaris and night drives.
The waterways are home to numbers of hippo and crocodiles as well as a multitude of waterbirds. Other birding opportunities are spectacular, with a list of 450 recorded species in the area.

title: The real deal
text: Moremi was a wonderful National park rich with absolutely every animal you can imagine.  From Leopard to Lion, we even chased Wild Dogs on a kill but sadly lost them.  The next morning, we found about 15 of them with 4 pups, sleeping across the track we were driving on, full stomachs after eating half the Impala that was beside them!   Truly magical.  Dont miss Moremi!

title: Camping with elephants
text: It was very dry during our visit, but it is still beautiful, especially next to the rivers.  We camped at Xakanaxa and the elephants was consistently in and around our camp.  There are a lot of game, but the roads are challenging. We could drive to areas which is usually not reachable by car, because of the low water levels in the Delta

title: Lions and Leopards and Antelope, oh my!
text: Not ten feet away a young lion was in the brush watching a herd of impalas.  As my camera was clicking it leaped out and chased into the herd.  A big leopard was resting in a tree with a kudu carcass nearby,  Impalas, kudus, wildebeast, other antelope small and large.  A mother elephant bellowed at us blocking the road so her family could cross. Giraffes strolling by.  What more can you say?

title: Spectacular
text: You see all animals possible, except cheetah, rhino or oryx. But wow, really amazing. I would repeat if I had the opportunity.

title: Beautiful despite draught
text: This area is very rich in game. Self-driving is now easier than ever because the water levels are low.

title: Wildlife a plenty
text: There is no lack of wildlife in the Moremi Game Reserve. Large herds of elephants, buffalo and Lechwe/Moors antelope abound as well as impala, kudu, sable antelope and the elusive cats, lions, leopards and hyenas and jackals.

title: Best game reserve in Botswana
text:
Moremi is one of the best game reserves I ever witnessed. You can see nearly everything here. Tons of birds, rare mammals like servals and african wild dogs, as well as the big five. A must see!
Best places to view the wildlife are in the Khwai area (North Gate) and Xini Lagoon (South Gate)

title: Must visit!
text: Wish I had camped over night and done more game drives. So many animals to see. So amazing to see them in the wild, rather than a zoo!!!

title: A Place to See the Big 5 ...
text: ... but not necessarily close up. Since it's a National Park you cannot go off road so that does mean some sighting will not be as close as one would like.  That doesn't mean you would not have an exciting experience but if going for photography bring your best zoom lens.

title: Loved Moremi - one of the best
text: We went to 4 different Game reserves/ National Parks and Moremi was our favourite.  Secluded and many animals.  We heard lions, Elephants and hippos every night and saw all those and more.  Going with an organised tour is definitely worth it, as the truck drivers all stop to talk to each other when we pass by and we were told the location of animals (including Wild dogs in their den), which we would never have seen if we were driving ourselves.

title: Magical Moremi
text: Fabulous wildlife experiences in Moremi. A leopard walked out of bush directly to our jeep then crossed in front of us n walked down road in search of impala ahead. Then later we virtually parked between a pride of lions to observe them, glad they had full bellies. Hippos galore in last remaining waterholes as drying up. Lunch under sausage trees, beware of falling seed pods.

title: Elephants galore
text: Fabulous game viewing in Moremi Game Reserve - so many elephants, hippos and other wildlife. A pride of lions wandered past our camp. Just beautiful.

title: A highlight of Botswana
text:
My small-group tour spent the entire day in Moremi Game Reserve and, though long with much driving, it served up some amazing sights for us.
We started at dawn and it was 5C, which meant we were very cold in the open vehicle. It was worth the pain. I saw my first leopard, a female hunting Impala. The sighting was close and for about 10 minutes.
We saw many giraffe, lions, hippos and dozens of elephant. Our guides were terrific.
Snacks and lunch were welcome.
Highly recommended.

photos.caption: African Hornbills are everywhere here and are not afraid of humans. This one was playing around my feet. © Photos by Pharos 2019

title: Big place, big areas without animals, some places crowded
text: Do not expect too much from the animal kingdom. The place is huge and it takes time to discover. The north-west part is almost crowded, but there are still areas where you can drive for hours without seeing another car. The experience depends complete on the weather / climat. This yeas it is bone dry - a lot of roads are passable which normally have too much water. The main roads consist almost entirely of deep, fine sand. Positiv: the main roads were graded in June this year. Well done! Is it worth? I personally like the Khwai area much more.

title: Wild
text: Th roads - make sure you have a powerful  4x4 vehicle - in the dry months there is a large "middle section" we and others got stuck despite having a good car, thank goodness people are kind and help you if youre on a main road there is traffic - but dont chance going there with a "silly little car".  It is beautiful, at times the lions were close enough to reach out and touch.  We went to sleep being able to hear the elephants stomachs growl.  There was a leopard sighting, but sadly not by us.  The Wild dogs were magnificent.  Take your provisions - the odd shop has basics that will cost you.

title: The wildlife exceeded our expectations.
text: Lions, giraffes, leopards, warthogs, elephants, hippos, rhinos, impala, sable antelope, Cape buffalo, Nile crocodiles, birds and more! Just wonderful.

title: What a amazing place!
text:
We stayed over in 3rd bridge...can highly recommend this place! the trip from south gate was rough and 4x4 is needed for sure, but hell it makes for a stunning adventure! Lots..and I mean lots of animals, many close encounters especially with the elephant! A must do is a guided boat trip on the delta, which is available in camp. If there is one place in Botswana we can highlight it is Moremi!
On a negative only is the ladies at reception of South gate is quite arrogant, but if you look past that a altogether amazing experience!

title: Lions galore
text: The Moremi Game Reservewhich is separated from the Khwai Community Land by the Moremi river, has lots and lots of lions, and other game, including elephants, buffaloes and leopards. We saw 14 lions and 9 leopards.

title: wildlife
text: With a good guide you should see and learn about lots of animals in this wildlife rich reserve. Kudos to Botswana for maintaining it.

title: Lions! Impalas! Elephants!
text: So many good sightings. Vast and varied landscapes. So huge that you'll feel extremely small, in the best possible way.

title: un game-drive d'une très grand qualité
text:
Une journée entière dans le parc à la recherche des animaux sauvages.
Le pique-nique au milieu des animaux, avec crocodiles et hippopotame à quelques mètres est impressionnant.
Un conseil, allez y avec un guide qui saura vous montrer tous les recoins inconnus...

title: En güzel dinlenme yeri
text: Dünyanın bir ucunda insanlardan medeniyetten uzak vahşi doğa ile iç içe bir 15 gün. Doğanın icinde vahşi hayvanların arasında insanlarin eskiden dersiz ve keyifli bir yaşamları olduğunu anliyorsunuz

title: Safari
text:
O parque é muito bem localizado e como tem caminhos a visita fica facilitada.
Vi grande quantidade de animais o ponto alto foi uma família de cheeetas que parecia que estava posando para as nossas fotografias.

title: Begeistert
text: Viele Tiere, gute Safaris mit Jeep und Boot, tolle Guides, die uns nicht gehetzt haben. Wir waren mit Bush Ways unterwegs,

title: Natur pur mit Tieren hautnah
text: Erlebnisreicher Tagesausflug den man besser organisiert von Maun macht.Lange Anfahrt aber es lohnt sich immer.Trotz Trockenheit viele KATZEN gesehen.Grosse Herden waren im Nov.schon in Richtung Chobe

title: In 1 woord geweldig
text: Jammer dat onze gids andere dingen belangrijker, dan de wensen van zijn gasten. Maar heel mooi park, waar we veel bonus hebben gekregen. Leeuw in boom en African wild dogs die hun prooi verscheurd. Heerlijk genoten in 't Park. Wel voldoende water meenemen. Zeker tijdens de hittegolf die wij daar hadden

title: Super Tiersichtungen
text: Wir waren einen Tag mit Abraham unterwegs. Super Guide, tolle Sichtungen. Der Ausflug hat sich auf jeden Fall gelohnt und war eines unserer Highlights!

title: Koniecznie!
text: Mnóstwo zwierząt, w ciągu 6 godzin zobaczyliśmy całą wielką piątkę! Koniecznie , ale nie ma gwarancji zobaczenia zwierząt , dużo kurzu , trzeba mieć dobrego  przewodnika.

title: Una esperienza indimenticabile!
text: Sei notti in tenda nelle riserve del Botswana. In piedi alle sei e via in fuoristrada alla ricerca dei big five!

title: Unvergessliche Momente
text:
Wir haben eine mokoro Bootsfahrt in das Okavango Delta mit einem tollen Guide erlebt, diese Flora und Fauna ist einfach unbeschreiblich 
Ein Höhepunkt unserer Afrika Reise

title: La vera Africa
text:
Immersi nella natura per più di 5 giorni.
Dormire in un campo tendato, sentendo gli animali (elefanti, impala e iene) che camminano intorno: una esperienza indimenticabile.
Abbiamo scoperto la natura selvaggia, con animali di ogni tipo proprio accanto a noi. 
Un’esperienza indimenticabile!

title: Moremi
text: Moremi safari alanı Botsvana da küçük bir alan hayvan çeşitliliği bizim şansımıza çok düşüktü . Bol bol kudu gördük.

title: 沢山の動物達に、出会えました。
text: 初めてのアフリカ・サファリでしたが、感動の体験でした。希少動物にも、出会えて満足でした。朝夕は、肌寒い位のなのでアフリカのイメージも良い意味で、意外でした。英語は、パーフェクトに通じます。むしろヨーロッパより通じる感じです。お勧めします。

title: Sehenswerter Park, aber nicht der schönste in Botswana
text:
Wir hatten heute einen FULL-DAY Game Drive im Moremi Game Reserve.
Die vielfältigkeit der Tiere ist hier größer wie im Chobe National Park, allerdings bei weitem nicht so dicht besiedelt.
Um alle big Five sehen zu können braucht man schon etwas Glück und vor allem Zeit. Da wirt's mit einem Tag schon knapp.

Trotz alle dem ein sehr empfehlenswerter Park um seine Liste der big Five zu verfollständigen oder einfach mal einen Tag auf Pirschfahrt zu gehen.

title: formidable
text: Superbe endroit nature préservée et de nombreux animaux facilement observables. Venez au lever du soleil pour les traces d'animaux sur la piste. Le Botzwana est un des meilleurs endroits pour de vrais safaris

title: Tältsafari i bushen!
text: Fantastisk natur! Vi hade förmånen att få se många lejon och vilda hundar som är sällsynta. Fem av hundarna jagade ner en Lechwe antilop i floden och fick till sin förvåning se en 4 meters krokodil sno deras byte!

photos.caption: Fyra vildhundar undrar: Var tog antilopen vägen?? Krokodilen tog den!
Herr och fru Lejon i Moremi
Två lejon och en unge Moremi

title: Cool Sunday
text: A very good and relaxing resort in the outskirts of the Capital City Gaborone. Good for family's with cool vibes. A place with swimming pools and rides

photos.caption: A very good and relaxing resort in the outskirts of the Capital City Gaborone. Good for a family retreat with cool vibes.

placeInfo.name: Lion Park Resort
placeInfo.address: Portion 184, Portion 12 Crocodile Pools No. 15-KO, Gaborone Botswana

title: Sun and fun
text: It’s a really fun place to be.. water was clear, they allow food and drinks. Queues not too long. Would bring back the kids. Have 4/5 because the aesthetics is very old. rides look rusty so a bit investment in the look I would give it 5/5

placeInfo.name: Lion Park Resort
placeInfo.address: Portion 184, Portion 12 Crocodile Pools No. 15-KO, Gaborone Botswana

title: Not as good as you probably remember it
text:
I remember this place from back in the day, good quality and service. However, I would not recommend now as only 2 rides were functional (but still in very bad condition), no seating and no shade available as well. The staff tried their best to help us but it was clear that they were overworked and not receiving any help from management. 

Wish management would step up and provide some much needed maintenance.

placeInfo.name: Lion Park Resort
placeInfo.address: Portion 184, Portion 12 Crocodile Pools No. 15-KO, Gaborone Botswana

title: Old unsafe rides
text: If you like vintage this is the park for you. Time stod still here, the rides are very old and one would wonder about security . Very small kids were riding , terrified!!! No age restriction??? .Not  all were working. Bigger kids seemed to have fun since I guess thats the best there is to find here.  I read good reviews about the rides, I guess there are from people that never experienced anything better. Those rides would never be allowed in Europe. We sow to lions.Lots of kids in the pools, water is low, 2-3 water rides that kids seem to enjoy

placeInfo.name: Lion Park Resort
placeInfo.address: Portion 184, Portion 12 Crocodile Pools No. 15-KO, Gaborone Botswana

title: Lions are amazing
text:
The lions are the best attraction there! They are so big, well fed. Rollercoaster and wave pool was fun. Price affordable.
After visiting other theme parks around the world, I can see the kids rides are unsafe. The teacup ride and Dumbo ride need safety chains so the kids don't fall out. Can't expect a kid not to try and stand up. Especially that the staff said it was safe for my 1 yr to go on the ride alone??? They need stricter age restrictions or I can see a litigation in the future.

placeInfo.name: Lion Park Resort
placeInfo.address: Portion 184, Portion 12 Crocodile Pools No. 15-KO, Gaborone Botswana

title: Had a great time with family
text: Lovely activities and a nice clean location. The rides were under maintenance when we went but otherwise it was a lovely experience. The change rooms are also spacious and clean. The rollercoaster ride was nice too. The best part was the lions. You can take selfies and see the lions up close.

placeInfo.name: Lion Park Resort
placeInfo.address: Portion 184, Portion 12 Crocodile Pools No. 15-KO, Gaborone Botswana

title: Nice day out place for family!
text:
This is 3rd time i'm visiting and good times of joy with family.
Kids will enjoy the water slides and wave pool.
Roller coaster is sleek and good thrill.

placeInfo.name: Lion Park Resort
placeInfo.address: Portion 184, Portion 12 Crocodile Pools No. 15-KO, Gaborone Botswana

title: Had a Great Time the Second Time Around!
text: I would recommend this place for families, it’s a great time to spend together and their rides, pools and entertainment caters for children of all ages as well as adults. I love the idea of it being in a bush as it gives it that “the best of both worlds” feel. It’s also very close to Gabs and the roads are good now with less traffic in and out of Gabs. I would recommend taking note of the times for being on certain rides or viewing times for lions as we ended up not seeing the lions because we missed the viewing times.

placeInfo.name: Lion Park Resort
placeInfo.address: Portion 184, Portion 12 Crocodile Pools No. 15-KO, Gaborone Botswana

title: A Nice Way to Spend an Afternoon
text: We wanted to male vacation good for our grand children. This was a cool place to visit. Great rides, a water park with a wave pool, and let's not forget the lions; five of them quite close by.  A worthwhile stop on our journey.

placeInfo.name: Lion Park Resort
placeInfo.address: Portion 184, Portion 12 Crocodile Pools No. 15-KO, Gaborone Botswana

title: LIONS!!!!!

placeInfo.name: Lion Park Resort
placeInfo.address: Portion 184, Portion 12 Crocodile Pools No. 15-KO, Gaborone Botswana

title: It is not a park full of lions

Bar facilities available. They do not accept South Africa rand at this place, debit, credit cards accepted or Pula. There are lions in an enclosure to view and take photos.

placeInfo.name: Lion Park Resort
placeInfo.address: Portion 184, Portion 12 Crocodile Pools No. 15-KO, Gaborone Botswana

title: The beach in the bush
