placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Don't miss, well worth your time!
text: We stayed 3 nights here and were lucky enough to be allowed to stay on site camp grounds not allows the case as many times the local camp staff have problems with visitors leaving trash in the camp grounds or taking candle light parties into the hills at night, never a good idea. Get a local guide here and stretch your legs!

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Lovely site to visit
text: The most amazing Bushman paintings are to be seen here. It does require some walking but it is well worth the effort.

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: A must visit
text: You can now get to the hills with a reasonable 2WD vehicle and it is worth the trouble - employ a local guide and buy beads from the Basarwa kids

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Very hot but absolute beautiful
text: We arrived in teh morning with already 43 degrees. So we got a very friendly and knowing guide and walked only at the bottom to see a few rockpaintings. Really stunning! Will come back during the cooler season and do the trails!

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Dangerous Campsite!
text: We went in the Campsite (very expensive!). The man at reception said us we were alone. At night we heard a car coming....we did not feel safe, so suddenly we decided to go away in the night! The car coming was full of young boys. Who were them? It was a very bad experience, pay attention!!!!!

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: The sign stated Tsodilo Hills, but the gate was chained and padlocked with no one in the gate house to ask.
text: After 33km of travelling on a 'dirt' road, we saw the Tsodilo Hills signs pointing to the right to a short dead end.  There was a gate clearly stating, Tsodilo Hills, but the gate was chained and padlocked with no one in sight.  It was 12.45 on a Saturday, and seeing no other signs or notices to the contrary, we just went back the 33km to the main road.  Apparently, this is the óld' gate.  The new gate is further on -and round the corner to the right, but when asking for directions, before we set off, no one mentioned the old and new gate!  Bit of a waste of time, fuel and was not very pleasant driving on the poor road surface.  Disappointed and felt a bit thick, that we hadn't thought to explore a bit further on.  I think that the road's condition had put us in a fairly out of sorts mood!  To add to our mood was the fact that although we had found diesel at a garage in Shakawe, the amount it took to fill the car seemed excessive compared to the car's fuel usage, by 11 litres!  Seriously! Of course they would only take cash.  The rest of our holiday was so fantastic.  This is just a small moan, but I don't want anyone else to make the same mistake we did.

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Beautiful art, terrible conditions
text: As an UNESCO heritage site it has some beautiful rock art. The guide date good but every walk is asleep rate fee of 120 pula. You can only do one walk per fee. The road about the visitor centre is truly awful. No one is looking after the place. I even collected plastic walking about and the guide looked amazed that someone would collect rubbish. Camp site has water at rate times and the cost of 400 pula to camp as a family is ridiculous. The boy at the front gate had a terrible attitude. No omegas any interest at in the site and it's disappointing that there are no longer san people near the mountain as they were all removed by the government in 2008 toa local village. The guides are all Bantu and the rock art is not from  their  people. I would love to have had a San guide to make it a more authentic experience. Have a look but do not plan a stay over. Also, donkeys are all over the place which is also not good. UNESCO need to review the current strategy of this wonderful site.

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: If you came this far, don't miss this heritage sight.
text: We took a guided walk around Tsodilo hills.  I felt for the guide because we were quite a large group, but she struggled to engage the group.  Rock paintings are very interesting, and restroom facilities clean.  Worth a visit.

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: lame rocks
text: Terrible excursion. UNESCO Heritage Site, so you shuldn't have to pay, but they charge an entrance fee and make you take a guide. The guide we had was terrible, spoke poor english and was not very knowledgeable. The paintings look fake, and the place is poorly maintained and poorly run. Not worth the trip. I was really excited to go, but it was piss poor all around.

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Campsite not up to standard for a Unesco Worl Heritage site
text: When we arrived we were told that the campsite at the visitors centre was not open and had to camp in the community camp area far from the centre. Donkey and cow dung everywhere, no hot shower although solar installation, and at times no water. We did not even feel like venturing the bad road back to the visitors centre to see the rock paintings. So sad to see the disinterest and lack of pride by the local people in what could be a fantastic destination. The price for camping and entrance are exorbitant for what one gets.  Not a place that I would recommend to visit.

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Quite interesting
text: It is interesting to see the presumed bushman paintings, I do however have my reservations as to whom actually panted the paintings, really....in the middle of a arid place...why would there be a picture of penguins and whales... made me think. The road there is unpaved, and corrugated but quite ok. The people there are very friendly and helpfull

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Expensive campsite and nobody cares about the clients...
text: The campsite was moved from the foot of the mountain to about 3 km away where you can't really see the mountain. You're in the middle of the bush, so the landscape is not very interesting. There are showers and toilets close to the campsite. I spent one night there with 3 friends. When we got from the Cliff walk at night we tried to take a shower but surprise : NO HOT WATER!!! The next morning we tried to take a shower again and, surprise number two : NO WATER AT ALL!!! No even to wash out our faces! When we left the place we talked to the lady at the entrance ( which is probably the only person you can talk to if there is a problem ) and she really didn't seem to mind. There is a HUGE discrepancy between the abusively high campsite prices and the quality of service provided by the people in charge.

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Unique rock art on some magical hills
text: The rock art at this site is unique and quite amazing, I advise getting up early to try and see as much as possible. The caves are beautiful too and a great place to reflect on the history of the ancient site. It's best to catch the guides on their first walk of the day, they'll be more likely to take you to the less accessible places (they spend the whole day walking). I went late on in the day and the guide definitely didn't take me the whole way around but I was too tired to care after a long day. There are different routes you can take, most of them costing 120 Pula, the most expensive one being 175 Pula. There is a campsite right next to the entrance which is 130 Pula pppn for camping and 50 Pula entrance fee to the hills. The entrance gate is about 5km from the hills and it's best to just follow the side fence until you can see a track taking you towards the smaller hills. Make sure to charge all your equipment before you go and take a couple of spare toilet rolls. I travelled there without a vehicle. It's around 30km from the main tarmac road and so quite far to walk. I was lucky and waited at the road for ten minutes before a truck came and so I got on the back of that which took me to the main gate for 10 Pula. I wasn't as lucky on the way back though and waited for four hours, but I got there eventually. If you're travelling alone, with no vehicle or a time limit, travelling here is definitely something you can do, despite what people may tell you. Well worth a visit if you're in the Caprivi Strip or in Maun.

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Well worth the visit
text: We really enjoyed our visit to Tsodilo Hills. Seeing the cave paintings was amazing. We can't imagine who created these amazing painting.

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: A penguin in the rock art
text: I was blown away by the quality of the rock art; some of the best I've seen (especially the eland).. What was even more astounding was the panel with the whales and the penguin - that the people who painted them had been more than a 1000km west of the site at some stage is incredible.. You preferably need a robust vehicle to get there, but if you've got several hours to kill and you are capable of at least a 2.5 hour walk on the shortest trail (the rhino), then pay a visit.

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Spectacular Rock Art
text:
I recommend that a 4x4 vehicle is used as the road condition varies depending on the weather. Ensure that you confirm the directions both to the site and when leaving as the signage is poor and if in doubt rather back track than getting stuck in deep sand or mud.

There is an entrance fee at the gate and an additional fee for the tour guide. Our guide was informative but the rest of the visitor centre, museum and facilities needs general maintenance and good management to be implemented to ensure longevity of the facility.

Our groups age ranged from 14yrs - 64yrs (with a hip replacement and a non-gym member). We all did the harder trail up to the top of the hill. But what goes up must come down and the decline had to be well negotiated as we had been caught in the rain (rocks where a little slippery). We all made it down safely, but ensure that you are medically fit and up for the challenge. There is an easier bottom route as an alternative. If its going to be a hot day ensure that you get an early start to the tour before the heat of the day.

Remember your sun block, hat, camera (small backpack/water tight camera bag in the event it rains and to ensure the safety of your valuables i.e. mobile phone) while clambering down the rocks as in some places you need to assist yourself by holding onto a rock/branch/tree. Take along a (small) water bottle.

Take a picnic basket and camping chairs with you and leave it in your locked vehicle for a nice snack after the guided tour.

The toilet facilities did not have toilet paper, soap or lights the day we visited (take your head lamp with you/torch) and due to the power failure we could not look around the museum.

The hills are a comparatively small group of isolated quartzite inselbergs (from German: Insel, “island,” and Berg, “mountain”) and can be seen from up to 100km's away and are situated in the heart of the Great Central Plateau of Southern Africa in Botswana, which is a very flat country in the African context. 
Located on the edge of the Kalahari Desert, in the extreme north-west of Botswana, close to the Namibian border. The outcrop also known as the "male, female and child" is 40 kilometres west of the main road - near Shakawe.

The occurrence of inselbergs implies immense variations in the rates of degradational activity on the land surface. These structures are one of several varieties of landform called paleoforms that can survive with little modification for tens of millions of years. 

Tsodilo hills has over 4,500 rock art paintings depicting a variety of subjects, including wild animals, people, cattle (introduced in the 6th century AD), riders on horses (1850's) and other domestic animals and various geometric symbols and designs (1000 years old), with the latest paintings dating to the 19th century.

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Remote and a bit disappointing
text: Tsodilo Hills is, beside the newly added Okavango Delta the only UNESCO site in Botswana. It is situated in the far northeast and very remote. It took us a three hour drive to get there. It is poorly indicated (we had to ask a few local children the way for the last 6 kilometer, a horrible experience over the very bad roads. Don't turn around, eventually you will get there. After this trip we got to the visitor centre with a small museum. Hiring a guide is compulsory. Maybe we had the wrong guide (uninterested in us) but he showed us all the carvings and paintings. Nevertheless interesting to witness the remnants of early human settlement in this area.

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Tsodilo Hills is not to be missed
text: This is an outstanding World Heritage Site. The heritage that this site embodies must be protected for the enjoyment of future generations. The work that has been done so far is wonderful, but the site deserves much better attention from the authorities. The museum is pathetic. Our guide was a lovely person but could convey little more than what you would find on a pamphlet. The pamphlets and maps were out of stock (apparently for some time). The access road from the main road to the museum is shamefully inadequate. Where is the ministry of tourism in all this?

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Highest point in Botswana
text: Remote and remarkable for the thousands of wall paintings.. this is a World Heritage area. We chose to try to climb the highest hill known as the father.. it was hot, rough and steep. We gave up and rested just 20 minutes from the top while our daughter leapt on upwards with our guide. Going down was harder than going up and we had happy sore muscles next day. Botswana being so flat, it was terrific to be a little higher and to see the curve of the earth around us.

placeInfo.name: Tsodilo Hills
placeInfo.address: Near Sepupa Northwest Botswana, Shakawe Botswana

title: Awesome wildlife here
text: We did see a lot of wildlife here living in and loving nature. A definite must do.  A great place to have a sundowner

title: Leopard area
text: I have been fortunate to see 10 leopards in the Khwai area within 3 days. Getting there is best done by air, but a 4 wheel drive vehicle is needed and a drive from Maun take 4 hours for 140kms.

title: A total wild experience, but totally safe with your ranger by your side
text: Experience on Khwai River is what you usually see on BBC Documentaries !!! The only exception is that you can hear noises, wind on your face and smells ( and often it's your adrenalin ) . Leopards on trees not far than 3 meters from you, Hyppos on the road especially at sunset are totally but rare, Giraffes, hyenas and buffalos complete the collection. Every camp you will chose ( mine was Khwai River Lodge ) will assist with the best rangers of the world. They will introduce you in a wild world tiptoeing, and will explain the delicate balances that rule something we still have in our DNA after 50.000 years.

title: Camps on either side of the bridge!
text: The Khwai River borders the Moremi Game Reserve in the North-East.  Although the Moremi Campsite is on the river itself, it is rather costly for foreign visitors to camp there.  On the northerly side of the bridge is Khwai Village, which has a community camp.  The community camps do not differentiate in price between SADC citizens and foreigners, unlike the Botswana Game Reserve that contracts out all accommodation the reserves  which is  expensive for foreigners compared to SADC citizens.  It would pay foreigners to rather stay at community camps and go into the Reserves daily. There is not differentiation in the entry cost for SADC and foreigners to Botswana reserves.

title: Fantastic!
text:
My wife and I recently stayed 4 nights here . The accommodation is excellent with wonderful views over the river. From the large deck we had superb views of elephants , hippos and a wide variety of wonderful Birdline. The food was also excellent and the staff were all so very friendly and helpful . A huge thankyou to our guide , Richard , who was superb . He gave us so many exceptional wildlife sightings of elephants, lions , leopards as well as a fascinating pack of wild dogs . We also enjoyed the wonderful singing and dancing performed at the bomb evenings. 
Fantastic experience- we would love to return before too long .

title: Real "bush" experience
text:
We were in Khwai for 2 nights. This was the starting point for our safari and boy did it give us the best possible start for our trip! The geography of the place is stunning with the beautiful Khwai river serving as a backdrop to all possible kind of birds and animals - hippos (hundreds), impalas, lechwes, kudus, hyenas, giraffes, elephants and also lions.
Lots of birds too. One does need a guide to enjoy this place though - we did see some vehicles who were attempting self drives. Experienced guides with their excellent knowledge of the topography, climate, sharp eyesight and the senses can give one much more in a safari.
Khwai shall not disappoint.

title: Elephant crossing
text: We saw a large herd of elephant crossing whilst we stopped on this rather rickety wooden bridge, all part of the experience in this area of the delta.

title: the bridge is worth the picture
text: the bridge and surroundings are worth the drive, from there you can go further into Moremi , Kwai village has not much to offer and little to do for tourists.

title: Okavango Delta Experience
text: This entire area has an abundance of wildlife and is one of the great place on Earth to visit. I'll let the photos do the talking!

title: outstanding sighting
text: My visit to khwai was outstanding as usual. I was on a business trip with my friends just to see the routes and also new camps in the area. our 1 night at Magotlho campsite we saw loads of animals, lions, giraffes, leopard and general game. We also decided to do a night drive and a walk to the village and interact with people. I love Khwai. Great sightings every day. The Bridge also was new and it has a nice view

title: New Wooden Bridge Guarded by Baboons
text: The bridge was interesting, quite new as the old collapsed bridge has been replaced.  It offered a nice view of the sunset and was guarded by a large troupe of baboons.

title: Yes, we whistled the movie song
text: The bridge is made of telephone poles running across the river. One day on our return to camp, baboons were dragging a dead baby around and would not let us cross for about ten minutes. A learning experience about baboon behavior.

title: Great sightings
text: As part of my trip to Moremi, Khwai River Bridge was part of it and between the 2, split by the river I saw the best of all sightings I had in Botswana. Lots of Leopards, Lions, wild dogs etc etc.

title: I wish we could've stayed here longer
text: During our safari, we camped in Moremi, Khwai, Savuti and Chobe.  Khwai was by far my favorite in terms of the nice river that ran through it and the views of the wildlife.  The river means that you get to see the "prey" animals hang out by the water on a regular basis...including lots of elephants and hippos.  But it also means lots of "predator" animal sightings as well.  We got to watch two lions "arguing" over territory and also saw a leopard mother (Mma Tsebe) and her two year old son hanging out and gnawing on a red lechwe that they had killed (we saw them over two separate days and felt very blessed).  If you are planning a safari (either on your own or with a tour group, be sure that it includes a stop in Khwai!!

title: First time at Safari Lodge
text:
This lodge is very good.  I found the atmosphere to be very friendly and the staff well informed and helpful. 
Our guide was Johnson and he made our safari excursions exciting and memorable.  He is a very well  informed guide who easily answered and questions we had. 
The staff at the lodge are happy to accommodate groups from what I could see. We saw four of the big five here.  The highlight for me was seeing a leopard. 
The accommodation and food were excellent! I would definitely return to this lodge.

title: Trip of a lifetime
text: Absolutely wonderful place.  Wildlife was incredible. Guide was astoundingly knowledgeable.  Food was wonderful and the camp setting is just beautiful

title: Excellent Reserve
text: The Kwai River Reserve is excellent and has a wide and intact wildlife. You will probably get to see all expected African animals. But it is not a zoo and a little luck is needed.

title: Awesome Campsite ! Fantastic game around. Please protect it and dont abuse.
text:
Was here during our epic trip to Chobe from Moremi via Khwai and Savuti. We stayed at K2 close to the wooden bridge and the river ofcourse.

What a campsite mannnnnn?

Hippos making noise, Hyenas & Spotted genets walking around and the Honey Badger coming straight into the middle of our chairs looking for something and freak the "Sxxx" out of us. 

Later when we go to sleep we have all of these walking around and fighting with each other while we watch from the tent. Did not have any safety issues, but the adrenaline and thrill to live with the wild is priceless and Khwai is one exceptionally beautiful place.

title: Khwai river - hidden treasure
text:
We visited th Khwai Region while driving from Chobe NP Mababe (South) Gate to the Moremi North Gate. Despite the new gravel road, we tried to get as much Khwai river front experience as possible. This was quite difficult because of high water and the main track flooded in many places. But it was very worthwhile, as we spotted many animals, mainly herds of zebras, elephants, girafes an many hippos. Highlight for me was the opportunity to watch elephants bathing and diving in the river and playing with each other in the water.
The many tracks are difficult to navigate and in parts quite deep sandy. But it is very rewarding to take the effort and to stay as close as possible to the river. Avoid water crossings, especially if you do not see how deep they are and what the ground Looks like. If you have bad luck, you can easily dump your car in the river ...

title: Wonderful campsite with good albutions
text: Wonderful campsite with really good ablution facilities that are spotlessly clean.  Great location on the river.  Hyena at night are a problem and baboons during the day can also be an issue. Beautiful drives from the camp.

title: Respect for others in the bush
text: What an experience! You will need a 4x4 vehicle here, and to be travelling together with at least one other vehicle. Also,you will need recovery gear like a long reach jack, tow rope, axe, etc. Definitely a first aid kit, anti malaria tablets and sufficient provisions. Always stop to assist others and hope for the same. This is the real raw African bush and you can expect to be in the same space as lions,buffalo, elephants and other dangerous animals, insects,snakes and things. But you will feel ALIVE like never before and the only stress will be healthy survival awareness. One of the precious places in my heart, also because of thecproximity of the San bushmen. Do this!! Even ifvit is the only thing you do.

title: Kwai river bridge
text:
A must see and it is a breath taking experience
Always try to be at least two vehicles you might need help

title: Great wildlife viewing
text: Despite there being less water than usual at this time of year, the wildlife viewing in this location was exceptional and we also looked at birds, insects, dragonflies and butterflies, and plants.

title: The best experience ever!
text:
It was our first time camping in the open, in unfenced camp. We were verry nervous but now we can never camp in a camped site again. The experience of feeling one with nature, not seeing or hearing anything besides lions, hippos and hyeans  was life changing. Make no mistake we were vigilant but never had any hair raising experiences.

There are no facilities here so make sure you have enough water, food and fuel. 

Sitting and watching elephants and hippos playing no more than 40 m from our camp in the water was incredible. Make sure you get to experience this.

We also saw more animals in one afternoon on a game drive in Khai than we saw in. Moremi. Next time I might stay at Third. Bridge for one night and the rest in Khwai. It was that good!

title: Interesting sight
text: Traveled across the "new" bridge into Moremi gam reserve.  The old bridge was right beside it, now in ruins.  The bridge was fun and at the gateway to the main attraction!

title: Saw lions and wild dog...
text:
It doesn't get much better than that when the place is flooded and the grass is jungle.

We stayed in the campsites and hippos took to shuffling through our camp.

The village on other side of the road has an old lady who is the town baker. Her bread can be found in the little hut with an embossed 'quench' on the front (you'll see). 

The bridge and the areas around were flooded and it made for exciting 4wding.

title: Khwai campsites
text: Khwai village is located just outside Moremi National Park, home to Okavango Delta. If you want true nature connection camp at Mogotho campsites. No toilets or running water you take what you bring! This place is like having a home zoo; close by there is a hippo pool, and more big 5 crew. For those into birds you will not be disappointed too. Good balance for everyone.

title: Steel bridge over the river Khwai
text: An amazing structure safe and solid.. over the river Khwai - and certainly not to be confused with the bridge over the river Kwai at Kanchanaburi  in Thailand, known as the death railway built by the Japanese during WW2

title: A few glitches but very good
text: It wasn't the hotels fault as such, but the very high temperatures obviously put a strain on the air con in the tents and we sweltered both at night and day.  Another fantastic location in the Delta with terrific staff.  Food was good but not as much choice as at Eagle Island and Savute although all part of Orient Express.  Fantastic game drives with plenty to see.  Cooling off in the pool would have been great but it was in the full glare of the sun with no shade, which was a pity.  Shortly to close for a month for renovation so maybe the aircon will be upgraded.

title: Its much harder than it looks
text: But before that you had to cross a river by its bottom, which was not on the map. And it was even more fun!

title: one of the most interesting bridge crossings ever.........
text: This bridge really does remind you you are in the middle of no where, standing above the water, surrounded by fantastic birdlife, I even saw  Genet! whoa!

title: Viagem dos quase 60 anos
text:
Local mágico em frente a um rio cheio de animais. 
Serviço e simpatia cinco estrelas. permanente.
Nosso tracker Rio ficou parte da familia.
Vimos.de bebés leões a hipopótamos bebês. 
Once in a life time
Ricardo

title: Herrlich für Tierbeobachtungen
text: Die Stelle ist perfekt für Tierbeobachtungen, vor allem wenn die Umgebung sehr trocken ist. Dennoch: Abstand halten!

title: Leopardo nel cuore
text: Abbiamo fatto ogni specie di safari in questa zona ma lo spettacolo del leopardo con la sua preda resterà per sempre indelebile nel nostro cuore e nella nostra testa. Grandissima varietà di animali d ammirare in tutte le circostanze della giornata

title: extraordinario
text: No sabía gran cosa del Delta del Okavango hasta que en este mes viajamos a Sudafrica, Namibia, Zimbawue, Zambia y Botsuana y pudimos hacernos una idea de la magnitud de este ecosistema inédito y peculiar; un río que no muere en el mar sino que termina, formando un falso delta, engullido-escondido-desaparecido en las secas tierras del desierto de Kalahari.

title: Experiencia a la intemperie
text:
Muy pocos sitios en el mundo te dan la oportunidad de acampar en medio de la naturaleza de la forma que se puede hacer en Kwai. Aquí no hay vallas, no hay guardas, no hay nada entre tú y la naturaleza. 
Nosotros acampamos en Kwai River Bridge, en el único camping (excluyendo los lodges de lujo, claro) que hay. Y son como 10 sitios, con 1 poco de cemento para hacer hoguera, con un grifo para el agua y unos baños comunes que tienen agua caliente por disponer de placas solares. Por supuesto, no hay luz. El acceso es complicado, hay muchos bancos de arena y a veces se inundan, por lo que un buen 4x4 es no recomendable, pero obligatorio.
La emoción de irse a dormir pronto, al poco de caer la luz y antes de que se apague tu hoguera, de ver y oir a los animales, a veces a uno o dos metros de tí, no tiene precio.
Eso sí, no vayan con niños.

title: Puente de acceso o salida a/de North Gate
text: El  puente esta ubicado en 19°10'18.6"S 23°45'04.3"E. Es un sitio muy típico que recordaras por su estructura. Debes pasar despacio lo cual es de agradecer ya que es un punto agradable para ver avistamientos en el río. La zona esta llena de vida salvaje

title: lodge de grande classe
text: le plus beaux du voyage , vue insaisissable presque tous les animaux visibles ( sauf le léopard trop bien caché)

title: Prachtige omgeving
text: Op onze doorreis in Botswana zijn we ook in dit prachtig gebied gekomen. Het wild is soms lastig te spotten, maar dan zijn er weer open stukken waar je van alles kunt tegenkomen. Van giraffen, tot zebra's en als je geluk hebt, leeuwen die lekker liggen te zonnen.

title: Мост
text: Ездили в путешествии по Ботсване, видели много слонов, гиппопотамов, диких кошек вдали, птиц, насекомых.

title: Fantastisch speziell wenn es in anderen Teilen sehr trocken ist
text: Wenn es in der Gegend sehr trocken ist und lange nicht geregnet hat ziehen sich die Tiere an den Fluss zurück. Hier kann man alles sehen, was zu sehen ist.Die Wege sind zwar nur in richtigen 4x4 Fahrzeugen zu bewältigen aber man kommt hautnah an die Tiere heran, denn es gibt immer einen Pfad auf dem man noch näher herankommt. Aufpassen auf Verbotsschilder, hier sollte man auf keinen Fall weiterfahren, denn die privaten, extrem teuren Gamelodges verstehen da keinen Spass.

title: Wat kan de wereld toch mooi zijn
text: Prachtige natuur, geweldige rivier die vele dieren aantrekt. De rivierdoorsteek bleek echter in augustus nog aan de diepe kant.....

title: Ospiti della natura
text: Due notti passate in tenda per godere delle fantastiche visioni che il delta offre. Game walk e giri in mokoro per immergersi in uno spettacolo fantastico. Il game walk (passeggiata a piedi) permette di vedere elefanti, zebre, giraffe nel loro habitat. Da non perdere i tramonti sia in mokoro che a piedi uno spettacolo della natura che non ha eguali.

title: Non è un vero ponte, ma è suggestivo
text: Indimenticabile: accoppiamento dei leoni. Non bisogna a tutti i costi cercare qualche animale... ascoltare il " silenzio"  e farsi prendere dai colori e dagli odori della savana è un ottimo wash out

title: VIVERE IN  UN DOCUMENTARIO,,,
text:
Una  vacanza  qui  è  come  un  continuo  documentario  a  due  metri  di  s
distanza  da  te!!
si  vede  di  tutto,  animali  che  dormono  ,  fanno  l'amore  o  si  azzannano  o  vanno  a caccia  ,  o  pascolano  tranquilli,  zebre  ,  leoni  ,  elefanti,  ippopotami ,  rimoceronti , anche  in  campeggio  la  notte  si  sentono  le  ... urla  della  foresta.... un  esperienza  primordiale  da  fare  in  campeggio  ,  qui  non  sono  chiusi  conme  in  Namibia  ,  si  e  veramente  a  stretto  contatto  con  gli  animali...  come  l'uomo  primitivo!!  Bellissimo

title: best thing to do in Gabs, what isn't saying much....
text: Mixt feelings; bad roads and works at several places, so bad that even our new Landrover Defender had some difficulties with all the mud. But very friendly people at the gate and lots of animals to see. We were here for the second time in two years and never have we seen so easily water monitor lizards has here, and eland antilope for exemple.

title: A great experience, great views, connecting with nature.
text: The site of different species of animals in the area.  I saw zebras and others 😁. I would really recommend this place while you in Gaborone. I feel you can to connect with nature, the quietness, the animals and its well taken care of. No litter around the place. I would love to go back for camping now 😊. The entrance fees are reasonable as well

title: A very cheap and exciting afternoon
text: We saw lots of animals. For ex. we have never seen so many nile monitors. And even very close. We had a 2W drive car and that was sometimes tricky though (it had rained a few days)

title: Was not very impressed.
text: Not much to see and the staff were not helpful at all.  Found the reserve very neglected.  We spent about 2 hours there and littering seems to be a big problem.  Lots of empty beer bottles etc.  Saw a few aminals, but really nothing much else

title: Beautiful scenery and wildlife
text:
We thoroughly enjoyed our visit, unfortunately some reviews mentioned you can walk around which was our plan but it’s not allowed so we paid our taxi driver to take us around.
It’s been raining recently so the colours were amazing. Animals look so healthy and thriving. Everything was bright green with rich red earth. 
Probably the best value adventure in Africa

title: Gaborone Game Reserve, An In-The-City-Safari
text: The Gaborone Game Reserve is an excellent place for people who don't want to or can't take game drives in the north. Except for the Big 5, there are many African animals roaming free in natural surroundings but all within the city limits. because there are no predators, picnicking is allowed and you can bike or walk the trails. Take time to look and you will see and hear many wonderful birds. This is a great and cheap way to spend a day in Gaborone.

title: Not a must see place
text: The setting is perfect .... right in the heart of Gaborone, a wildlife reserve.  Sadly, the place has hardly any animals worthy of a game drive.  The picnic spots are good ... one can braai for the group...  unfortunately, the monkeys are a menace ... pouncing on the picnic food.

title: beautiful, untapped nature
text: the reserve still holds an undisturbed natural appeal.the picnic sites are the only facilities which seemed foreign but even they blend in with the whole place.

title: pity, but has potential!
text: small game reserve, which certainly has potential as a nearby learning center, even for local citizens. However, the entry fee is so very low (approx. 10 pula equivalent to about US $ 1.-), you may not expect any proper maintenance. At the more remote spots, of the reserve, human garbage is accumulating, and it really is a pity, to see nothing more is done to improve on the nice collection of endemic species (Zebra, Eland, Ostrich, Warthog, various bird species etc. My advise: Clean up your act, increase price dramatically, so you can have some proper improvements done, invite your local pupils to learn about the beauty of Africa!

title: Great little self drive mornjng
text: Well we just loved this, paid just 30 Pula which is just over two pounds in GBP. No real facilities apart from a picnic area, but we just drove round randomly on unpaved but decent tracks. No big beasts to be seen, but plenty on impala, zebra, ostriches, warthog, kudus,quail,oxpeckers,maribou and a few others I've forgotten. A splendid couple of hours.

title: Bush not far from the city
text: GGR is very close to where we stayed. We took an afternoon drive here and saw many species of birds and animals. We did not have enough time to visit the bigger game areas of Botswana, but this was a sample.

title: Nice self drive
text: Good place to visit if you have time to spare in Gaborone. Good self drive and you see quite a lot of smaller animals (antelope, zebras, monkeys, warthogs,...). Cheap entrance fee and picnic area.

title: Good spot to see animals
text: A very good place to see wildlife. On the down side theres not much else going on there. There is a picnic spot with a few chairs. it could do with a bit more development.

title: Self drive delight
text: Although this park does not have the big five it contains a fabulous variety of wild animals. It costs only a few Pula to enter and you drive around at your own pace. The roads are not metaled but reasonably smooth. You need to allow 2 to three hours to enjoy fully, stopping to take photos and watching the wildlife. You can get out and walk if you like. Be careful not to let the monkeys see food!

title: Hidden Gem in the Big City
text: The Gaborone Game Reserve is right on the perimeter of the capitol city. I was able to spend about 3 hours in the reserve unwinding from a busy work day. The park does not house the Big 5, but does have a variety of mammals, birds and reptiles. I was most impressed by the use of the park to educate local children and adults in the Gaborone area.

title: GO For Braai, enjoy the day between nature
text:
Gaborone game reserve is good option to spent a relax day to avoid city hustling. One can enjoy beautiful day with BRAAI option. Go relax, Go for BRAAI' ing.

Take a round of reserve, see few animals, birds .i.e Imphala, monkeys, ostrich, ziraffe, buffaloes

Beaware of monkeys, they will share your BRAAI food, They will snatch your food from BRAAI stands..

Note: You cannot stay after six in reserve

title: Awesome Experience
text: The experience of having a braai in the forest with animals is overwhelming. the monkeys playing all over the place.

title: Ok
text: An ok city. Am South African and i felt i was still at home same food outlets., same shops, same banks, just more expensive because of the stronger currency ,the town doesn't have much to offer

title: Hidden treasure of Gaborone
text: I literally didn't believe that Botswana has any wild animals like the lions and the giraffes etc that we have back at home.. Finding this wild animals is a hell of a task!! But once you do, you will get to enjoy the visit! Tucked away at the Gaborone Military Force since Botswana has yet to know how to handle such, the military takes care of this animals... It was simply amazing getting to see the white lions, the huge hyenas, the biggest python have ever seen and HELD! Yes I did hold a live PYTHON! One of the greatest highlight on my trip definitely!

title: Oasis in town
text: Just amazing. I have been to several game drives in Africa. Do not expect to see the big 5. But you can expect to see many other animals. And the best things are: it is very very cheap, you can drive with your own car, and there are almost no other tourists there. Highly recommendable.

title: Always a nice spot to visit for a picnic on a Saturday afternoon with the kids.
text: Always a nice spot to visit for a picnic on a Saturday afternoon with the kids. Only spoilt by certain selfish people turning their car sound systems to maximum volume. Most of us go to the bush to enjoy the animals and the peace and quiet!!!

title: fun for the children and family
text:
park is looking lovely and always tidy. staff friendly and welcoming 
fun for the children to see animals and great for a picnic

title: Small game reserve low entrance fee, good for a few hours fun
text: The Gaborone Game reserve is just around the corner in town. The entrance fee is 10BWP per person and 10 BWP for a car. You can also picnic or braai in the game reserve (at a little extra fee). Residents go here on Saturday morning to have breakfast or in the late afternoon to braai. You will encounter zebras, impalas, warthog, ostrich, kudu, monkeys and rock hyrax. It is not possible to go on foot, you will have to drive in this reserve. We went on late afternoon and drove past a group of trees and all of a sudden all of these hyrax were dropping out of the tree (they were probably eating or sunbathing). I have been to this game reserve 4 times now and it is still nice to drive around, never knowing when you will see the animals. Of course the game reserve is nothing compared to Chobe, but a nice place to go if you just need to get out of your hotel room or want to get out with the family. On weekdays entrance is easy, in the weekend you have to book in advance (as they only allow so many people in the game reserve).

title: You need to prebook to visit this destination now.
text: Gaborone Game Reserve is based in Central Gaborone.  You can see monkeys - lots of them that plague the pinic areas, zebras, waterhogs, buck and ostrich.  The park is small and easy to drive right around.  However it is necessary to make a pre-booking. Two nice pinic areas with tables and braai spots are available.

title: Take a Wild Drive in the City!
text: If you have an hour to spend in a city of Gaborone and wondering what to do.  Drive in Gaborone Game reserve.  You will be treated with Plenty of Elands, Zebras, Ostriches, Warthogs and Impalas.  Great to see these small game reserve improving in standards and stock!

title: A very nice tiny game reserve
text:
I was just a few days in Gaborone and wanted to go on a short game drive. I decided to just rent a taxi for a few hours ($10 per hour all inclusive should be fair), and got driven around in this very small, yet cute game reserve. 
Entry will be 10 Pula per person plus another 10 per vehicle. The game presented here is diverse but not dangerous. I guess that makes it a great place to visit with children: you can just exit your vehicle to go for a closer inspection of an area without running the risk of ending up as a lion's supper, as there are no lions. 
There's a picnic place or two in the center of the park and this is probably where you'll find most of the monkeys. 
I've been told that the park is usually packed with people during the weekends and holidays, so it may be worth visiting on a regular week day. When I was there, it was just me and my taxi driver, so we had the park all for our selves. Which was great. 
I recommend to spend about 2 hours here, as that's sufficient to see everything worth seeing here. 
Anyway, I really liked my drive here. If they could add a few more types of game, I'd give it a 5 star rating. For now, it's a good 4 stars.

title: Nice place
text: An exquisite, relaxed and fun place to visit with family and friends. It has interactive animals. The staff is also helpful

title: Convenient to the city but limited viewing opportunities
text: This Reserve is the most accessible to visitors to the capital city. Because the tours are self-driven it is convenient, easy, and inexpensive. Impala, kudu, and ostrich are fairly easy to locate but other species harder to find and film. Overall impression is a less well managed facility that some of the private reserves a little farther out from the city.

title: WORTH A VISIT
text: Although the rains this year have been excellent, the park suffers from chronic overgrazing during the drought years and is now full of broadleafed weeds and little grass. For some reason they have introduced booking for weekends, maybe to control the volume of picniccers. This means that game viewers have the place to themselves on Saturday and Sunday. The roads and bridges badly need attention.

title: Great day out
text: Very reasonble price to see animals and also very close to the city. We saw a wide range of animals and really enjoyed the experience, a great way to see wildlife without having to go ot on ssafari. We were able to drive around in our own car at our own pace, saw lots of interesting stuff. recommended.

title: Nice getaway
text: Very close to the city center. During the weekend you have to make a reservation. Easy accessible in a sedan car. You can easily visit the park in an hour and see some game. Nice picnic area!

title: Visit to the game reserved
text: It was a very long time ago kids were quite young.  The place is very dry and boring. Not many animals. But I don't know about now.

title: Elephants
text: It is extremely dry in the whole area and most of the animals were along the river. We saw elephants crossing the river to the plains on the inside to feed and then swim back late afternoon. It was really amazing with the little ones. Drives do not go deep into the park because it is so dry. Saw also a lot of different species of buck.

title: Is it really a reserve?
text: There isn't much I can write about this reserve. It was self -drive and I did round trip around the reserve. The roads are not all marked, I ended up on a dead end and hd to turn back, I only saw 2 Zebras, about 4 Springboks and maybe around 10 Warhogs and that was it. It really was a waste of time really.

title: DULL
text: I went there once,but there was nothing exciting about the place. its dull,dry.dusty. I only saw a couple of gazzelles

title: dry - reserve
text: we arrived on two busses - busses will struggle in this reseve as some corners are too tight and busses struggle. this reserve is currently very dry . if you are a  south afican this place is not for you too little game . advantage it is in the city .

title: Cute monkeys
text: I enjoy going to this reserve as they are not so over crowded.  There isn't that much wild but the monkeys always give you a laugh at the picnic areas which are kept very clean.

title: Quick and quirky
text: So close to the city centre, easy to find and access in any vehicle, so this is a good way to spend an hour or two. It's just P10 per person and per vehicle no matter what the nationality which makes a change from other parks. Nice viewing of Gemsbok and I had less than an hour to get around. Ostrich came close to the car. Just be careful on some of the deeply rutted tracks if you're not in a 4x4. Very dry at the moment but feed is put out and the animals look healthy with lots of baby impala to see quite close up if you approach slowly.

title: Pleasant afternoon break...
text:
The Gaborone Game Reserve is unique in that it is in the suburbs of Gaborone and easily accessible.
'The Ponds' offer good opportunity for those interested in Birding to watch and photograph plenty of water-birds, including Lesser Flamingo. Ignore any unpleasant smells please...
The drive around the reserve and within the Reserve will certainly offer opportunity to see Zebra, Impala, Kudu, Warthog, Ostrich.
A recent inconvenience is that prior booking has to be made to enter the Reserve.

title: Perfect Barbecue place
text:
Despite early closing hours- at least because there are wild animal that need peace in the evening, this is a perfect place for get togethers with several braai spot and chilling areas. During the game drive you will see several animals, Zebras and Kudus.. if lucky you can see a giraffe :)
You bring you own food and drinks for picnics. I highly recommend it.

title: Our day trip to the game reserve :)
text:
My cousin was here from Canada and we decided to take her to the game am reserve as animals in the wild fascinate all tourists when we are soo used to them:) 
At first we just saw one or two buks and it was getting quite boring until we came to a small place where they drink water that was flooded with zebras, buks, warthogs and monkeys :) 
It was absolutely beautiful :) soo green and beautiful :)

title: Average
text: The Game reserve is just  average. Its  not a bad place to host a braai. The amount of  animals also isn't  satisfactory. All in all there are much  better places in Gaborone just  as Notwane Dam.

title: Would love a revival of this area.
text:
Very well positioned reserve on the outskirts of the Eastern side of Gabs.   Rhinos were relocated years ago leaving Zebras warthogs impala ostrich monkeys and a few others.  Nice for a weekend pinic with friends.  Braai areas and pinic tables and benches are provided although they are aged. Monkeys 
are bothersome and have to be constantly monitored or else they steal your food.

title: Mr
text:
Got told to book a week before to do a game drive. Even with my own vechile? Please update your website or train your staff at the gate to explain better .
Joe

title: Nothing much to speak about
text: Pretty average game reserve, with only a few animals. Perhaps this is one of the few parks where you will not see any of the Big 5.

title: A place to visit for first time game drive
text:
Its OK for a short afternoon drive over the weekend. For anyone who took part in the real game drives its nothing to compare.
I did not picnic but did see many families do so in the designated area.

title: Wildlife and picnic
text: If you want to enjoy some relaxed quite time in the company of animals and people, thats the place. This is perfect for picnics and yet enjoy the scene of wild animals. The reserve also offers tranquil time to introspect and just enjoy the bush scene in Gaborone. Its ideal to catch up on your journal entry and yet enjoy a drink over braii(barbeque).

title: GOOD FOR BIRDING TOO
text: I enjoyed the birds more than the animals. We spent a couple of hours driving around, seeing only monkeys and beautiful birds, right until we had to leave when the zebras, warthogs and antelope (I think) decided to make their appearance. Don't expect to see loads of wildlife, but keep an eye out for some lovely birds.

title: Safe reserve close to town
text: We enjoyed our visit and saw some interesting wildlife and birds.A good trip out from the town and very cheap entry.

title: great place for picnic
text: I didn't see much though, its cheap entry, but we were unfortunate couldn't see a variety of animals only, ostrich, warthog monkeys,  and some impala

title: Well worth the climb.
text: This is a great place to go and hike. The view from the top is fab, as you can see the Gaborone Dam. It can get busy on weekend mornings and the track is narrow. Some litter which is really sad to see.

title: Morning exercise
text: Me and my wife done it for our morning exercise. What a view and look amazing from top their. Was really tiring but worth it.

title: Kgale Hill - A Medium Difficulty Hike
text: Situated on the outskirts of Gaborone (capital of Botswana) near Game City Mall, this is an ideal morning getaway especially on weekends. A short drive straight from Game City (instead of entering the mall parking) and the road turns left towards a gravel path and then again on left hand side, a makeshift parking exists, which serves as entrance to the Kgale Hill (pronounced Kaaley Hill) Public Park. Two adjacent paths can be seen, though both lead to the same first plateau with about 15-20 minutes of not-so-difficult rocky hike on granite rocks. From this plateau, a brief steep hike gets climbers to the top of first smaller hill, with a scenic view point on right hand side and a nice cool breeze. From this point, a 10 minute downhill and then a steep 15-20 minute uphill hike opens up to the top of the Kgale Hill from where Gaborone Dam and Mokolodi Nature Reserve offer beautiful views, as also the A1 highway going to Lobatse. Many people can be seen imbibing the views, doing light exercises and stretching at the hilltop. Undoubtedly, it is a popular destination for many locals and visitors, especially on weekend mornings when weather is not too hot. Children 10 years and above can complete the trail (both the hills) with enthusiasm. November and December appear to be ideal months, because of verdancy after the rains in the region. Walking path is easily noticeable and no particular tour guide is needed in this 2.5 hour (approx) adventure.

photos.caption: A1 Highway going to Lobatse in the backdrop
Up and above with granite rocks
View of Scenic Mokolodi Nature Reserve
People enjoying exercises on hilltop, with Mokolodi Nature Reserve in the backdrop

title: Awesome hike, magnificent views
text: Hiked this awesome hill for the first time in August and I will definitely be frequenting it every chance I get. There is 2 ways to hike, through the paved road or the rocky steep path (most adventurous and exciting). The air and the view is amazing once you reach the top.

title: Great view!
text: The Hills offer a great view of the city including parts of the Dam, the Quarry and the rest of the city with the backdrop of misty mountains and bushy hills at sunrise. It takes about an hour to climb to the top if you are at it (without breaks). Totally worth the climb!

title: Tougher than expected but worth the climb
text:
With a height above sea level of approx 1598 metres the total vertical climb is about 600 metres. It start fairly and then quickly becomes quite rocky and makes for a great climb. There are few routes up the hill. Take the one to left for a bit more of a rocky vertical climb or the one to the right for a flatter climb. 

Both climbs end up the top of the hill next to the phone towers and present a beautiful view over the Gabs dam and city. 

It’s definitely worth the exercise and most certainly worth the view!

title: Kgale Hills
text: Every morning I pass this hill before going to the office and coming back from the office. The hill gives you a relaxed feeling before going into the hectic city and it gives you a feeling of release when coming out of town.

title: Kgale hill popular for a picnic
text: Kgale hill is a must to climb, if you have the stamina. It's not a real easy climb, but if you are in a normal/good condition you can climb the hill. Like the hill in Oodi, this is a place where a lot of people go for a picnic when the moon is full. We did the climb after work and had a nice view on the city. Leave your jewellery and other belongings at home. Beware of baboons (we didn't encounter any, but baboons are everywhere in Africa). I wouldn't recommend this for families with very small children.

title: Nice Walk
text:
Nice Walk. Two paths to the top - when you pass the first Hill and meet a Stone With two arrows on choose the Hill on the left for the hard rock climbing style path to the top or go right to get to the semi paver Road Which takes you almost all the Way to the top 

By accident we took the rock climbing path- that was tough! 

But excellent view from the top 😊 well worth the climb

title: A snapshot of Gabs!
text: Most Batswana frequent this place for fitness purposes however it is also a great recreational place and you get an overview and a snapshot of Gaborone when you are up there and you see the dam. Make sure you go when it's not scotching hot. Mornings and late afternoons are a great time to go up but make sure you go as a group especially during the weekend or on public holidays.

title: Good for  long hikes
text: Kgale hill is quite a nice place to visit if you want  to exercise  or are just  eager to see Gaborone from a high peak.

title: Nice Walk
text:
Nice Walk. Two paths to the top - when you pass the first Hill and meet a Stone With two arrows on choose the Hill on the left for the hard rock climbing style path to the top or go right to get to the semi paver Road Which takes you almost all the Way to the top 

By accident we took the rock climbing path- that was tough! 

But excellent view from the top 😊 well worth the climb

title: The view Is majestic
text: Visited the GameCity Mall in Kgale Hill, yes it's quite a view. Wish I took pictures, the whole view is that will last in anyone's mind the mountains that tower over the buildings. Enjoyed it very well.

title: Wonderful hike...but be safe.
text:
This popular hike whilst out the way on the outskirts of Gaborone has great views and won't disappoint. 

**There are real issues of safety and muggings do happen. However if you go in a group, 3 or more, and if you go during the busier and cooler early mornings on the weekends you will be safest. 

Follow the white arrows for a good walk and small scrabble at parts (managed by almost all but those with bad hips).... otherwise there is a concrete drive up to the top just to the right of the path - BUT ask for directions as its starting location isn't easy to find otherwise.

title: Lovely hike on the outskirts of Gabarone
text: There are different options to the walk - the difficult option where you will be going on all fours over very steep terrain or the alternative is a concrete road to the top. The views are very rewarding and well worth the effort. It is possible to fit it in after work and takes approximately one hour to the top if you keep a consistent pace. A leisurely  walk will take much longer and will provide for an opportunity to do birding and an opportunity sit on the rocky outcrops to enjoy the views which are fantastic! The route can be busy after work with runners so go during office hours if you prefer the peace and tranquillity of the bush.

title: The view pays off
text: Hiking there is just about choosing the right rocks to step on and you're good to go. It takes about an our to go t the top and the view is amazing! A must if you're staing in Gabs

title: Good Climb
text:
We took the kids for climb up Kgale Hill and enjoyed the outing very much. Just good old fashion sunshine, fresh air and exercise. 
Good for the whole family. 
Try you may just like it. 

Ben and family Mission

title: Mr T
text: Went up kgale hill. ...not easy but as long as u r determined u will reach the summit and hv a better view of gaborone and it's environs....

title: good hike!
text: Don't be put off by the entrance (cinder block stairs across an old fence). There is a small track which leads up the hill. My party only made it half way but we had great views and a fun walk. Definitely for the somewhat more intrepid visitor but fun, especially if you have limited time to get out of the city.

title: Superb view
text:
Well worth the effort given the peace, serenity and superb view from the top.
Don't expect however a simple guided journey up there. A taxi driver will drop you off on the main road at a set of concrete stairs over the fence marked by a coloured drum. From there you'll see a path straight ahead towards the base of the hill and another that seems it's a perimeter track headed hard left and right.
If you take the one straight ahead, after a few hundred meters it becomes almost indistinguishable amidst increasingly solid bushland as you then need to make out a route between large rockfaces. It's not hard as long as you plan out a sensible route to the top.

title: breathtaking
text: went up kgale sometime back, it was hard work getting there, takes a lot of dedication but once you get their, the view of the city is just breath-taking. Don't think il ever climb up there again, but I definitely don't regret the experience.

title: A great view of Gaborone
text: A great hike with a great view at the end. Just know that it is uphill the whole way and steep in some areas.

title: A harder walk than you might think
text: This is a harder walk than you might otherwise think particularly in the summer, make sure you set off early enough and take a bottle of wayer

title: Something for the sportive
text:
Stunning view!  Absolutely worth while going in the morning or evening!
30 minutes up-hill walk! But worth while the effort

title: 최고의 경치
text: 처음에 올라가는 길을 찾지 못해 헤맸었는데 다른 사람들을 따라가니 금방 정상에 도달했습니다. 사람들이 없는 시간대에 올라가다간 강도를 당할 수 있다고 해서 조금 무서웠지만 다행히 그런 문제는 없었네요. 정상에 올라간 뒤 좁은 길을 따라 통신소같은 곳으로 올라가야 진짜 탁 트인 전경을 맞이할 수 있습니다. 힘들었지만 그럴만한 가치가 있는 일이었네요. 가보로네에 가게 된다면 꼭 올라가봐야할 곳입니다.

title: Not our best camping experience in Botswana
text:
We reserved a campsite in the Mokolodi Nature Reserve close to Gabarone on our way to South Africa after a 3-week 4x4 Botswana trip. The Nature Reserve was easy to find and at the reception we were told to enter the park through a second gate and follow the signs to Chalets & Campsites and then to Campsites (no clear direction or indication of the time required). It turned out to be a long (4+ km) curved badly maintained stong track with big stones requiring a 4x4 and taking more than 25 minutes to find our campsite (we were the only campers). The sites are far apart (good for privacy) but with poor signs to the various sites. As we wanted to have diner in the restaurant we had to return and had an excellent diner but had to return to the campsite in the dusk and too late to light up the donkey boiler etc.
The campsite offered a boiler, shower, toilet, braai, flush toilet, dustbin, wash basin and fire place. No electricity, no lights. Cars passing during the night. And of course baboons.
Not our best camping experience in Botswana.
Our advice: come early and take your time to find the campsite.

title: Seriously dissatisfied and very expensive for the quality of the chalet
text: I was seriously dissatisfied, we asked for a chalet for 2 and then at the last minute they said the only availability was a chalet for 6 almost double the price 😡 we agreed as it had been along day .. supposedly the chalet had just been renovated…. Untrue, it was in serious need of a renovation and in the morning no water. Also the 2 person chalet stayed free … a shame it could be a loveyp’ace but it was a ripoff

title: camping near Gaborone
text:
ok its not Kutse or Central Kalahari but its close to Gaborone,
we camped thanks to our chobe 4x4 as it has all the equipment need to camp in game reserves. nice positioned campsites

title: Wonderful experience at Mokolodi
text: Good food. Wonderful service. Excellent vibe at the the restaurant. Wonderful atmosphere as place is out of town/ nature reserve.

title: First trip to Gaborone
text: We had a great time at the Game reserve. Got to see 3 different animals for the first time, Impalas, a Red Hartebeest, and the Greater Kudu. We also got to see a male Giraffe (he said he knew the sex because of its darker spots as opposed to the female ones that have lighter spots here) sitting down, waited for it to get up but it didnt for a long time. At the end of the ride we also got to see some Zebras with more Impalas. Our driver was really nice and gave us a great tour.

photos.caption: We had a great time at the game reserve, saw 3 different animals for the first time, Impalas, A Red Hartebeest, and the Greater Kudu. We also saw a Giraffe and some Zebras. Very happy.
